Title: T0425 AD10 CS 470 Monitoring Support 2023/24
Description:
National Highways (NH) is to continue with the provision of technical support on structures with safety critical, substandard components as identified by NH, Safety Engineering and Standards (SES policy CS470, Management of Substandard Structures. The task is to continue with the management of this risk commissioned under SPATs2 task, TO304. 
This task will look to take invested knowledge, any new knowledge acquired during task 304 to seamlessly manage these safety critical structures with recognised hidden critical defects. 
The successful contractor will also be required to work with AD10 staff, Design Services Contractor (DSC) as required, SES and 3rd part data providers who supply monitoring information for contractor analysis. This role will include 3rd party data interpretation with recommendations drawn for NH to act upon, including informing future strengthening works, in maintaining the safe and full operational use of these structures and the Strategic Road Network they carry. The task is to run throughout financial year 2022/23, reporting monthly on progress on finance, project and technical matters, liaising with monitoring data providers and adhoc queries as the need arises or increased risks dictate.
The asset knowledge, skills and expertise required for this task are discussed later in this work scope package.
Attachments: T0425 SPaTS 2 Award Letter - Trans.pdf

Title: GB-London: Small Works Framework
Description:
Network Homes (NH) invites applications from suitably experienced and qualified contractors to be appointed to a framework from which contracts will be called off for  dis-repair works, insurance works, FM type works and small works such as structural repairs, roofing works and similar to properties owned /managed by Network Homes.

NH intend to issue works of between £500 and £20,000 to the 4 successful contractors on a broadly rotational type basis but will however take into account Value for Money, current performance and the geographical spread of the works in allocating work.  Network therefore reserves the right to allocate works as they see most appropriate.
 
It is however important to note that there is no guarantee of work and as such NH do reserve the right not to issue works orders to one or more of the successful Contractors. The majority of the works instructed will be located in Brent, Westminster, East London and Hertford. Contractors must be able to provide the services in all areas.
Additional Text: The contracting authority considers that this contract may be suitable for economic operators that are small or medium enterprises (SMEs). However, any selection of tenderers will be based solely on the criteria set out for the procurement.

Title: Tender enquiry for NH CDC
Description: The Exeter Nightingale Community Diagnostic Centre centres on the reconfiguration of the existing Buttercup Ward at the Exeter Nightingale hospital to provide an extension to the existing physiological measurements service.  The Buttercup Ward was one of five wards created during the Covid-19 pandemic to provide a Covid escalation facility, latterly converted to an elective and diagnostic centre.   The works comprise the reconfiguration of existing layouts to better suit the intended function, together with works to better suit patient flow (and mechanical and electrical services modifications). The Trust require the facility to be operational within a constrained programme.  In order to best achieve this, the project will follow a two-stage method of procurement, with the Trust seeking initially to engage a contractor under a preconstruction services agreement to work alongside the consultant team to help define the scope, and develop the design for the scheme ahead of entering into Contract.  Whilst it will be confirmed as part of this exercise, the anticipated construction cost is expected to be in the region of £1.2m - £1.5m (excluding VAT).

Title: National Highways - LTC - Green Hydrogen Supply & Associated Services
Description:
National Highways is dedicated to achieving the lowest possible carbon solution to deliver the comprising works of the Nationally Significant Infrastructure Project (NSIP),  Lower Thames Crossing (LTC). 

We are seeking to engage with the market to ascertain the solutions available to achieve this ambitious engineering accomplishment that integrates the projects carbon reduction agenda.

NH wish to invite interested parties to partake in a second phase of market engagement exercise in relation to "Green Hydrogen Supply & Associated Services" pertaining to the LTC NSIP. The aim of this exercise is for us to better understand what is possible in regards of the Green Hydrogen value chain. 

The aim of the market engagement event will be to understand the capability and the capacity of the market in potentially delivering the following services:

1. Full Turnkey managed service - Generation, supply, compression, on-site, storage & refuelling of Green Hydrogen

2. Supply of Green Hydrogen

3. Compression & Liquification of Green Hydrogen

4. Transport/ logistics of Green Hydrogen

5. Distribution & refueling of Green Hydrogen on site

The format of the market engagement will be a series of online 1-2-1 sessions led by NH from 6th February 2023 - 28th February 2023,.To register your interest in attending this session, which will be held via MS Teams, please complete this form

https://forms.office.com/e/DQcWqw7LNR

Following the market engagement exercise and ratification of the procurement strategy, a PCR2015 compliant procedure will be undertaken to appoint suitably qualified supplier(s) for the provision of the identified requirements.
Region: Any region,North East,North West,Yorkshire and The Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West,Scotland,Wales
Additional Text:
Interested parties will not be prejudiced by any response or failure to respond to this Early Engagement Notice. Nor shall a response to this Early Engagement Notice guarantee an invitation to participate in any future procurement process that National Highways may conduct. This Early Engagement Notice does not constitute a call for competition to procure any works or services and is not published to reduce time limited for the receipt of tenders. National Highways is not bound to accept any proposals offered.

National Highways is not liable for any costs, fees or expenses incurred by any party responding to this Early Engagement Notice or any party who may participate in any future procurement process. In the event that National Highways decides to proceed with any procurement, it is currently assumed that such procurement will be carried out in accordance with the provisions of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 unless any legal requirement requires a different procedure to be adopted.

This Early Engagement Notice does not constitute any commitment by National Highways to undertake any public procurement exercise for Lower Thames Crossing.

Title: Responsive Repairs and Voids Contract
Description: The proposed contract will include the delivery of Responsive Repairs and Void Refurbishments, to properties owned and managed by Network Homes. The contract may include the delivery of planned and project works but this will be at NH discretion and will be dependent on performance. The successful Contractor shall deliver a high-quality service offering value for money to residents and also provide and secure continuous improvements across all of the works. The contract will be for an initial term of 5 years with a possible extension of a further 5 years (10 years in total) In advance of the re-procurement of this contract, NH will undertake some pre-market engagement activity and we will host a Pre-Market Engagement event to take place in April 2023. Further details will be made available to suppliers and interested parties in due course via this e-Sourcing portal.

Title: F0010b DIP Model Collaboration and Integration Assurance Programme B
Description:
The RDP programme is being delivered through an integrated delivery team model involving early engagement with NH and contractor supply base. The model is based on the delivery of an output-based specification for a defined and agreed budget, which is inclusive of the costs associated with the delivery of a scheme. This budget would have traditionally been the reserve of the client but is entrusted to the integrated teams to manage and deliver the outputs against. The commercial incentivisation is centred on out performance where value is created by achieving the required outputs at less cost but regulated against whole life cost of the asset being created.
This approach is novel to the industry and therefore a crucial element of its success will be NH's ability to encourage and develop consistency of performance across the programme. 
Currently, within the RDP programme there are a total of 18 Delivery Integrated Partnerships, all of which are at different levels of performance and behavioural maturity that require a more detailed understanding of exactly where they are on the spectrum.
Attachments: F0010b FAF Award Notice Deloitte - trans.docx

The RDP programme is being delivered through an integrated delivery team model involving early engagement with NH and contractor supply base. The model is based on the delivery of an output-based specification for a defined and agreed budget, which is inclusive of the costs associated with the delivery of a scheme. This budget would have traditionally been the reserve of the client but is entrusted to the integrated teams to manage and deliver the outputs against. The commercial incentivisation is centred on out performance where value is created by achieving the required outputs at less cost but regulated against whole life cost of the asset being created.
This approach is novel to the industry and therefore a crucial element of its success will be NH's ability to encourage and develop consistency of performance across the programme. 
Currently, within the RDP programme there are a total of 18 Delivery Integrated Partnerships, all of which are at different levels of performance and behavioural maturity that require a more detailed understanding of exactly where they are on the spectrum.
Attachments: F0010a FAF Award Notice The Orange Partnership - trans.docx

Title: T0238 M53 Clatterbridge Half Joint Calculation Review
Description:
National Highways (NH) has Hidden Critical Defects amongst its structures stock on the Strategic Road Network (SRN). Half Joint bridge construction is one such detail that is known to cause concern and is part of a national programme of Half Joint assessments aimed at understanding their condition and contribution to limiting capacity.
Ideally, the assessment will confirm that the HJ bridge capacity in its as-built condition is adequate for the route capacity. Where necessary, consider condition factors associated with a bridge, several decades old.
In Area10 on the M53, Clatterbridge Bridges, an interchange junction, have been assessed by NH's Design Services Contractor, Amey. The uncertified capacity is indicating a capacity less than expected based on results achieved on similar bridges with similar design on that route. That is affecting how the bridge is managed and monitored.

Organisation Name: NH South Yorkshire Integrated Care Board Doncaster Place
Title: NHS South Yorkshire Integrated Care Board : Attempted Suicide Resilience Service Doncaster place :
Description:
The Five Year Forward View for Mental Health  set out clear recommendations on suicide prevention and reduction, and made a commitment to reduce suicides by 10% nationally by 2020/21. Alongside this, in 2018, Jeremy Hunt (then secretary of state for health and social care) announced a zero-suicide ambition for mental health inpatients.

The preventing suicides in England strategy, March 2021  estimates that annually 800,000 people across the world die by suicide, with 5,316 people sadly taking their life in England in 2019.

Within the NHS Long Term Plan, the NHS's made a commitment to make suicide prevention a priority over the next decade, implementing a new Safety Improvement Programme across all mental health trusts, and setting out important measures to improve crisis care services. 

All areas of the country will receive investment in their services, by 2023 to 2024, to further support local suicide prevention plans.

SY ICB have had a focus over the last few years on providing self-harm and suicide awareness training for all staff in primary care and running both a large-scale prevention campaign working with local organisations, and events that are accessible and relevant amongst males such as sport, leisure facilities and service industries. Part of the funding has been used to improve pathways and support for patients (including children and young people and people with personality disorder) presenting with self-harm, including in acute hospitals and mental health services. 

Finally, the ICS will consider consistent and cost-effective bereavement support pathways across the ICS, including enhancing data sharing agreements across organisations and improving real time surveillance. 

In addition to this as part of the Alternative approaches Service an element of funding in Doncaster is dedicated to providing support to people who have recently attempted suicide, as outlined within this specification.

The contract is for three years with option to extend by two years making a maximum of five years. The value given in this notice is for the full five year term.
Contact Address 1: NHS South Yorkshire Integrated Care Board

Title: Procurement for the provision of Gender Dysphoria Surgical Services to NHS England, NHS Scotland and NHS Wales
Description:
NHS England and NHS Scotland seek bids from providers who have the capability and capacity to deliver Gender Dysphoria Surgical Services. Services being procured are Chest surgery (trans masculine), Genital surgery (trans feminine) and Genital surgery (trans masculine).

The Services will be available to individuals eligible for NHS-funded care who are ordinarily resident in England, Scotland or Wales - or otherwise who are the commissioning responsibility of the NHS in England, Scotland or Wales - and who meet the eligibility criteria described in the Service Specification. Successful Bidders will hold a single contract with NHS England for services provided to eligible patients who are the commissioning responsibility of NHS England, NHS Scotland and NHS Wales.

The NHS pathway of care for adults with gender dysphoria will differ according to the individual's goals. The envisaged adult pathway may typically be summarised as: 

•	Referral to a specialist Gender Dysphoria Clinic 
•	Assessment for gender dysphoria, and diagnosis
•	Individuals who meet the criteria for diagnosis of gender dysphoria are accepted on to the NHS care pathway and an individual treatment plan is agreed between the individual and their lead clinician in the Gender Dysphoria Clinic
•	Certain therapeutic interventions are delivered by the Gender Dysphoria Clinic; and / or referral for interventions with other providers; which may include recommendations to primary care for prescribing endocrine treatments
•	Gender Dysphoria Clinic makes a referral for surgical interventions of the chest and genitals if criteria are met via a planned National Referral Support Service
•	Ongoing review and monitoring during and after interventions
•	Conclusion of contact: discharge to primary care

Contracts will be for an initial term of 5 years with a possible extension of any period up to a further 2 years as defined and at the discretion of the Commissioner.

The approach for improving the surgical market is focused on establishing a flexible contract that facilitates patient choice based on a consideration of reliable data including new quality indicators. No volumes are guaranteed on the award of a contract.

This procurement is being carried out by NHS South, Central and West Commissioning Support Unit (SCW) on behalf of the Commissioners.
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and The Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West,Scotland,Wales,Isle of Man,Channel Islands
Additional Text:
Interested providers will be able to view this notice via the 'current tenders' list on the e-procurement system In-Tend, available on the following link: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/scwcsu/aspx/Home 

In order to submit a bid, you will need to be registered on the e-procurement system and 'express an interest', and then complete a response as specified within the procurement documents. 

On registration, please include at least two contacts to allow for access to the system in times of absence.

The services are healthcare services falling within Schedule 3 to the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 ("the Regulations")  which are not subject to the full regime of the Regulations, but is instead governed by the "Light Touch Regime" contained within Chapter 3, Section 7 of the Regulations (Regulations 74 to 77).

The tendering process will be conducted in accordance with the requirements and flexibilities provided by Articles 74 to 76 of the Directive, and Regulations 74 to 76 of the Regulations. The Authority will run a transparent tender process, treating all Bidders equally. For the avoidance of doubt, the Authority will not be bound by the Regulations or the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union or any other regulations or legislation except for the specific parts or circumstances that apply to the procurement of these Services. 
  
Neither the inclusion of a Bidder selection stage, nor the use of any language or terms found in the Directive or Regulations, nor the description of the procedure voluntarily adopted by the Authority ("Open", "Restricted", "Competitive Procedure with Negotiation", "Competitive Dialogue" or any other description), nor any other indication, shall be taken to mean that the Authority intends to hold itself bound by the Directive or Regulations, save by the provisions applicable to services coming within the scope of Annex XIV of the Directive / Schedule 3 of the Regulations. 

The Contracting Authority intends to voluntarily observe the award decision notices provisions and 10 day standstill period described in Regulation 86 of the Regulations. Unsuccessful Bidders will receive scores and reasons for the decision, including the characteristics and relative advantages of the winning bid and the reasons why the Bidder/application was unsuccessful. Deadline for lodging of appeals should be in accordance with Regulation 87 and Regulation 91 of the Regulations.

Organisation Name: NHS Midlands and Lancashire Commissioning Support Unit
Title: NHS Chorley & South Ribble CCG, NHS Greater Preston CCG, NHS Morecambe Bay CCG, NHS West Lancashire CCG, NHS Blackpool CCG and NHS Fylde and Wyre CCG Online Counselling Service for 11-16 year olds
Description:
Chorley & South Ribble Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG), Greater Preston CCG, Morecambe Bay CCG, West Lancashire CCG, Blackpool CCG and Fylde and Wyre CCG are inviting suitably experienced and qualified organisations to participate in this 'Invitation to Tender' for an online counselling service for 11-16 year olds. This service will support children and young people with emotional wellbeing and/or emerging mental health problems, many of whom will require a low level/targeted/short-term intervention.
    
Online counselling has the potential to revolutionise the way in which we provide support to children and young people. It opens up access out of traditional working hours and allows young people to contact counsellors from their own home or at a location preferred to them and via a digital medium they are comfortable with.  Online forums also empower young people by helping them to learn more about the problems they are facing and facilitating the sharing of experiences with others going through the same difficulties.

A service specification is available on request which provides further details regarding the service being commissioned.  

There is an existing contract in place to deliver this service that is due to end on the 30th September 2019. 

The new contract is intended to be for an initial period of 6 months with the option to extend up to a further 2 years. It is proposed that the new contract commences at the earliest opportunity following the award of contract (end of September 2019), however a suitable mobilisation/transition period will be agreed with the new provider prior to the full commencement of the new contract.

The contract value for the initial 6 months is £81,730.
Additional Text:
If your organisation is interested in this opportunity and requires further information please contact the buyer at mlcsu.tendersnorth@nhs.net to register your interest. Once you have registered your interest the tender documents (including the service specification) will be forwarded to you via email. 

The deadline to formally submit a bid is the 23rd September 2019 at 12 noon.  Any tenders received after this date will not be considered. 

How to apply

Please apply (via email)  directly to the buyer using the contact details provided.

Title: Market Engagement Event for Non-Emergency Patient Transportation Services - NHS Herefordshire CCG, NHS Redditch & Bromsgrove CCG, NHS South Worcestershire CCG, and NHS Wyre Forest CCG:
Description:
This is an Advert for an Engagement Event to gauge market interest which will influence the future commissioning direction.

NHS Midlands and Lancashire Commissioning Support Unit on behalf of NHS Herefordshire CCG, NHS Redditch & Bromsgrove CCG, NHS South Worcestershire CCG and NHS Wyre Forest CCG (which will henceforth be known as 'the CCGs'), is seeking to engage with potential Providers for the provision of non-emergency patient transportation services.

The CCGs intend to jointly go to market in March 2019 under Schedule 3 of the Public Contract Regulations 2015 to procure a non-emergency patient transportation service for the health population of the counties of Herefordshire and Worcestershire. It is likely that the duration of the service contract will be five (5) years, with the option to extend for an additional two (2) years, subject to agreement. 

The aim of the market engagement event will be to engage with potential providers for these services in order to share the commissioning intentions of the CCGs, and to seek the input from providers on a number important aspects relating to the services, including the service specification. The CCGs would like to assess the current market appetite to provide this service and identify any barriers to successful implementation. The outcomes of the market engagement event will then determine next steps. 

Please note, as the service specification is still under development, the estimated contract value of £20m (for the 5-year period) is an indicative figure only, intended as a guide, and may be subject to change prior to any future procurement exercise.

At the event, the commissioning authority will also present information regarding the proposed procurement process and procurement time line.

At the event there will also be an opportunity for providers to network with other providers and the commissioners.

The event will be held on: 
Wednesday, 30th January 2019 
At: 10am to 12noon (Registration from 9.30am)
Location: The Meeting Room, Malvern Community Hospital, 185 Worcester Road, Malvern WR14 1EX. 

Please note no more than 2 attendees per organisation should attend.

Closing date for registration is 22nd January 2019 by 12 noon. Please note that after this deadline participation cannot be guaranteed.  

To book places at this Market Engagement Event, please use the Bravo Solution e-portal to complete a Response Form. Bravo Solution can be found here: https://mlcsu.bravosolution.co.uk/web/login.shtml.

Please access Bravo Project Code 634, and the Response Form can be found at PQQ 468 within this Project.

For instructions on how to register your organisation on Bravo Solution, please see additional text below. 

As above, we politely request no more than 2 representatives from each organisation.
Contact Name: Lyle Lloyd MCIPS, Senior Procurement Officer, MLCSU
Additional Text:
How to Register your company on the BravoSolution e-Tendering portal (this is only required once): 

1 Go to https://mlcsu.bravosolution.co.uk/web/login.shtml 
2 Click on the Click Here to register link 
3 Enter your organisation details in the form Registration Data and click Save
4 Continue to enter your details in the form: Basic Profile Form: Basic Form - Company Details. Click Save
5 You will receive an email from Bravo Solutions with your user ID and another email with your temporary password 
6 Go back to the Bravo login page and login with your new details 
7 Accept the terms and conditions by clicking  I agree and then Next
8 On the next screen you will be asked to specify a new password (for security reasons) 
9 You are now registered and ready to use the portal. 
10. Search for the Project code_634 (then PQQ_468 for the Response Form)

Title: Termination Of Pregnancy Service - NHS Hastings and Rother CCG, NHS Eastbourne, Hailsham and Seaford CCG, NHS High Weald Lewes and Havens CCG - Request for Information (RFI) - NHS/SoEPS/17.381 RFI
Description:
The Commissioners (NHS Hastings and Rother CCG, NHS Eastbourne, Hailsham and Seaford CCG and NHS High Weald Lewes and Havens CCG ) seek your views for this requirement and asks a number of set questions, which can be accessed via the In-Tend e-portal.

We expect you will find some questions more relevant to you and easier to respond to than others at the moment. Please try to respond to as many as you can as your views are valuable whether or not you have come across all of the aspects covered.

This is a process designed to help the Commissioner form a view of the best way to commission the service and is not the beginning of a Tender exercise. A further Tender advertisement will be issued at the appropriate time where required. Your feedback at this point will not have a bearing on any future Tender submissions you may wish to offer at a later date. You will not be disadvantaged if you choose not to respond to this RFI but it will be helpful to understand your views at this early stage, so you are encouraged to respond as fully as you can.

Complete your response and return via our InTend eTendering Portal reference SoEPS/17.381 using the correspondence functionality by 24th November  at 17:00. 

Thank you for your participation - Commissioners' appreciate your time and effort in completing this RFI, which will remain confidential apart from main/sub contractor information exchange opportunity (if used) at the end of the document.
Attachments: Instructions_for_Registering_on_the_SoEPS_Commissioning_Support_In-tend_Portal.pdf

Title: Parenteral Nutrition
Description:
This is an award notice not a call to competition.

The use of nutrition products is split between:-
Unmixed licensed multi-chamber PN bags
Licensed multi-chamber PN bags that have been supplemented with standard vitamins and
trace elements in suitable aseptic facilities (to make unlicensed bags) Components used for compounding and additions to bags (e.g. infusion fluids, vitamins)
Consumables (e.g. empty bags) Standardised unlicensed neonatal bags and syringes (suitable for supply to hospital after aseptic manufacture as part of a batch)

The contract does not include PN supplied for homecare.

The Contracting Authority for this ranked framework contract is Berkshire Healthcare NHS
Foundation Trust on behalf of the Thames Valley and Wessex Pharmacy Procurement Service. The
Purchasing Authorities expected to access this contract are:
Buckinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust
Dorset County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust
Frimley Health NHS Foundation Trust
Hampshire Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
Isle of Wight NHS Trust
Milton Keynes University Hospital
Oxford University Hospitals NHS Trust (see note below**)
Poole Hospital NHS Foundation Trust
Portsmouth Hospitals NHS Trust (including the Regional Manufacturing Unit)
Royal Berkshire NHS Foundation Trust
The Royal Bournemouth and Christchurch Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
University Hospital Southampton NHS Foundation Trust
This framework will also be available for use by Trusts in Kent, Surrey and Sussex (South East
Coast)
covering:
East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust
Maidstone and Tunbridge Wells NHS Trust .
Medway NHS Foundation Trust .
Dartford and Gravesham NHS Trust .
Brighton and Sussex University Hospital NHS Trust .
Queen Victoria Hospital NHS Foundation Trust .
Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust .
Western Sussex Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust .
East Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust .
Ashford and St Peter's Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust .
Royal Surrey County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust
*Oxford University Hospitals NHS Trust has a local contract for PN and would only use this
contract in the unlikely event that the local contract was terminated.
The contract is divided into four lots.

Title: Trustwide Domestic Waste and Recycling service to Birmingham Community  Healthcare NHS FT
Description:
The current service is out-sourced and in contract until 31/08/2022
 
The Trust are procuring a Trust wide Domestic waste and Recycling service for go live from September 1st 2022 for 5 years and 2 optional years 

The procurement  will be aligned to the NHSSBS framework SBS/17/NH/MXR/9307 : Waste Management and Minimisation services Lot 4 and suppliers awarded to this Lot. Tender documents will be available from 1.11.21 on the Trust e-tendering portal https://procontract.due-north.com/register 

The contractor will be responsible for the Trusts food, domestic and recycling,  waste streams in terms of
•	Segregation
•	Collection and transportation 
•	Recycling and treatment 
The waste streams aligned to the service are :
•	Cardboard and Packaging waste
•	Dry Mixed Recycling (DMR) 
•	WEEE Waste
•	Skips
•	General Waste
•	Plaster Waste 
•	Food Waste
•	Glass Waste 
•	Furniture and Bulky Waste
•	Chemical Waste

Excluded from the contract are : 
•	Used Household Batteries 
•	Scrap Metal recycling 
•	Buildings / Ground Waste / Construction Demolition Waste
•	Offensive / Hygiene Waste
•	Clinical Waste

The Trust wide non-hazardous scheduled  service will be required over 62 locations across Birmingham and across 6 locations for the ad-hoc non-hazardous service 

The service is required  from Monday to Sunday including all Public Holidays during site access times

TUPE is not applicable to this contract 

The award will on a sole supplier basis for duration of the contract.

Organisation Name: NHS ARDEN AND GREATER EAST MIDLANDS COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Market Engagement - Non-Emergency Patient Transport Services for NHS Herts Valleys (HVCCG), NHS East and North Hertfordshire (ENHCCG) and NHS West Essex (WECCG) Clinical Commissioning Groups
Description:
Market Engagement - Non-Emergency Patient Transport Services (NEPTS) for NHS Herts Valleys (HVCCG), NHS East and North Hertfordshire (ENHCCG) and NHS West Essex (WECCG) Clinical Commissioning Groups

NHS Arden & Greater East Midlands Commissioning Support Unit (AGCSU) on behalf of the Commissioners, NHS Herts Valleys Clinical Commissioning Group (HVCCG) (Lead Commissioner), NHS East and North Hertfordshire Clinical Commissioning Group (ENHCCG) and NHS West Essex Clinical Commissioning Group (WECCG), as part of the Hertfordshire and West Essex Integrated Care System (ICS) and collectively referred to as "the Commissioners", would like to invite interested Providers, to take part in a market engagement process. This process will further inform an anticipated contract offer and associated procurement process to cover NEPTS for the entire Hertfordshire and West Essex Integrated Care System.  

Following the market engagement exercise held in Autumn / Winter 2021 the Commissioners are seeking to engage with the marketplace to seek feedback on the proposed contract and procurement structure(s), including Bidding requirements, and to investigate market development requirements, if any.

To allow for an appropriate commissioning, procurement, and mobilisation process (following the feedback gained during the previous market engagement), the Commissioners are seeking to undertake a tendering exercise commencing in June 2022.  With a view to awarding a contract in March/ April 2023 to allow for a potential 12 month mobilisation period following on from Contract Award.  Note that this has not been finalised due to seeking feedback via this engagement. 

This engagement is taking place via completion of a form on Microsoft Forms. The information provided will be kept confidential where possible. However, if information is gained that results in changes made to the draft service specification, performance metrics, other contract documentation or any of the associated tender documentation, then an audit trail that may detail the Provider could be deemed releasable under the Freedom of Information (FOI) Act or any other applicable request mechanisms for the NHS.  
If you have not already done so and would like to informally register your interest in the procurement process and be added to a delegate list whom courtesy emails will be sent with updates on the procurement, then please complete the relevant questions on the form linked below.

The Microsoft Form to submit your views and feedback is at the following link: 
https://forms.office.com/r/iBmTrNt3DR 
The deadline to submit your registration form is 5pm 27th April 2022. You can submit more than one form, but you are not able to edit what you may have already submitted. If you think of further information you would like to share please just submit a new form.

Please note any financial or service information contained within this advert are not final.
Additional Text:
Responding to this advert, registering to take part in this engagement or registering your interest does not commit any Provider to taking part in any anticipated procurement process or count as a formal expression of interest. This advert also does not commit the Commissioners to continuing this project and / or publishing any procurement or tendering process(es).
You are also advised to register on the procurement portal (EU Supply / Mercell) if you have not done so already, instructions for this are:

To register on the portal: 
» 	https://uk.eu-supply.com/login.asp?B=UK
»	From the portal Home Page, click the "New Supplier Registration" link on the left if you have not registered before, or log in on the right if your organisation is already registered (please note the portal will not allow multiple registrations for the same organisation so if your company already has log in details, these must be utilised)
»	By registering, or logging in you are accepting the terms & conditions for using the portal. 
	
If you require technical support with logging on to EU Supply (Mercell), please contact:

•	uksupport@eu-supply.com 
•	0800 840 2050 during office hours ONLY (08.00 to 17.00)

Please note there is no live project or tender on the procurement portal at this time.

Organisation Name: NHS ARDEN AND GREATER EAST MIDLANDS COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Market Engagement - Non-Emergency Patient Transport Services (NEPTS) for NHS Herts Valleys (HVCCG), NHS East and North Hertfordshire (ENHCCG) and NHS West Essex (WECCG) Clinical Commissioning Groups
Description:
Market Engagement - Non-Emergency Patient Transport Services for NHS Herts Valleys (HVCCG), NHS East and North Hertfordshire (ENHCCG) and NHS West Essex (WECCG) Clinical Commissioning Groups

NHS Arden & Greater East Midlands Commissioning Support Unit (AGCSU) on behalf of the Commissioners, NHS Herts Valleys Clinical Commissioning Group (HVCCG) (Lead Commissioner), NHS East and North Hertfordshire Clinical Commissioning Group (ENHCCG) and NHS West Essex Clinical Commissioning Group (WECCG) would like to invite interested Providers, to take part in a market engagement process to further inform an anticipated contract offer and associated procurement process, using expert Provider-led information.

This engagement is taking place via semi-structured interviews, between Commissioners and Providers who register their interest. The interviews will be done on an individual Provider basis and kept confidential where possible. However, if information is gained that results in changes made to the draft service specification, performance metrics, other contract documentation or any of the associated tender documentation, then an audit trail that may detail the Provider could be deemed releasable under the Freedom of Information (FOI) Act or any other applicable request mechanisms for the NHS.

The interview slots will be for 90 minutes and will take place using Microsoft Teams (delegates will be sent an email / calendar invite). The interviews are anticipated to take place on 19th, 20th, or 21st October 2021. You can register to take part in this interview process on the form linked below. 
If you have a request for a specific date, we will try to accommodate this but please note it cannot be guaranteed. Thank you for your understanding.

If you would like to informally register your interest in the procurement process and be added to a delegate list whom courtesy emails will be sent with updates on the procurement, then please complete the relevant questions on the form linked below. 

The Microsoft Form to submit your interest in attending an interview or anticipated procurement process can be found at the following link: 
https://forms.office.com/r/BTJZREspvY   


The deadline to submit your registration form is 5pm 11th October 2021. You can submit more than one form, but you are not able to edit what you may have already submitted. If you change your mind or delegate details etc., please just submit a new form. 

Please note any financial or service information contained within this advert are not final and you must take proper care to read the final tender when published. 

Responding to this advert, registering to take part in this engagement or registering your interest does not commit any Provider to taking part in any anticipated procurement process or count as  formal expression of interest. This advert also does not commit the Commissioners to continuing this project and process.

Organisation Name: STAFFORDSHIRE AND LANCASHIRE COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Tier 4 Bariatrics Service - Lancashire, Cumbria, Merseyside CCGs
Description:
NHS Midlands & Lancashire Commissioning Support Unit (CSU) is working on behalf of Lancashire, Cumbria and Merseyside CCGs. This invitation to tender is for Tier 4 Bariatric & Weight Loss Service in Lancashire, Cumbria and Merseyside. NHS Chorley & South Ribble CCG will be the lead commissioner on behalf of the following CCGs:
NHS Blackburn with Darwen CCG
NHS Blackpool CCG
NHS Greater Preston CCG
NHS Chorley & South Ribble CCG
NHS East Lancashire CCG
NHS West Lancashire CCG
NHS Fylde & Wyre CCG
NHS Morecambe Bay CCG 
NHS North Cumbria CCG
NHS Halton CCG
NHS Knowsley CCG
NHS Liverpool CCG
NHS South Sefton CCG
NHS Southport and Formby CCG
NHS St Helens CCG
NHS Warrington CCG
NHS Wirral CCG

Please note this may be extended to include NHS Cheshire CCG as a commissioning organisation to be added to the contract at a later date following the award of contract.

This procurement is based on two lots around the geographical areas as detailed above: Lot 1: Lancashire and Cumbria CCGs and Lot 2: Merseyside CCGs (with Cheshire CCG potentially coming on board at a later stage). 

The ITT will be live on Thursday 14th April 2022 on the MLCSU Bravo portal (see below) & it will have a deadline for submissions on Friday 27th May 2022 12:00pm.

A maximum of 2 providers may be selected in each lot, one of which must be an NHS Acute provider. There will be a maximum of 4 providers across both lots. The highest scoring NHS Acute Provider for each lot will be recommended as a successful bidder. Secondary, the highest scoring bidder, whether this is another bidder from the NHS Acute sector or another bidder from the Independent Sector, they will also be recommended as a successful bidder. 

The Indicative Financial Cost Envelope for Lancashire & Cumbria (based on 100% activity) is £1,401,139 per annum (at 2021/22 tariff prices). 5 years total (£7,005,695), with an option to extend for a further 2 years (£2,802,278) gives a total indicative contract value for Lot 1 of £9,807,973.

The Indicative Financial Cost Envelope for Merseyside (including Wirral & Warrington) (based on 100% activity) is £1,865,210 per annum (at 2021/22 tariff prices). 5 years total would be £9,326,050, with an option to extended for a further 2 years (£3,730,420) gives a total indicative contract value for Lot 2 of £13,056,470.

Total for both lots £22,864,443   

The contract is for 5 years with an option to extend for 2 years.

The Commissioner reserves the right to reject bids that exceed the indicated budget.

Candidates wishing to be considered must register their expression of interest & provide additional procurement-specific information (by registering on the Bravo portal). Candidates should register on the portal at https://mlcsu.bravosolution.co.uk (registration and use of the website is free of charge).
Additional Text:
This procurement is for Social and other specific services which are Light Touch Regime services for the purpose of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 as specified in Schedule 3 of the Regulations ('Regulations') http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2015/102/schedule/3/made

Accordingly, the Contracting Authority is only bound by those parts of the Regulations detailed in Chapter 3 Particular Procurement Regimes Section 7 http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2015/102/part/2/chapter/3/made


The Contracting Authority is not voluntarily following any other part of the Regulations.

As the CCG is a relevant body for the purpose of the National Health Service (Procurement, Patient Choice and Competition) (No 2) Regulations 2013 these Regulations also apply to this procurement.
Right to Cancel: The Contracting Authority reserves the right to discontinue the procurement process at any time, which shall include the right not to award a contract or contracts, and does not bind itself to accept the lowest tender, or any tender received, and reserves the right to award a contract in part, or to call for new tenders should it consider this necessary.

The Contracting Authority shall not be liable for any costs or expenses incurred by any candidate or tenderer in connection with the completion and return of the information requested in this Contract Notice, or in the completion or submission of any tender, irrespective of the outcome of the competition or if the competition is cancelled or postponed.
All dates, time periods and values specified in this notice are provisional and the Contracting Authority reserves the right to change these.
Transparency: The Contracting Authority is subject to the Freedom of Information Act 2000 (FOIA) and the Environmental Information Regulations 2004 (EIR) and may be required to disclose information received in the course of this procurement under FOIA or the EIR.

In addition, and in accordance with the UK Government's policies on transparency, the contracting authority intends to publish procurement documentation and the text of any resulting contractual arrangements, subject to possible redactions at the discretion of the Contracting Authority.

Any redactions, whether in relation to information requests under FOIA, the EIR or policies on transparency will be in accordance with those grounds prescribed under the Freedom of Information Act. If and when this requirement is offered to tender, this will be done via electronic means using the internet. Midlands and Lancashire CSU is conducting this procurement exercise as a central purchasing body for another NHS body with whom the successful bidder(s) will enter into contracts for the supply of the services.

Any other public-sector body detailed within this notice, wishing to access the contract may do so only with permission from the contracting NHS body.

Further details will be made available via documentation and information.

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: School Aged Immunisations Services - NHS England & NHS Improvement South East
Description:
This is to inform the market of future commissioning intentions in the South East Region for NHS England & NHS Improvement for School Aged Immunisations Services. 

NHS England and NHS Improvement has extended six contracts for School Aged Immunisations (SAI) services held by the South East Region, to achieve a contract end date for each of them of July 2024, in order to allow services to complete and catch up on the programme of work which was delayed and expanded due to the pandemic. As a result of all of the material factors, the extension is justified under regulation 72 (1)(b).

The school aged immunisation services to which this aggregated Notice applies to are:
•           Berkshire Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust  
•           Buckingham Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust  
•           Oxford Health NHS Foundation Trust   
•           Sussex Community NHS Foundation Trust  
•           Kent Community Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
Please note the timescales have changed from previous communications, these are indicative and any planned procurement may be subject to change due to legislative changes expected in 2022. 

The indicative timeline below is for School Aged Immunisation (SAI) opportunities in the South East Region for:
•           Berkshire
•           Buckinghamshire
•           Oxfordshire
•           Kent and Medway
•           Sussex

Market and stakeholder engagement to commence - Early 2023
Publication of tender - March 2023
Planned contract commencement - August 2024

South Central and West Commissioning Support (CSU) is a commissioning support service hosted by NHS England and is acting on behalf of NHS England & NHS Improvement

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH OF ENGLAND PROCUREMENT SERVICES
Title: Sussex 111 Service - NHS 111 Clinical Assessment Service, Home Visiting Service and Out of Hours Service for Sussex
Description:
The seven* Sussex Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs), acting together under a Collaborative Commissioning Agreement, wish to procure a Service Provider for the NHS 111 Clinical Assessment Service, Home Visiting and Out of Hours Service for Sussex (See Note 1). Each year the NHS provides around 110 million urgent same day patient contacts, with around 85 million of these being urgent GP appointments and the remaining being though A&E or minor injury clinics.
In Sussex the NHS 111 service takes around 363,000 calls a year, with 75% being taken out of hours (6.30pm-8am).  Within the existing Kent, Medway Surrey and Sussex contract around 43% of the total calls taken are for Sussex.
The Commissioners have agreed to offer the contract as a 5 year initial term with a single option to extend forup to a further two years (5 +2 = 7 years maximum duration) at the sole discretion of the Commissioner. The Commissioners will take the view to extend to the full seven years as soon as it is appropriate but with the first consideration at 18 months and thereafter at regular intervals. The vision for a more integrated urgent care system across Sussex will improve patient care and choice, as well as, streamlining and improving services for staff working in both primary and urgent care. The new NHS 111, Clinical Assessment Service and Out of Hours Service will be vital in the journey to integrate urgent care across Sussex. 
The Commissioners have set a maximum total financial envelope of £72.72m for the seven year maximum duration of the contract.
The new service will need to be in place by 1st April 2019, and the Commissioners expect to complete the procurement process and award the contract during August 2018.
The deadline for submission of completed bids is Thursday 29th March 2018 at 12:00pm (midday).
* The Seven Sussex Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) are:
NHS Coastal West Sussex (Acting as the Lead Commissioner)
NHS Brighton and Hove
NHS Crawley
NHS Eastbourne, Hailsham and Seaford
NHS Hastings and Rother
NHS High Weald Lewes Havens
NHS Horsham and Mid Sussex

Note 1: Home Visiting and Out of Hours service provision for NHS Coastal West Sussex CCG is outside the scope of this procurement:  the CCG is commissioning this separately. 
The NHS standard contract will be used, as amended at the time of contract award i.e. currently 2017-19 contract, amended by National Variation effective from 1 Feb 2018 and therefore Providers will be expected to meet all standards therein. The successful Provider shall use, when applicable, the NHS Standard Sub-Contract for the Provision of Clinical Services, as recommended by NHS England and the Department of Health, as amended at the time of contract award i.e. currently 2017-19 contract, amended by National Variation effective from 1 Feb 2018: https://www.england.nhs.uk/publication/template-sub-contract-for-the-provision-of-clinical-services-for-use-with-nhs-standard-contract-full-length-2017-18-and-2018-19/
Attachments: Instructions_for_Registering_on_the_SoEPS_Commissioning_Support_In-tend_Portal.pdf
Additional Text:
The tender documents will be available with free, unrestricted access at the e-tendering portal https://in-tendhost.co.uk/soepscommissioning after 10am on Monday 12th February 2018.  All correspondence relating to this procurement should be raised via the portal and no other correspondence will be responded to.  
Late submissions will not be accepted.  The e-portal system will shutdown at 12:00pm and any bids submitted to the system after this time will not be accepted.  Therefore, please submit in good time prior to the deadline date and time. The Services to which this ITT relates fall within Chapter 3, Section 7, Particular Procurement Regimes to thePublic Contracts Regulations 2015 and Part H of the Annex V to the Public Contracts Directive (also known as'light touch regime' formerly Part B services). Title: Greener NHS Staff Campaign
Description:
The NHS is a world-leading healthcare system with a long history of firsts. It was the first healthcare system free at the point of service.  In October 2020, the NHS became the world's first healthcare system to commit to reaching net zero

Reaching this goal matters. The core purpose of the NHS is to improve patient and community health outcomes. Climate change threatens this purpose, undermining the foundations of good health and putting the NHS, its staff, and the people it serves at risk. Tackling climate change is lifesaving, with health benefits gained through cleaner air, active lifestyles, and improved diets. As the UK's largest employer, contributing 4.6% of carbon emissions, the NHS is part of the challenge and the solution. It has a collective responsibility to act, with all 1.3 million staff having a role to play.

The second half of 2021 offers renewed hope. The UK will host COP26 - the world's largest climate action conference. This major international event provides a focal point to inspire raised ambition across the NHS and beyond. As the NHS emerges from the crisis phase of the pandemic, restrictions relax, and the external agenda on climate action intensifies, there is a converging opportunity for the Greener NHS team to re-affirm the NHS commitment to Net Zero and re-engage staff in showing their support for building a Greener NHS - and a healthy, sustainable recovery.

Complementing other targeted communications activity within and beyond the NHS, we will launch a staff engagement campaign in the second week of July - following on from the NHS Birthday, as a means to look forward - after what has been moment of reflection and thanks for what has gone before. The campaign will launch ahead of the Olympics, leading up to our Net Zero Ambition Anniversary [30th September], and culminating in COP26. 

Staff Engagement Campaign Objectives
It will take the support of all 1.3 million staff to ensure the NHS reaches its net zero goal. We want to launch a grassroots staff engagement campaign in the second week of July through to COP26, that will:
•	Build understanding and support among NHS staff in its Net Zero ambition and the importance of building a greener NHS to improve health now and for future generations
•	Inspire NHS staff to pledge support or take an action that demonstrates tangible support for a Greener NHS and/or reduces their carbon footprint, contributing to the overall net zero ambition 

Documents can be found at https://health-family.force.com/s/Welcome

Title: Non-Emergency Patient Transport (Birmingham, Sandwell & Solihull)
Description:
The four CCGs in Birmingham, Sandwell and Solihull have taken over responsibility for funding Non-Emergency Patient Transport services (NEPT). The project is being led by Birmingham CrossCity CCG, in partnership with Birmingham South Central CCG, Sandwell and West Birmingham CCG and Solihull CCGs. It also involves other CCGs and populations within the wider West Midlands area, who use NEPT services. 

These CCGs are:
•	NHS South East Staffs and Seisdon Peninsular CCG
•	NHS Redditch and Bromsgrove CCG
•	NHS Herefordshire CCG 
•	NHS South Worcestershire CCG
•	NHS Walsall CCG
•	NHS Dudley CCG
•	NHS Wyre Forest CCG
•	NHS South Warwickshire CCG
•	NHS Wolverhampton CCG
•	NHS Cannock Chase CCG
•	NHS Stafford and Surrounds CCG
•	NHS Shropshire CCG
•	NHS Telford and Wrekin CCG

A review of NEPT services has shown that there is significant variation in delivery of these services between NHS hospital trusts across Birmingham and Solihull. There is also insufficient evidence available to CCGs about the quality of these services, or the extent to which they are meeting the needs of patients. Commissioners have aggregated a significant number of non-emergency patient transport (NEPT) service contracts in the Birmingham and Solihull area to ensure standardisation of services and seek improvements in quality, productivity and efficiency. The scope of this non-emergency patient transport (NEPT) service shall include provision of NEPT to and from the following healthcare premises of the following NHS Trusts or other services: • Birmingham Community Healthcare NHS Trust; • Birmingham Women’s Hospital NHS Foundation Trust; • Heart of England NHS Foundation Trust; • Royal Orthopaedic NHS Foundation Trust; • University Hospital Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust; • Worcestershire Acute Hospital NHS Trust (for BSOL CCGs only); • GP referrals for same day assessment (for BSOL CCGs only) • Or other secondary or community NHS service as defined by the commissioners. A detailed description (draft service specification) of the requirements can be obtained via the Bravo eProcurement system.
Please see instructions later in this notice (VI.3) for details of how to access this information. The contract duration will be five years with a two year extension option
Additional Text:
NHS Midlands and Lancashire CSU is conducting this procurement exercise as a central purchasing body for another NHS body (please refer to the PQQ and/or MOI for details) with whom the successful bidder(s) will enter into contracts for the supply of the services. Any other public sector body wishing to access the contract may do so only with permission from the contracting NHS body. The contract conditions will be set out in the Invitation to Tender. Further details will be made available via documentation released during the course of the tender process. SUBMISSION OF EXPRESSION OF INTEREST AND PROCUREMENT SPECIFIC INFORMATION This exercise will be conducted on the NHS Midlands and Lancashire CSU portal at https://mlcsu.bravosolution.co.uk. Candidates wishing to be considered must register their expression of interest & provide procurement-specific information (by completing a PQQ) as follows: i)Candidates should register on the portal at https://mlcsu.bravosolution.co.uk (registration and use of website is free). If your organisation has registered previously, you do not need to re-register. ii)Once registered, express interest by a) logging-in to the eTendering portal, b)selecting response to advert and PQQ, c) select Open Access PQQ, d) search for and access listing related to this contract and view details (PQQ_396), e) click on Express Interest link iii)After expressing interest, access the My PQQs page where you can download documentation (if required) & construct your reply as instructed. You must submit your reply on the website by the deadline stated. For technical support in submitting your expression of interest contact the BravoSolution Help-desk on 0800 368 4850 or help@bravosolution.co.uk 
This procurement relates to NHS healthcare services. Therefore, section 120 of the Public Contract Regulations 2015 applies. Under section 120, the service to which this procurement relates falls within Part B of Schedule 3 of The Public Contracts Regulations 2006 (as amended). Neither placement of an advertisement for this procurement, nor the use of an open procurement process, nor any other indication shall be taken to mean that the commissioner intends to hold itself bound by any of the regulations save those applicable to Part B services.

Title: NHS England and NHS Improvement: NHS Foundation Trust Audit Quality Monitoring
Description:
The NHS Act 2006  requires external auditors of NHS foundation trusts to comply with a monitoring regime established by the Secretary of State for Health and Social Care. The Secretary of State has issued a direction delegating this to NHSE/I, in exercise of Monitor's legal functions. This procurement is for a supplier to undertake these reviews for NHS foundation trust audits relating to the financial years 2019/20 and 2020/21 in England, based on a sample of audits.

See the following links for further details and access to the Request for Proposal: https://www.mytenders.co.uk/

https://www.mytenders.co.uk/authority/authority_noticestatus.aspx?ID=221140

Organisation Name: NHS ARDEN AND GREATER EAST MIDLANDS
Title: Provision of Non-Emergency Patient Transport Services for NHS Dudley, NHS Wolverhampton and NHS Sandwell & West Birmingham CCGs
Description:
***THIS ADVERT IS FOR A MARKET ENGAGEMENT EVENT ONLY***

NHS Arden and GEM CSU, on behalf of NHS Dudley, NHS Wolverhampton and NHS Sandwell & West Birmingham CCGs are holding a Market Engagement Event for providers of Non-Emergency Patient Transport Services. The CCGs are seeking to gain enhanced understanding of the market's perception of:

- Potential financial modelling;
- potential lotting strategies; and
- the draft service specification.

The event will also provide a forum for providers to pose any questions they may have of the commissioning CCGs in advance of the launch of a formal tender process. 

Indicative activity data from the CCGs, along with the draft service specification are attached to this advert. Information regarding potential lotting strategies, for discussion with interested parties are included in the additional text below.

By way of background, the Department of Health defines Non-emergency Patient Transport Service (NEPTS) activity as being typified by the non-urgent, planned transportation of patients, with a medical need for transport, to and from a premises providing NHS healthcare and between NHS healthcare Provider/s. This can and should encompass a wide range of vehicle types and levels of care consistent with the patients' medical needs. The overarching principle of NEPTS is that only patients who are eligible for transport will receive safe, timely and comfortable transport, without detriment to their medical condition. The objectives of the service are to ensure that delivery is high quality, responsive, high performing, provides value for money, is environmentally efficient and innovative in the use of information technology. Details of patient eligibility can be found in the draft service specification attached to this advert.

Commissioners are supportive of partnership models that can include car/taxi companies, community transport operators, and volunteer services including those working within hospital trusts, in order to deliver the service as specified.

The event will be held between 9am and 3pm on Wednesday 22nd May. An initial presentation will be given by commissioners after which there will be an opportunity for potential bidders to have one to one sessions with the commissioners which will be allocated on a first come first served basis.

To secure a place at the event, request a one to one session (if desired), and access details of the venue, please visit Eventbrite using the following link https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/market-engagement-non-emergency-patient-transport-for-3-black-country-ccgs-tickets-61296443312. Providers are also asked to answer a short survey based on the information attached to this advert when reserving their place. Information provided will be treated as confidential and will be used to inform the Commissioners' overall procurement strategy.
Attachments: NEPTS Service Spec V0.10 12.02.2016 FINAL.docx Eligibility Criteria - FINAL.pdf NEPTS - financial envelopes and activity by CCG v2.docx
Additional Text:
***POTENTIAL LOTTING STRUCTURE ONLY***

Lot 1 - Patient Transport via Ambulances

The NEPTS service will provide safe, timely and comfortable transport to eligible patients. 
The Provider shall supply sufficient vehicles to provide the service under the Contract. In so doing, it is expected that vehicles will transport those patients that are best suited for this mode of transport such as patients with:

•                     a high level of dependency; 
•                     bariatric; 
•                     4 person lift; 
•                     stretcher patients; 
•                     neonatal patients and 
•                     (complex) renal patients 
•                     Wheelchair (two person)

Lot 2 - Patient Transport by car/taxi (including renal patients)

The NEPTS service will provide safe, timely and comfortable transport to eligible patients.
The Provider shall supply sufficient vehicles to provide the service under the Contract. In so doing, it is expected that vehicles will transport those patients that are best suited for this mode of transport such as patients with:

•                     (mobile/non-complex) renal patients 
•                     Wheelchair (one person)
•                     Walking with no/minimal assistance
•                     Paediatrics (car seat usage) with escort


Lot 3 - Call Handling

The NEPTS Provider will handle all Dudley CCG Bookings, bookings for Wolverhampton CCG are out of scope of this service. 
All NEPTS bookings for services within the Dudley specification will be assessed against the eligibility by the Provider prior to acceptance.  
The Providers booking system must facilitate:
•             Ease and efficiency of booking
•             Confirmation of booking to Patient Transport Office using a Booking Reference Number, including confirmation that suitable arrangements are in place.
•             Functionality for regular, repeat bookings
•             Enable the cancellation of bookings up-to 2 hours prior to appointment time
•             Highlight and investigate repeat bookings
•             Highlight and investigate aborted journeys/cancellations
•             Highlight and investigate any patient who refuses to travel, and has not cancelled their booked transport, on two+ occasions
•             Record and report patient information and delivery against quality measures. 
•             Highlight relevant patient specific details such as communicable diseases, DNR in place, for example. 
The Provider will supply a computerised booking system with hardware

Title: The Provision of a Community Neurology Service on behalf of NHS North Manchester, NHS Central Manchester and NHS South Manchester Clinical Commissioning Groups - Request For Information
Description:
NHS Shared Business Services (NHS SBS) on behalf of NHS North Manchester, NHS Central Manchester and NHS South Manchester Clinical Commissioning Groups (the CCGs) and led by NHS Central Manchester CCG are looking to gauge market interest and conditions for The Provision of a Community Neurology Service. 

The CCG Commissioners are seeking responses from viable providers or individuals (Specialist Nurses or GP’s with a Special Interest in Neurology) who would be interested in providing a community Neurology Service either as the lead provider or as part of a collaborative partnership with other providers. Assurance of competence, quality, innovation and safety standards is required.  Elective neurology out-patient activity is currently commissioned by Specialised Commissioning and will become the responsibility of CCGs sometime in 2015. 

Approximately 40% of all referral to Secondary care Neurology outpatient departments are for people with suspected or diagnosed Epilepsy or Headaches. We recognise that most of these patients could be managed in a Community service and as there is a need to add additional capacity into the system the 3 Manchester CCG’s are looking to commission a Community Neurology service that is outcomes focused.

Potential providers who wish to express an interest in the Community Neurology Service are asked to provide the following information and details relevant to the service: 

1. Please provide details of any experience you have in delivering/managing similar services. 
2. From when do you have capacity to deliver the contract from? Please provide brief details on current and future capacity. 
3. How extensive is your knowledge of the current Manchester health economy in relation to these services. 
4. Please identify your current organisation structure (public limited company, limited company, partnership, sole trader, charity, other public sector organisation, etc). 
5. Please state which of the Manchester CCG’s listed above you could provide services for stating the clinical areas for each. 

At this point individual CCG’s are trying to gauge market interest before deciding how to proceed, therefore potential providers need to assume at this stage that if CCG’s go out to procure services that could be on a Manchester footprint or individual CCG footprint.
Additional Text:
Potential providers wishing to express an interest in participating in the Request For Information and any future Tender Process should do so by, emailing their interest to andrew_payne@nhs.net no later than 12 noon on Friday 10th July 2015. 

Please note that an expression of interest in delivering The Neurology Community Service is not a tender response. An expression of interest is no indication of a commitment to participate in the tender process nor does it infer any special status on those providers who do submit an interest. Potential providers who do not express an interest at this stage will still be able to apply in the future. All responses will be treated in confidence. This Expression of Interest does not commit NHS Central Manchester CCG or the other named CCGs to undertake the procurement of The Neurology Community Service and NHS Central Manchester CCG and the other named CCGs have the right, at this stage, to withdraw the notice.

Title: AWARD NOTICE - NHS Commissioning Board (NHS England & NHS Improvement South East and South West): Provision of School Aged Immunisations for Hampshire, Southampton, Portsmouth, Isle of Wight & Dorset
Description:
NHS England & NHS Improvement South East and South West sought to commission immunisation programmes aimed at school aged children across the following three geographical lots:
•	Dorset (including Bournemouth, Christchurch & Poole)
•	Hampshire
•	Solent (Portsmouth, Southampton & the Isle of Wight)

The purpose of national immunisation programmes is to protect the population from vaccine preventable illnesses and reduce the associated morbidity and mortality and the burden this places on health services. This includes reducing the risk of individuals infecting others (herd immunity), particularly those who cannot be vaccinated either because they are too young or for medical reasons. Collectively the programmes protect young people against a range of infectious diseases which can lead to death or severe, permanent disability requiring long term care such as limb amputations, brain injury, paralysis and cancer.   

The aim of the project is to secure provision, for each of the Lots, which can achieve and sustain high levels of coverage  of the immunisation programmes in scope overall as well as at the level of individual schools/communities and population groups e.g. those who typically have difficulty accessing services. Coverage will be measured in the year the vaccination is first offered and in subsequent school years. The ambition is to be in the top quartile for the country for each vaccination programme and in each lot.  

There are currently four programmes for children of school age relevant to this procurement:
•	the Seasonal Influenza immunisation programme
•	the Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) immunisation programme
•	the Tetanus, Diphtheria and inactivated Polio (Td/IPV) adolescent booster programme 
•	the Meningitis ACWY immunisation programme

In addition, the provider will offer a catch-up service for under-immunised children in line with the national measles eradication strategy. 

The programmes are continually evolving. By 2020, the HPV programme will have been extended to boys as well as girls and the flu programme will have been extended to school year 6. Further school years may be announced for the flu programme in due course. The scope may also be extended in future to include additional programmes, as advised/ recommended by the Joint Committee of Vaccinations and Immunisations and/or at the request of the commissioner. Any provider will have to demonstrate an ability to respond positively to programme changes and implement them in a timely fashion to a high standard.  

The contract term will be 5 years, with the option to extend by a further 2 years, and will commence on 1st August 2020. 

Interested parties were allowed to bid for one or more lots. Evaluations were based on Most Economically Advantageous Tender (MEAT). 

This procurement was carried out by NHS South, Central and West Commissioning Support Unit (SCW) on behalf of the Commissioners.
Additional Text: The services are healthcare services falling within Schedule 3 to the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 ("the Regulations")  which are not subject to the full regime of the Regulations, but is instead governed by the "Light Touch Regime" contained within Chapter 3, Section 7 of the Regulations (Regulations 74 to 77).

Title: NHS Privacy Enhancing Technology (NHS-PET)
Description: NHS England are committed to keeping patient information safe and being transparent about how it is used. NHS Privacy Enhancing Technology (NHS-PET) will provide robust protection and deliver a standard approach to support safe data use including data privacy treatments and ensuring appropriate data access. NHS-PET will initially be deployed for the Federated Data Platform Programme (FDP). NHS-PET will be a standalone service that potentially includes cloud-based Software as a Service (SaaS) solutions to provide data privacy and protection to FDP, and the wider NHS. NHS-PET will be used across NHSE in conjunction with various data platforms. The successful supplier will be required to scale the use of the solution across the enterprise. Connectivity between NHS enterprise data platforms is extremely important as it will enable rapid scaling and sharing of tools and applications that have been developed at a local level, in a secure way, supporting levelling up and reducing variation across England. Bidders should therefore ensure their solution is designed around open standards to support integration and scaling requirements. NHS-PET will be a distinct service that is a required part of the overall NHS data protection ecosystem and FDP capability for sharing data safely and securely. The 3-year NHS-PET contract will have an additional option to extend by 24 +12 + 12 months with a total estimated value of up to £35,000,000 over the contract period. The actual contract value will depend on the extent of the use of the service.

Title: NHS Leicester City, NHS East Leicestershire and Rutland (LLR), NHS West Leicestershire Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCG's)
Description:
This notice is a call for competition under an open type Procedure requesting bids for NHS Midlands & Lancashire CSU (MLCSU) on behalf of the Commissioners, NHS Leicester City, NHS East Leicestershire and Rutland and NHS West Leicestershire Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCG's).  The service must be delivered across the geographical reach of all 3 CCGs.  The CCG's wish to publish their intent with regards to the following service: The LLR Children & Young People Emotional Mental Health & Wellbeing Triage and Navigation service will offer access to a wide range of information and advice, triage and signposting to the right services to meet the identified needs of the children and young people.  The service will be delivered by a range of clinicians, both experienced generalists and specialists either via the telephone or online referrals.  Self-referrals will be available via a dedicated telephone line.  

It is envisaged that this will be a personalised advice, triage and onward referral service that is responsive to children's up to the age of 18 years old health needs which gives advice to health professionals in the community to provide clinical advice and support to decision making and admissions avoidance effort from a locally within the geographical boundaries of LLR.  The provider must have in place a secure N3 connection.    The contract value is £192,000.00  per annum.   The whole life costing of this contract is £960,000.00

The Commissioners wish to offer a contract for a period of 3 years plus an option to extend for a further 2 years. The anticipated date the Commissioners would like the service to start being delivered on the 1st October 2019.  The Commissioners anticipate that this procurement will be awarded to one service provider or a lead provider on behalf of a consortium.
 
Interested providers are guided to complete and submit their bids.  All completed and submitted bids must be via the NHS Midlands and Lancashire (MLCSU) eProcurement portal, Bravo by the stated deadline. 
Please note, this ITT will close on 26th June at 13:00 hours
The contract term will be for 3 years plus 2 years extension period.
The CCGs reserve the right to award in part or in whole.  The CCGs reserve the right not to proceed with award.
 "Light Touch Regime" services: This service is classified as clinical which comes under the Light Touch Regime services for the purpose of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 as specified in Schedule 3 of the Regulations ("Regulations"). The contracting authorities are not voluntarily following any other part of the Regulations. As the CCGs are relevant bodies for the purpose of the National Health Service (Procurement, Patient Choice and Competition) (No 2) Regulations 2013 these Regulations also apply to this procurement. 
To register interest and download the ITT documentation you will need to follow these steps:
To register on the portal, go to: 
https://mlcsu.bravosolution.co.uk
Follow instructions from there.
Contact Name: NHS Leicester Citiy CCG, NHS West Leicestershire CCG and NHS East Leicestershire & Rutland CCG
Contact Address 1: MLCSU 120 Grove Road Stoke on Trent
Additional Text:
Light Touch Regime services
This procurement is for clinical services which are Light Touch Regime services for the purpose of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 as specified in Schedule 3 of the Regulations ("Regulations"). Accordingly, the contracting authorities are only bound by those parts of the Regulations detailed in Chapter 3 Particular Procurement Regimes Section 7. The contracting authorities are not voluntarily following any other part of the Regulations.  The procedure which the contracting authorities are following is set out in the MOI and ITT. As the CCG is a relevant body for the purpose of the National Health Service (Procurement, Patient Choice and Competition) (No 2) Regulations 2013 these Regulations also apply to this procurement.

To register on the Bravo portal
If your organisation has registered previously, you do not need to re-register.
Register on the portal webpage at https://mlcsu.bravosolution.co.uk (registration and use of the website is free of charge).
Once registered, candidates must Express their Interest by:
logging into the ML CSU eTendering Bravo portal
selecting response to ITT,
select Open Access ITT,
search for and access listing related to this contract and view details,
click on Express Interest link.
Once you have expressed your interest, please access the My ITTs page, where you can view all the documentation (and download if required) and construct your reply in the bravo online questionnaire, as instructed. The deadline will be detailed in the tender documentation.  For technical support in submitting your Expression of Interest or registering on the 'Bravo Solution' Electronic Sourcing system please contact the Bravo Solution helpdesk via Tel: 0800 069 8630 or email: help@bravosolution.co.uk.  All communications from Bidders (including their Bidder Members) during the period of the Procurement must be directed to MLCSU via the 'messaging' area within the ML CSU online procurement portal: https://mlcsu.bravosolution.co.uk. Strictly no other forms of communication to MLCSU or the Commissioner will be accepted (including telephone calls, postal queries/submissions, faxes or email communications) during this period.
