Organisation Name: N E L Commissioning Support Unit
Title: Provision of Community Dermatology Services for NHS Havering Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG), NHS Barking & Dagenham CCG and NHS Redbridge CCG
Description:
NHS Havering Clinical Commissioning Group (acting as coordinating commissioner), NHS Redbridge and NHS Barking &
Dagenham CCG have a requirement to procure community dermatology services. The Community Dermatology
Service carries out procedures and treatments for specified skin conditions along an agreed care pathway
with a set pathway price. Please note that this service excludes all persons under 5. All other dermatology conditions and procedures that fall outside of the community
specification including 2 week wait appointments are seen and treated via the dermatology outpatient clinic at
BHRUT or another acute provider of choice.
Please be advised that this notice is for relevant providers information and does not represent a commitment
from Havering, Redbridge or Barking & Dagenham CCG to award a contract. Please be advised further that this service will exclude provision to those under five years of age

Organisation Name: WEST AND SOUTH YORKSHIRE AND BASSETLAW COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: NHS Bradford City CCG, NHS Bradford Districts CCG and NHS AWC CCG AQP Assisted Conception Service.
Description:
Bradford City, Bradford Districts and Airedale, Wharfedale and Craven CCGs have a combined registered population of 619,500 patients.  Together the CCGs’ locality can be referred to as Bradford District and Craven.  

Bradford district is unusual in the high levels of poverty and diversity; hence, it is not representative of the rest of the country, although there are similarities with other UK cities and with cities with high levels of ethnic minority and immigrant communities across the world.  Almost half of babies born in the city have parents of Pakistani origin.  
Around 20% of the population is of South Asian origin (90% of whom are from Pakistan), and this constitutes a three-generation community that maintains close links with Pakistan.  Almost half of the South Asian population in Bradford is of Mirpuri origin.  Mirpur is a predominantly rural district in the province of Azad Kashmir in Pakistan.  Some members of the community do not read or speak English.  However, the majority are able to understand Urdu or Mirpuri, although not all are literate in Urdu.  Of the patients attending the specialist fertility clinic, approximately 50% are of South Asian origin, 45% of white British origin and 5% of Eastern European origin.

Bradford district and Craven is served, in the main, by two local hospitals – Airedale NHS Foundation Trust and Bradford Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.  The Provider must establish and demonstrate robust relationships and pathways of care with local obstetrics and gynaecology departments for care of women during pregnancy.  This assisted conception service is considered tertiary in nature and the majority of referrals will come from the two local hospitals. 

All assisted conception treatment in the UK is statutory regulated by the Human Fertility and Embryo Authority (HFEA).  The Commissioner will only commission fertility techniques regulated by the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA).  All tertiary providers of fertility services must be licensed with the HFEA in order to be commissioned.  

The most recent DH costing tool estimates that there are 98 attendances at a fertility clinic for every 10,000 head of population.  In Bradford Districts and City, this currently averages around 15/week for general fertility and 5/week for the specialist reproductive medicine service.  Of these, some patients will be fee-paying.  IVF cycles average in the region of 250 per year.  

The successful providers(s) will be offered an AQP standard NHS contract. It should be noted that `under the Any Qualified Provider model, there will be no guarantees of volume or payment in the contracts awarded. Service specifications and the electronic application form can be found online at www.nhssourcing.co.uk and applications will be received until 21/12/15. The accreditation will last for five years.
Additional Text:
How to apply 

For further information about this service, to access the service specifications for this service and to apply to provide this Any Qualified Provider service please visit www.nhsssourcing.co.uk

Suppliers Instructions How to Express Interest in this Tender~: 

1. Register your company on the eSourcing portal (this is only required once) - Browse to the eSourcing Portal: https://www.nhssourcing.co.uk and click the link to register - Accept the terms and conditions and click 'continue' - Enter your correct business and user details - Note the username you chose and click 'Save' when complete - You will shortly receive an email with your unique password (please keep this secure)

2. Express an Interest in the tender - Login to the portal with the username/password - Click the 'PQQs / ITTs Open To All Suppliers' link. (These are Pre-Qualification Questionnaires or Invitations to Tender open to any registered supplier) - Click on the relevant PQQ/ ITT to access the content. - Click the 'Express Interest' button at the top of the page. - This will move the PQQ /ITT into your 'My PQQs/ My ITTs' page. (This is a secure area reserved for your projects only) -You can now access any attachments by clicking 'Buyer Attachments' in the 'PQQ/ ITT Details' box 

3. Responding to the tender - Click 'My Response' under 'PQQ/ ITT Details', you can choose to 'Create Response' or to 'Decline to Respond' (please give a reason if declining) - You can now use the ‘Messages’ function to communicate with the buyer and seek any clarification - Note the deadline for completion, then follow the onscreen instructions to complete the PQQ/ ITT - There may be a mixture of online & offline actions for you to perform (there is detailed online help available) You must then submit your reply using the 'Submit Response' button at the top of the page. If you require any further assistance please consult the online help, or contact the eTendering help desk.

Title: Request for Information - Tier 3 Specialist Weight Management Service (on behalf of NHS Cumbria CCG, NHS Hartlepool and Stockton-On-Tees CCG and NHS South Tees CCG)
Description:
North of England Commissioning Support Unit (NECS), on behalf of NHS Cumbria Clinical Commissioning Group, NHS Hartlepool and Stockton-On-Tees Clinical Commissioning Group and NHS South Tees Clinical Commissioning Group ("the CCGs"), is looking to gauge market interest and conditions for the provision of a Tier 3 Specialist Weight Management Service.

As such, the CCGs wish to engage with the wider market via a Request for Information (RFI) process, in order to potentially inform future service model development and/or commissioning intentions.

The increasing levels of obesity in the UK are well documented; it has been estimated that the combined medical costs of an extra 11m obese adults nationally could be £2bn a year, equating to £100m annually for the health economies of the North East and Cumbria.

Tier 3 weight management services are typically designed for obese individuals who have not responded to previous interventions, and are comprised of a multi-disciplinary, clinically-led team of specialists.  Tier 3 weight management services are a pre-requisite in the NICE eligibility criteria for Tier 4 bariatric surgery and are integral to a tiered approach to management of obesity. The overarching aims of any such service would be to reduce obesity rates, prevent related illnesses, and lower the number of patients needing referral into Tier 4 bariatric surgery.

NECS is managing this RFI process for and on behalf of the above-named CCGs. If your organisation would like to register an interest in responding to this market engagement exercise and obtain a copy of the Request for Information documentation please go to the NECS E-Tendering Portal: https://in-Tendhost.co.uk/necs . If your organisation has not previously registered on the NECS E-Tendering Portal, please ensure that you do register in order to access the RFI documentation. It is free to register on the portal, which can be accessed at any time of day.

Once registered, to view details of the RFI exercise, please navigate to “Request for Information - Tier 3 Specialist Weight Management Service” and select “View Details”. Please then select the button marked “Express Interest” – you will then be able to access the RFI documentation.

Any organisations who wish to provide a response to this RFI are requested to complete and return their responses by 12:00 noon on 18th December 2015, by uploading them onto the NECS E-Tendering Portal using the designated placeholder.

Please be aware that all communications and submissions will be conducted via the NECS E-Tendering Portal. A dedicated helpdesk is available should potential providers have any queries about, or problems with, the portal; 0844 2728810 (Monday to Friday 8am to 5pm) / e-mail: support@in-tend.co.uk.
Additional Text: PLEASE NOTE – this facility allows providers to express an interest in this proposed service. It is NOT a Pre-Qualification Questionnaire exercise and is NOT part of any pre-qualification or selection process. It is intended as an awareness, communication and information gathering exercise which will assist the above-named CCGs to inform potential future service models and / or commissioning intentions. An Expression of Interest is no indication of a commitment to participate in the RFI process nor does it infer any preferential or special status on those providers who do submit an interest.

Organisation Name: NHS Black Country Integrated Care Board
Title: NHS 111 Services (Midlands) - Invitation to Tender (ITT)
Description:
NHS Black Country Integrated Care Board and NHS Derby and Derbyshire Integrated Care Board are undertaking a procurement process and are inviting suitably qualified and experienced providers to bid for NHS 111 services to cover the West and East Midlands regions (including Staffordshire and Stoke) on behalf of themselves and the following Integrated Care Boards:

NHS Birmingham and Solihull ICB
NHS Coventry and Warwickshire ICB
NHS Herefordshire and Worcestershire ICB
NHS Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland ICB
NHS Lincolnshire ICB
NHS Northamptonshire ICB
NHS Nottingham and Nottinghamshire ICB
NHS Shropshire and Telford and Wrekin ICB
NHS Staffordshire and Stoke-on-Trent ICB

NHS111 aims to ensure patients with an urgent clinical need are assessed and referred to an appropriate service, in a timely manner, by providing health advice and onward referral over the telephone and online. The NHS111 service will deliver a safe and patient focused service that promotes quality and reduces health inequalities.

Further objectives of the service will be to:
• Achieve nationally and regionally mandated KPIs and quality measures.
• Expedite patient access to appropriate end point services.
• Deliver good patient experience by providing consistent, safe and efficient clinical assessment at first point of contact.
• Provide onward referral to primary care and all non-emergency department (non-ED) pathways, including ICB commissioned services that can undertake remote triage and onward referral (such as local clinical assessment services (CAS).
• Nurture a culture of self-help, education and self-management.
• Ensure the Directory of Services (DoS) is maintained in partnership with local systems and used to facilitate timely and appropriate levels of care.
• Ensure early identification of calls that would benefit from access to a clinical adviser.
• Develop and maintain clear pathways of care which ensure safe and optimal transfer of patients' care where additional or specialist care is required.
• Reduce the risk of harm to patients by ensuring patients are referred to the most appropriate service, at the earliest opportunity along the pathway.
• Share real time data with health and social care partners to improve the patient journey, safety of staff, and the efficiency of NHS and Local Authority commissioned services.

The contract term will be 5 years with the option to extend for up to a further 2 years.

This Procurement has been advertised in accordance with the requirements of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended) (the "Regulations") to the extent that the Regulations relate to services within the scope of Schedule 3 thereto (Social and Other Specific Services). The Commissioner and AGCSU are, therefore, bound only by those parts of the Regulations applying to Schedule 3 services.
Contact Name: NHS Black Country Integrated Care Board
Additional Text:
To express interest and participate in the tender, please register and apply via Atamis e-sourcing portal https://health-family.force.com/s/Welcome.

Should Tenderers have any queries, or having problems using the portal, they should contact Helpdesk at:

Title: NHS Supply Chain - Digital Commerce Platform
Description:
Supply Chain Coordination Limited (SCCL) is a government organisation that acts as the management function for the NHS Supply Chain. SCCL is responsible for driving commercial objectives, managing Category Management Service Providers, and enabling services whilst overseeing continuous improvement.

By 2022/2023 we aim to save the NHS £2.4bn by leveraging the scale of the NHS to drive savings and provide a standardised range of quality assured clinical products that meet the diverse needs of the NHS across all areas.

NHS Supply Chain provides a leading procurement and supply chain services to hospitals and healthcare providers, to help leverage national expenditure whilst providing a resilient, sustainable national supply chain. The organisation is at exciting cross-roads, having recently defined a new 10-year vision to enable it to better meet the needs of the NHS and bring its value proposition to a broader range of healthcare
providers. It currently provides (B2B) services to almost all Trusts in England, as well as operating a small but critical and growing home delivery (B2B2C) business. This increased diversity of customers lays the foundations for future requirements for the business, as healthcare becomes more integrated regionally, through integrated care systems (ICS).

NHS Supply Chain captures customer demand through a range of solutions including a core catalogue, EDI order feeds, through a forecast driven automated replenishment model, and through orders triggered by inventory usage (e.g., in theatres for high value products). Some of these solutions are over 30 years old, unstable, aren't flexible and are unable to adapt to our strategy or external changes.

The organisation is at a relatively early stage of a 3 - 5 year transformation to re-platform its core Front Office and Digital Commerce solutions, and dramatically improve the user experience and interface to offer an experience which is comparable to those offered by for example leading retailers. NHS Supply Chain's
mission is to provide the NHS with a modern and intuitive ordering experience to increase Customer satisfaction, make it easier for the NHS to put Patients first and be flexible to adapt to the changing needs of the NHS. Modernisation is also an imperative part of our longer-term vision to be easy to work with and enable further adoption of NHS Supply Chain's services.

In order to deliver upon the Mission, NHS Supply Chain are seeking an eCommerce Solution and Delivery partner to provide a single tailored and intuitive ordering platform, managing personalised content delivery across web and mobile channels whilst supporting integration with Electronic Data Interchange (EDI) and 3rd
party platforms.

The value of the contract is anticipated to be circa £10,000,000 over 5 years.

This notice is for information only. The purpose of this notice is to inform the market of the forthcoming procurement.
Contact Name: Supply Chain Coordination Limited (SCCL) - the management function of NHS Supply Chain
Additional Text:
This notice is for information only. The purpose of this notice is to inform the market of the forthcoming procurement. Further information will be available once the formal procurement process commences.

Suppliers should Express Interest to indicate if they would wish to participate in a future procurement for this requirement. Interested parties are advised to express their interest in accordance with the information provided within the Prior Information Notice URL: https://www.find-tender.service.gov.uk/Notice/029875-2022 This does not create any obligations on the part of the Authority. No response is required beyond the Expression of Interest.

This notice is for information only and SCCL, as the Authority, reserves the right to not proceed to tender. 

Additionally, SCCL reserves the right to discontinue the tendering process and not to award the contract.

The commencement of the formal procurement process will be the subject of a separate notice (Contract Notice). Potential Providers should note that they will need to respond to the Contract Notice at the appropriate time. 

Please note that the date of the Find a Tender Service Contract Notice is subject to change.

UK Procurement opportunities are now published on the new UK Find a Tender Service (FTS) and Contracts Finder, therefore, please monitor those sites for the notification of the release of the documents for this procurement.

The information contained in this notice, including information relating to the nature and scope of SCCL's requirements, the service classification of this requirement or the list of CPV codes, is only indicative of current thinking and is neither exhaustive nor binding and SCCL reserves the right at its absolute discretion to amend it at the time of issue of any further notice or notices or at any other time.

Title: NHS Supply Chain Logistics Services Provider
Description:
The purpose of this Contracts Finder Notice is to commence Pre-Market Engagement with Potential Providers that have the capability and capacity to deliver NHS Supply Chain's future Logistics service requirements.

SCCL will use the Pre- Market Engagement sessions to outline the future strategic objectives for the NHS Supply Chain, share the key requirements of the Logistics Services Provider contract, and for SCCL to capture industry information and Potential Provider views that may assist in the development of the NHS Supply Chain's Logistics Operating Model.

SCCL aims to commence procurement in late summer 2022 for the provision of Logistics services. These services are critical for the delivery of NHS Supply Chain goods procured under the CTSP frameworks which are available to 1) any NHS Trust; 2) any other NHS entity or healthcare provider (including private organisations, primary care, community settings and social care); 3) any government department, agency, or other statutory body (including Devolved Authorities, Crown Dependencies and/or Pandemic Planning Programmes), and/or 4) any private sector entity active in the UK healthcare sector on behalf of a public-sector organisation listed in 1) to 4) above.

NHS Supply Chain manage the sourcing, delivery and supply of healthcare products, services and food for NHS trusts and healthcare organisations across England and Wales. In 2018, SCCL (the management function of the NHS Supply Chain) entered contracts with 11 Category Tower Service Providers (CTSPs) to provide goods and services to NHS trusts and healthcare organisations across England and Wales. Goods are delivered through two enabling services which underpin the CTSP model, these enabling services are Logistics and Fulfilment, and Supporting Technology.

The scope of the current contract involves the operational logistics management of the NHS Supply Chain estate, Home Delivery Services (HDS), additional in-bound logistics and inter-depot trunking services.

NHS Supply Chain currently manages more than 8 million orders per year, across 94,000 order points and 17,465 locations and delivers over 28 million lines of picked goods to the NHS annually. Its systems consolidate orders from over 930 suppliers, saving trusts time and money by removing duplication of overlapping contracts.

The above scope may be further extended to incorporate the provision of pandemic response logistics, this may include the storage and fulfilment of legacy Covid 19 related consumables and equipment.

SCCL would like to meet with Potential Providers who are advised to register on the jaggaer  system under Project 979 at https://nhssupplychain.app.jaggaer.com/  for further important information about the Market Engagement Sessions  pre-market engagement questionnaire.

This procurement is at the pre-tender stage.
The commencement of the formal procurement process will be the subject of a separate notice (Contract Notice).
Contact Address 1: Supply Chain Coordination Limited (SCCL) - the management function of NHS Supply Chain
Additional Text:
The reference for this Notice and RFI on Jaggaer are: 

Project_979

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: NHS England - SPECIALISED SURGICAL SERVICES:  GENDER DYSPHORIA MASCULINISING GENITAL PATHWAY
Description:
NHS England seek bids from providers who have the capability and capacity to deliver specialised surgical services (genitals) for patients with a diagnosis of gender dysphoria and who are on the masculinising pathway. 

Successful Bidders will hold a single contract with NHS England, and services under that contract will be available to individuals eligible for NHS-funded care who are ordinarily resident in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland - or otherwise who are the commissioning responsibility of the NHS in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland - and who meet the various eligibility criteria described in the Commissioner's Service Specification. 

The NHS pathway of care for adults with gender dysphoria will differ according to the individual's goals. The envisaged adult pathway may typically be summarised as: 

•	Referral to a specialist gender dysphoria service that is commissioned by the NHS
•	Assessment for gender dysphoria, and diagnosis
•	Individuals who meet the criteria for diagnosis of gender dysphoria are accepted on to the NHS care pathway and an individual treatment plan is agreed between the individual and their lead clinician in the NHS gender dysphoria service
•	Certain therapeutic interventions are delivered by the NHS gender dysphoria service; and / or referral for interventions with other providers; which may include recommendations to primary care for prescribing endocrine treatments
•	NHS gender dysphoria service makes a referral for surgical interventions of the chest and genitals if criteria are met via a National Referral Support Service
•	Ongoing review and monitoring during and after interventions
•	Conclusion of contact: discharge by NHS gender dysphoria service to primary care

The approach for improving the surgical market is focused on establishing a flexible contract that facilitates patient choice based on a consideration of reliable data including new quality indicators. No volumes are guaranteed on the award of a contract. Contracts will be awarded to all providers who meet the minimum standard criteria.

This tendering process will consist of two stages: (1) Stage 1 will entail Bidders expressing their interest and providing evidence of their capability and capacity in relation to the service requirements.  The aim of this shortlisting stage is predominantly to test the capability and capacity of potential providers for this specialist service; (2) Stage 2 will either be: (a) for providers who currently hold a NHS contract for prescribed specialised surgical services - an assurance process assessing their capability to deliver the surgical element of the  female to male pathway; or (b) for providers who do not currently hold a NHS contract for prescribed specialised surgical services - an assurance process assessing all aspects of surgical delivery and ongoing care for patients with a diagnosis of gender dysphoria.
Additional Text:
The Assurance Process will be a collaborative and flexible, evidence-based approach to securing the delivery of the services.  Evidence will be assessed against critical success factors and expected minimum standards".

Contracts will be for an initial term of 5 years with a possible extension of any period up to a further 2 years as defined and at the discretion of the Commissioner.

This procurement is being carried out by NHS South, Central and West Commissioning Support Unit (SCW) on behalf of the Commissioners.

Interested providers will be able to view this notice via the 'current tenders' list on the e-procurement system In-Tend, available on the following link: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/scwcsu/aspx/Home 

In order to submit a bid, you will need to be registered on the e-procurement system and 'express an interest', and then complete a response as specified within the procurement documents. 

On registration, please include at least two contacts to allow for access to the system in times of absence.

The services are healthcare services falling within Schedule 3 to the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 ("the Regulations") which are not subject to the full regime of the Regulations, but is instead governed by the "Light Touch Regime" contained within Chapter 3, Section 7 of the Regulations (Regulations 74 to 77).

The tendering process will be conducted in accordance with the requirements and flexibilities provided by Articles 74 to 76 of the Directive, and Regulations 74 to 76 of the Regulations. The Authority will run a transparent tender process, treating all Bidders equally. For the avoidance of doubt, the Authority will not be bound by the Regulations or the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union or any other regulations or legislation except for the specific parts or circumstances that apply to the procurement of these Services. 
  
Neither the inclusion of a Bidder selection stage, nor the use of any language or terms found in the Directive or Regulations, nor the description of the procedure voluntarily adopted by the Authority ("Open", "Restricted", "Competitive Procedure with Negotiation", "Competitive Dialogue" or any other description), nor any other indication, shall be taken to mean that the Authority intends to hold itself bound by the Directive or Regulations, save by the provisions applicable to services coming within the scope of Annex XIV of the Directive / Schedule 3 of the Regulations. 

The Contracting Authority may observe a voluntary award decision notices provisions and 10 day standstill period described in Regulation 86 of the Regulations. Unsuccessful Bidders will receive scores and reasons for the decision, including the characteristics and relative advantages of the winning bid and the reasons why the Bidder/application was unsuccessful. Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Market Engagement Questionnaire NHS Community Pharmacy IT Systems
Description:
NHS E/I are exploring the establishment of a Dynamic Purchasing System (DPS) for referral systems to support the Community Pharmacy Consultation Service (CPCS). CPCS referral systems solutions are currently centrally funded, however pharmacy contractors will be required to fund these from April 2021. To facilitate this and to ensure that appropriate system requirements are met, NHS E/I are seeking to establish a DPS in January 2021. Pharmacy contractors will begin to procure from the new DPS as
soon as the establishment phase is completed.

Attached to this notice is a market engagement questionnaire, which NHS E/I are inviting suppliers to complete and which will inform the development of the Technical Specification and also the establishment of the DPS.

NHS England and NHS Improvement (NHS E/I) wish to support a market place for the providers of software solutions which are able to deliver the Community Pharmacy Contractual Framework (CPCF) services such as NHS Community Pharmacy Consultation Service (CPCS) in England. NHS E/I propose the creation of a DPS which will ensure that supplier solutions meet requirements and to provide a practical and secure route to market for customers and suppliers.

The NHS Community Pharmacist Consultation Service (CPCS) was commissioned as an Advanced Service from 29th October 2019, with the expectation that additional strands to the service will continue to be tested, developed and introduced into the contract. At the time of the service commencement for the specified IT solutions, the referrals will be made by NHS 111 or the Integrated Urgent Care Clinical Assessment Services (IUC CAS) and General Practice. NHS E/I are seeking to establish a DPS to outline entry level requirements. Pharmacy contractors will then be able to introduce additional requirements through the development of specifications which will support further tendering opportunities under the DPS.

NHS E/I have been exploring the development of a specification, which would determine the entry requirements to the DPS. To continue this exploratory work and to consider further elements relating to the establishment of a DPS, NHS E/I are inviting feedback from existing and potential suppliers. Included within this notice is a market engagement questionnaire, with feedback invited by 12.00 noon on 16 November 2020.
Additional Text:
Interested providers will be able to view this notice via the 'current tenders' list on the e-procurement system InTend, available on the following link: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/scwcsu/aspx/Home
In order to submit a bid, you will need to be registered on the e-procurement system and 'express an interest', and then complete a response as specified within the procurement documents.
On registration, please include at least two contacts to allow for access to the system in times of absence.
The services are deemed to be subject to the full regime of current EU procurement legislation and as such
this tender will be conducted in accordance with, and governed by, the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as
amended).

Organisation Name: East Of England NHS Collaborative Hub
Title: Transforming Organisations, Partnerships & Systems - Multi-Speciality Support & Advisory Consultancy Services
Description:
Services offered under this Framework will support Beneficiaries with elements such as but not limited to: advice, support, data analytics, service mapping, system reviews, redesign,patient/user service development, service delivery provider audits and legal advice,
integrated working, and other collaborative working practices which may be required with either singularly or collaboratively with other publicly funded entities, either as a result of publicly funded entities being directed/mandated centrally to work together or as is determined and required by the Beneficiaries themselves.

The Framework is intended to provide a support and knowledge base for the emerging care and integrated care models encompassing vanguards, sustainable
transformation plans (STPs), multi-specialty community providers (MCP) joint service developments, primary and acute care systems (PACS), accountable care networks (ACN) or where organisations come together to explore new working opportunities.  The framework is for the benefit of existing and emerging organisations during the life of the Contract, which includes but is not limited to providers, commissioners and support organisations.

Notice Identifier: Provision of Integrated Urgent Care Incorporating NHS111 Access and OOH Services (Project_302)
Title: Provision of Integrated Urgent Care Incorporating NHS111 Access and OOH Services (Project_302)
Description:
The following notice is a Prior Information Notice (PIN) only and is being placed to alert providers of an upcoming market engagement event and future procurement exercise. Any values and timescales stated within this PIN notice are for initial guideline purposes only, are subject to a high likelihood of change, and should not be relied upon or taken as a guarantee. 

NHS Sandwell and West Birmingham Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) on behalf of 16 CCGs of the West Midlands wish to commission an integrated urgent care model comprising NHS 111 services and integrated GP Out of Hours provision. 

This will be a pivotal service for the local urgent care health and social care economies in the West Midlands and will need to be able to work at a regional and local level in helping patients access the right care at the right time. 

The 16 CCGs covered by the planned future procurement exercise are: 

NHS Sandwell & West Birmingham CCG 
NHS Birmingham CrossCity CCG 
NHS Birmingham South and Central CCG, 
NHS Coventry and Rugby CCG, 
NHS Dudley CCG, 
NHS Herefordshire CCG, 
NHS Redditch and Bromsgrove CCG, 
NHS Shropshire CCG, 
NHS Solihull CCG, 
NHS South Warwickshire CCG, 
NHS South Worcestershire CCG, 
NHS Telford and Wrekin CCG, 
NHS Walsall CCG, 
NHS Warwickshire North CCG, 
NHS Wolverhampton CCG, 
NHS Wyre Forest CCG
Contact Address 1: Sandwell & West Birmingham CCG, Kingston House
Additional Text:
As part of the early planning for this procurement, the Commissioners are keen to engage actively with the market at an early stage in our development of an integrated specification. There is a planned market day on Tuesday 1st December where we wish to share the overall direction as well as local visions and seek feedback from the provider market prior to commencing the formal procurement process. This will be an interactive session in which comment and input will be sought from all suppliers. 

Interested suppliers who wish to receive information about this event should email Harie Mandair on harie.mandair@nhs.net no later than Monday 23rd November and further details will be sent accordingly.

Title: NHS ENGLAND NATIONAL CAMPAIGNS Quantitative Research
Description:
The NHS England Campaigns Team deliver national social marketing campaigns to support the NHS. Our campaigns are delivered under two overarching campaign brands:

• The 'We are the NHS' campaign aims to inspire people to join the NHS and retain those already working in it. It promotes the NHS as a first-choice employer, focusing on priority recruitment of professions including: Nursing; Allied Health Professionals; Healthcare Support Workers; and 999 & 111 Call Handlers; also supporting the recruitment of NHS Reservists.

• The 'Help Us, Help You' campaign is designed to save lives by changing the way people access services to reduce pressures on the NHS and maintain capacity, by driving effective use of the NHS, encouraging people to get help in the right place and at the right time.


This contract has been established for a research agency to deliver quantitative research projects to support the 
development and evaluation of our work across all our campaign activity. Previously this work has been subcontracted through the Lead Creative Agency working on either the 'We are the NHS' or 'Help Us, Help You' campaigns.
These campaigns are delivered through a number of different phases aimed at different audiences and with separate aims and objectives.

All our campaign activity supports the successful delivery of the organisational priorities of NHS England and the wider NHS. These are set out in the NHS Long Term Plan and the annual NHS Priorities and Operational Planning Guidance.

The contract is for 3 years with an extension option of 12 months (Max 4 years)
Attachments: RM6126-Order-Form-for-contract-QUANT.FV_redacted_Redacted.pdf

Notice Identifier: Personal Health Budget Support Services Framework on behalf of NHS Merton CCG & NHS Wandsworth C
Title: Personal Health Budget Support Services Framework on behalf of NHS Merton CCG & NHS Wandsworth CCG
Description:
NHS Merton Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) is working with NHS Wandsworth CCG to establish a new framework of providers who are able to offer support to Service Users eligible to be awarded an NHS Personal Health Budget (PHB). It is intended that the framework will be established from March 2017 for 4 years, with contracts being awarded to support Service Users either directly by the CCG, or on the basis of patient choice.

The services to be offered through the framework are intended to include:

• Support planning
• Payment service (including Third Party/Managed Account)
• Employer advice and guidance

These PHB Support Services will support both adults and children who have been approved to receive a PHBs by the CCGs. 

Please see the attached Draft Service Specification for further details of the CCGs' requirements.

Whilst uptake of PHBs by Services Users is currently low, a significant increase is expected over the next 5 years as the CCG plans to award at least 222 PHBs over the next 5 years to meet the intentions published by NHS England. As a consequence, the expected spend profile for NHS Merton CCG to framework providers is:

2017/18	£13,500
2018/19	£29,250
2019/20	£29,250
2020/21	£29,250

Whilst NHS Wandsworth CCG has already engaged with the local market about this new requirement, NHS Merton CCG now wishes to invite expressions of interest from appropriately qualified and experienced providers which may not have responded already to the Wandsworth invitation (if you have already responded to the Wandsworth CCG engagement invitation in December 2016, you need not respond again to this invitation from Merton CCG. However, if you would like to attend the Market Engagement Event to understand Merton specific details, please follow the instructions under attachments).
Attachments: Draft Memorandum of Information - Personal Health Budget Support (v2).docx Merton CCG - PHB Support Service Market Engagement Questionnaire (v2).docx PHB Support Market engagment event.docx Draft LOT 1 Service Specification for PHB Support Planning Services - 260117.docx Draft LOT 2 Service Specification for Personal Health Budget Payment Services - 260117.docx Draft LOT 3 Service Specification for Personal Health Budget Employer Advice and Guidance v2 260117.docx
Additional Text:
***TO EXPRESS YOUR INTEREST IN APPLYING TO BE APPOINTED TO THIS NEW FRAMEWORK, please complete the attached Market Engagement Questionnaire and return it directly to James.holden@mertonccg.nhs.uk by Thursday 9th February 2017 at 12:00pm.

In return, details will be confirmed about a Market Engagement Event scheduled to take place in Wimbledon at 2pm-4pm on Friday 10th February 2017 (subject to interest).***

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH OF ENGLAND PROCUREMENT SERVICES
Title: Strategic Organisational Talent Management Diagnostic Tool - Health Education England, NHS Leadership Academy - NHS/SoEPS/18.418
Description:
NHS South of England Procurement Services, acting on behalf of Health Education England , NHS Leadership Academy (the Commissioner) are commencing a tender for the development of a strategic organisational talent management diagnostic tool for the English NHS, the piloting of this tool across a Regional Talent Board, and Scale/Spread/Sustain of this national approach.

The overall aim is to source an expert provider with the capacity and expertise to work with the national TM leads network to develop one approach to organisational TM diagnostics. The provider should then work with us to pilot and refine this approach (most likely across the Midlands and East region due to this being the most mature RTB, and comprising of approximately 71 NHS provider organisations and 59 CCGs. However there is potential to extend the pilot across wider geographies - up to another 20 organisations. Therefore approximately 150 in total) so that the data can be shared both with the organisations themselves, and pooled together to strategically support the RTB ambitions. The final solution should be simple in its approach and ensure that internal NHS resources are able to run the diagnostic approach in the future for all RTBs as they develop and reach maturity. Ideally the diagnostic should be suitable for NHS organisational Boards to progress themselves internally with no external support or supervision.

The funding available for this work is within this NHS financial year (April 2018 - March 2019) and we see the work being completed within this period. Ideally the tool will be developed and piloted in the first 3 quarters, and then enhanced and ready to be scaled and spread during the final quarter of this financial year. We acknowledge these timescales are demanding and see potential for the provider to continue support with us into 2019-20 to 'hold our hands' whilst we fully roll out the tool to all RTBs nationally.

The maximum envelope for this piece of work is £100,000 (excluding vat)

Please access the ITT documentation at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/soepscommissioning for further information
Attachments: Instructions_for_Registering_on_the_SoEPS_Commissioning_Support_In-tend_Portal.pdf
Additional Text: Bidders are invited to access the procurement documentation at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/soepscommissioning. The deadline for submission of completed ITT responses is Monday 9th July 2018 at 12:00pm (midday). The e-portal system will shutdown at 12:00pm and any un-submitted bids not registered to the system at this time will not be accepted. Therefore, please submit in good time prior to the deadline date and time. Should Bidders have any queries, or are having problems using the portal, they should contact the In-tend dedicated Supplier Helpdesk by calling 0845 557 8079 Monday to Friday (9am to 6pm) or email support@in-tend.co.uk. During the tender exercise the Contracting Authority requests that all communications are channelled through the e-portal system via the appointed procurement specialist on behalf of NHS South of England Procurement Services and not with the Contracting Authority itself. No Bidder, Bidder Member, or any of such Bidder's advisors, consultants or subcontractors may have ex parte communications with the Contracting Authority or any of their employees, advisors, contractors or consultants regarding the ITT, the Procurement, other than as expressly permitted in this ITT.

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Provision of Lloyd George Record Digitisation Services - Lot 1 - Scanning Services NHS Norfolk & Waveney CCG/NHS Norfolk & Waveney Integrated Care Board
Description:
The LG patient record comprises of the LG envelope and the contents, which is an important part of the patient's historical medical record. Each Lloyd George envelope has a broad range of detailed personal information stored inside and maintaining the security accuracy, availability and integrity of these legacy records is vital. The handling of these records needs particular care; the paper records can be up to 70 years old and some records are fragile and in a poor state, coupled with the fact the information they hold is vital and paramount for safe medical practice. The lack of continuity and resilience within the paper record poses a risk to the ongoing, continuity of person-centred care.. There is a legal requirement to keep the full patients record for a minimum of 10 years after the death of a patient.

There are four primary reasons for digitisation of Lloyd George records:
•	safer care for patients 
•	release of space within practices to provide additional consultation areas
•	access to the full patient record at the point of care
•	GP Contract commitments to digitise all Lloyd George patient records by March 2022.



This procurement followed a competitive tender using the NHS England and NHS Improvement Dynamic Purchasing System (DPS) (OJEU Reference 2020/S 152-373617) which was established by the NHS England and NHS Improvement National Commercial and Procurement Hub as a route to awarding contracts for Lloyd George Record Digitisation Services. It is compliant with the public procurement regulations and public authority standing financial instructions. To note, the tender is caught in the scope of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 - Regulation 34: Dynamic Purchasing Systems.

NHS Norfolk & Waveney CCG/NHS Norfolk & Waveney Integrated Care Board have awarded a contract to deliver their Lloyd George Record Digitisation Services

This procurement process was facilitated by the NHS England National and Commercial Procurement Hub (commissioned from the SCW CSU) on behalf of the Commissioners.
Contact Address 1: Lakeside 400, Old Chapple Way, Broadland Business Park, Thorpe St Andrew

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Early Engagement - Mandatory Dental Services (MDS) for NHS England and NHS Improvement, South East (Wessex)
Description:
This notice is placed as a Prior Information Notice in order to facilitate early engagement with potential providers, and relates only to a pre-procurement market sounding questionnaire. 

NHS England and NHS Improvement (NHSE & NHSI), South East (Wessex) are seeking to commission Mandatory Dental services in the Portsmouth, Alton and Tadley area, and will be holding a procurement process to award new contracts for service commencement from September 2020.

At this time, the Commissioner(s) would like to gather information from providers from all sectors using a market sounding questionnaire to inform the procurement process. 

A market engagement workshop event is being proposed for December 2019 but a subsequent notice for this will be issued.

The key aims for Mandatory Dental Service provision are to:

•	provide access to NHS dental services to ensure equity and consistency of provision
•	deliver appropriate, efficient and cost effective services within the service provision framework of the NHS (General Dental Services/Personal Dental Services) Regulations 2005 and any subsequent revisions
•	provide high quality dental services that meet the needs of people wishing to attend an NHS Dental practice in Portsmouth, Alton and Tadley which may include flexible appointment times and accessible services
•	provide access to patients identified as having an urgent dental need via NHS 111 
•	refer patients to other NHS services as appropriate in line with the relevant local protocols and guidance
•	establish a positive working relationship between the Commissioner and Provider to facilitate and maximise high quality service delivery
•	develop services in line with the evolving strategic approach to primary care dental provision
•	address the needs of vulnerable groups by incorporating elements of the Starting Well Programme to reduce oral health inequalities and improve oral health of children under 5 years old, residents of care homes and other vulnerable groups

The route to market for the various service elements and geographies is still being determined but, as a guide, the procurement is anticipated to commence from January 2020, inviting tenders to deliver services for specific lotted areas, with contract commencement anticipated in September 2020. 

The market sounding questionnaire will be used to obtain feedback from the market to help inform the re-commissioning and procurement of these services. 

The procurement will be undertaken by South Central and West Commissioning Support Unit (SCW) Procurement Team on behalf of the Commissioner.
Attachments: Market Sounding Questionnaire v2.0.docx
Additional Text:
The market sounding questionnaire is open to all providers who may want to deliver NHS mandatory dental services in the future. 

Please complete this questionnaire and return it via email to scwcsu.procurement@nhs.net by 12:00pm on 5th November 2019 with the subject 'Market Sounding Questionnaire - MDS PAT'.

This notice is an information gathering exercise rather than a call for competition in its own right, and therefore publication or response does not commit the Commissioner  or respondents to a future procurement, nor provide any process exemptions or preferential treatment to any parties expressing an interest. Commissioners are looking to establish what interest there might be in providing such a service from suitably qualified, capable and competent organisations.

Organisation Name: NHS Arden and Greater East Midlands Commissioning Support Unit
Title: NHS111/Clinical Assessment Service for Kent, Medway & Sussex CCGs
Description:
NHS 111 provides a vital service to help people with urgent care needs to get assessment, clinical advice and treatment quickly, taking around 15 million calls a year. The service will be further enhanced by increasing clinical consultation for patients calling 111, so that more patients get the care and advice they need over the phone, and only those who genuinely need to attend A&E or use the ambulance service are advised to do this. All other patients will have their issue resolved over the phone if at all possible, or if not will be directed to appropriate primary care or community services, with an emphasis on strongly supporting patients in self-care.

The following 15 Clinical Commissioning Groups are collaborating to procure an NHS111 and Clinical Assessment Service across Kent, Medway and Sussex; NHS Swale, NHS West Kent, NHS Dartford, Gravesham and Swanley, NHS Medway, NHS Ashford, NHS Canterbury and Coastal, NHS South Kent Coast, NHS Thanet, NHS Coastal West Sussex, NHS Brighton and Hove, NHS Horsham and Mid Sussex, NHS Crawley, NHS High Weald Lewes Havens, NHS Eastbourne, Hailsham and Seaford, NHS Hastings and Rother Clinical Commissioning Groups.

The contract will be for a period of 5 years with the option to extend for a further 2 years subject, but not limited to satisfactory performance.

Further information and the ITT documentation can be found at https://uk.eu-supply.com/login.asp?B=agcsu ID 34384

Title: Provision of a Digital Mental Health Solution for Children and Young People across North West London
Description:
Central and North West London NHS Foundation Trust (the "Contracting Authority") has awarded a contract to the successful Bidder to provide an enhanced, integrated, and sustainable digital mental health solution for children and young people, to deliver early interventions, easy to access online counselling and a wellbeing support service to meet the needs of children and young people living or attending an education setting in North West (NW) London requiring low level, targeted or short-term interventions.  
The Contract will be for a duration of 3 years, which is intended to run from 1st April 2021 until 31st March 2024, with the possibility of one extension of up to 2 years, subject to any restrictions placed nationally by NHS England or the Department of Health.  The anticipated, maximum total contract value (including any potential extensions) is £2,269,735; with an annual value estimated at £453,947.  
Central and North West London NHS Foundation Trust are acting as the Contracting Authority and will manage the contract on behalf of The North West London Health and Care Partnership (NHS Brent Clinical Commissioning Group, NHS Central London Clinical Commissioning Group, NHS Ealing Clinical Commissioning Group, NHS Hammersmith and Fulham Clinical Commissioning Group, NHS Harrow Clinical Commissioning Group, NHS Hillingdon Clinical Commissioning Group, NHS Hounslow Clinical Commissioning Group, NHS West London Clinical Commissioning Group, NHS Central and North West London NHS Foundation Trust, and NHS West London NHS Trust). 
NHS Shared Business Services (NHS SBS) is an agent of the Contracting Authority, acting on its behalf solely to procure the Service.  All decisions regarding the Contract are made by the Contracting Authority.   
This Contract Award Notice has also been placed in OJEU.

Title: Talking Therapies, NHS West Yorkshire Integrated Care Board (Calderdale Cares Partnership)
Description:
NHS West Yorkshire Integrated Care Board (Calderdale Cares Partnership) is looking to commission the provision of NHS Talking Therapies, for anxiety and depression for adults.

NHS Talking Therapies, for anxiety and depression, is a provision that provides access to self-care and early intervention for people with mild to moderate mental health needs.

The national expectations of NHS Talking Therapies are mandated, and specified in the NHS Talking Therapies, for anxiety and depression, Manual and further developed in a set of 'Positive Practice Guides'. 

The service will deliver the following within the defined financial envelope:
-	Deliver the requirements of the NHS Long Term Plan
-	Support access, outcomes and experience for groups particularly impacted by the pandemic including but not exclusively ethnic minority communities, older adults
-	Expand access to NHS talking therapies for anxiety and depression to deliver target access trajectories, targeting capacity to meet the population need of Calderdale
-	Delivers high quality NHS talking therapies for anxiety and depression intervention, including the improvement or maintenance of waiting times and outcome metrics
-	Focuses on population level health outcomes, tackling inequalities and ensuring services are culturally sensitive and appropriate
-	Provide a range of place-based delivery models, designed through collaboration with stakeholders, including patients, to meet the needs of specific population cohorts
-	Provide support to patients with long term conditions in response to the specific demands of local populations driving integration across physical and mental health pathways, as well as other groups identified within the NHS talking therapies for anxiety and depression manual and Positive Practice guides 
-	From April 2024 it has been nationally mandated that Employment Advisors are included as part of NHS Talking Therapies local offer
-	NHS talking therapies for anxiety and depression for Calderdale will operate within the context of the wider transformation of community mental health services.


A bidder information event will be held 25th May 2023 at 10am-12midday via Microsoft Teams. The event will explain the service requirements and outcomes of the Talking Therapies service and the tender process. 

If you are interested in joining this event, please follow the link below to register. If you require any assistance with registration, please contact wyicb-kirk.procurement@nhs.net.

https://www.calderdalecares.co.uk/tt-bidding-24/
Additional Text:
The ITT will be available on the e-tendering portal Jaggaer from the 6th June 2023.

If you would like to submit a bid for this service, please submit your response by registering on https://nhswyicb.ukp.app.jaggaer.com/ref ITT_62 (available from 06.06.23) once registered, potential providers will be able to complete and upload their submission.

NHS West Yorkshire Integrated Care Board (Calderdale Cares Partnership) has the right to withdraw this notice.

Title: NHS 111 and the Integrated Urgent Care Clinical Assessment Service
Description: North of England Commissioning Support (NECS) is managing this process for and on behalf of NHS Durham Dales, Easington and Sedgefield CCG, NHS Darlington Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG), NHS Hartlepool and Stockton-On-Tees CCG, NHS Newcastle Gateshead CCG, NHS Northumberland CCG, NHS North Durham CCG, NHS North Tyneside CCG, NHS South Tees CCG, NHS South Tyneside CCG, NHS Sunderland CCG (The CCG's) intend to commission the NHS 111 and the Integrated Urgent Care (IUC) Clinical Assessment Service (CAS) for the North East Region.The service provides vital help to people with urgent care needs to assessment, clinical advice and treatment quickly. The CAS will be responsible for offering patients access to clinicians, both experienced generalists and specialists. Title: Stakeholder Event on Wednesday 25th March 2015 for The Provision of GP Out of Hours Service on Behalf of NHS Bolton Clinical Commissioning Group
Description:
NHS Bolton Clinical Commissioning group (NHS Bolton CCG) would like to invite potential providers and stakeholders to a stakholder event in relation to GP Out of Hours (GP OOH) service.   As set out in Equity and Excellence: Liberating the NHS, the Government is committed to developing a coherent 24/7 urgent care service in every area of England that makes sense to patients when they have to make choices about their care and to drive the integration of services. NHS Bolton CCG is committed to the provision of a high- quality GP OOH Service that is integrated with the 24/7 urgent and emergency care model in Bolton and which meets the values, rights, obligations and expectations of patients as set out in the NHS Constitution. Providers will have the opportunity to outline how they may deliver this service. NHS Bolton CCG is keen to explore innovative ideas and value added benefits to ensure that the service contributes to the NHS Bolton CCGs strategic priorities.  The service is required to be sustainable, based on a service model that is clinically and commercially robust, that can attract and retain suitably qualified competent practitioners, integrated with other services and able to deliver the service aims. The vision for Bolton is to achieve an optimal model of urgent care. NHS Bolton CCG expects the GP OOH Service Provider to be integrated within the Bolton System Resilience Group, NHS 111 Quality Assurance Committee and associated clinical pathway and sub-groups. The members of the Bolton System Resilience Group consist of commissioners from NHS Bolton CCG, Bolton Council and local health and social care providers, enabling a whole system approach to be adopted in shaping the model of urgent care in Bolton.  This stakeholder event is in relation to a PQQ that has already been issued on 27th January 2015 via EU Supply (NHS SBS on line tendering portal) Tender Reference 18180.  The event will allow any provider who has already expressed an interest at PQQ stage to gain further information around this procurement and service model and also any new providers who may wish to express their interest now.   The PQQ can be downloaded at https://uk.eu-supply.com/app/rfq/edittransaction.asp?TID=18180 and the closing date is Tuesday 31st March 2015 at 12.00 noon.
The event will be held at The Bridge Conference Centre, 109 Bradford Street, Bolton, BL2 1JX and will commence at 1.00pm until approximately 3.00pm (lunch and refreshments are included).  Please confirm your attendance by emailing claire_barnes@nhs.net by no later than Monday 23rd March 2015.

Title: Healthier You: NHS Diabetes Prevention Programme for NHS Mid and South Essex Integrated Care Board
Description:
This is a contract award notice to communicate that NHS Mid and South Essex Integrated Care Board (herein, The Authority) has awarded Provide CIC the provision of Healthier You: Diabetes Prevention Programme for a period of 12 months from the 01st September 2022 - 31st August 2023. The total aggregate contract value is £40,235.00.

NHS England first led the procurement process for the provision of this Diabetes Prevention Programme; however, the service provision has now been delegated to The Authority. It should be noted that the funding for this service has been maintained by NHS England.

The Healthier You: The NHS Diabetes Prevention Programme (NHS DPP) identifies those at high risk of developing type 2 diabetes and refers them onto a behaviour change programme. The NHS DPP is a joint commitment from NHS England, Public Health England and Diabetes UK. Provide CIC has a facilitative role in the delivery of this Diabetes Prevention Programme which includes: project management support, providing timely communications and support to both the public and relevant health teams and wider partners, collation and presentation of performance data, expertise and input in terms of service delivery and complaints.

The Authority is publishing this Contract Award Notice in the Contracts Finder in accordance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended by The Public Procurement (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2020) for spend above £30,000. The Services in scope of this Contract Award Notice fall within 'social and other specific services' within the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended by The Public Procurement (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2020), but the total contract value does not exceed the current threshold of £663,540.

Title: London APMS GP Contract (T7)
Description:
NHS NEL CSU on behalf of NHS England London Region (hereafter referred to as "The Authority") invites suitably qualified and experienced providers to deliver APMS Services for a number of GP practices in London. This procurement process relates to the contracts for the provision of primary medical GP services (the Services) to be delivered through an Alternative Provider of Medical Services (APMS) contract.  The Commissioners of these services include the following Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) acting under delegated authority from NHS England; NHS Bexley CCG; NHS Southwark CCG; NHS Bromley CCG; NHS Camden CCG; NHS Enfield CCG; NHS Newham CCG; NHS City & Hackney CCG; NHS Tower Hamlets CCG; NHS Waltham Forest CCG; NHS Ealing CCG; NHS Hounslow CCG and NHS West London CCG.  Tranche 7 (T7) of the London APMS Programme includes 15 (fifteen) individual APMS contracts in different parts of London.  The practices/lots are: Lot 1 - Bursted Wood Surgery (DA7), Bexley, Lot 2:  Queens Road Surgery (SE15) Southwark; Lot 3:  Silverlock Medical Centre (SE16) Southwark; Lot 4:  Cator Medical Centre (BR3) Bromley; Lot 5: Brunswick Medical Centre UHPC (WC1N) Camden; Lot 6: Camden Health Improvement Practice (CHIP) (NW1) Camden; Lot 7: Ordnance Unity Centre for Health (EN3) Enfield; Lot 8: Newham Transitional Practice (E12) Newham; Lot 9: Allerton Road Medical Centre (N16) City & Hackney; Lot 10: Carpenters Practice (E15) Newham; Lot 11: Goodman's Field (formerly known as Whitechapel Health Centre & East 1 Health) (E1) Tower Hamlets; Lot 12: Abbotts Park Health Centre (formerly known as S M A) (E10) Waltham Forest; Lot 13:  Waterside Medical Centre (UB2) Ealing; Lot 14: Heston Great West Practice (TW4) Hounslow; Lot 15: Earls Court Health & Wellbeing Centre (SW5) West London. NELCSU is managing this Procurement in accordance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (the "Regulations"). As a result of this procurement exercise an agreement will be established with the successful Bidder for each Lot for a period of 5 years, with the Commissioner having the option to extend for up to a further 5 + 5 years, (subject to NHS England internal approval). The contract extension will be subject to a review of the delivery and performance of the contract.  All completed bids must be submitted by 12.00 (noon) on 19th July 2019. The ITT reference for this tender is PRJ736.  The Procurement process is facilitated entirely online via the stated e-procurement portal ProContract (the Portal). 
This procurement is split into Lots. These comprise of NHS and Social Care organisations (whether acting individually, or on behalf of, or together as members of any consortia) along with any other public or private sector bodies which NHS SBS authorises to use the resulting Framework.
With Approved Organisations tasked with delivering on commitments to achieve NHS Net Zero by 2045, with the ambition to reach an 80% reduction by 2036 to 2039, and a waste and recycling management strategy guided by sustainability placed at the forefront, this framework aims to provide a collation of services and products carefully developed by the NHS for the NHS to support the achievement of these environmental objectives. Organisation Name: National Health Service Commissioning Board (known as NHS England )
Title: Armed Forces Community - Step into Health
Description:
NHS England & Improvement are looking for expressions of interest from suppliers who are able to support delivery of the below. This is a pre-procurement exercise to better understand the market and potential suppliers that can deliver the requirement. The outcome of this engagement will inform the procurement strategy. 

PROJECT BACKGROUND

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the relationship between the NHS and the Armed Forces with collaborative efforts in the delivery of testing services, the establishment of NHS Nightingale hospitals, supporting the PPE supply chain and infrastructure to local systems.

This joint and collaborative working has highlighted that members of the Armed Forces Community have many skills which are highly sought after by employers within the NHS. 

The requirement is for a bespoke programme designed to support the employment of members of the Armed Forces community (service leavers, reservists, veterans and armed forces family members) within the NHS. The programme will support potential and current employees of the NHS and employers in the NHS.

The programme will work with both employers within the NHS and potential / current employees to introduce a series of measures designed to support the needs of both parties. These include, for example, reviewing existing recruitment and HR practices to remove barriers to the Armed Forces Community, advertising employment opportunities with the Career Transition Partnership, introductory workshops, candidate insight days, mentoring opportunities and, the provision of work placements.

The Deliverables for this requirement go beyond standard recruitment support and will be looking for supplier who can deliver the following:

- Developing candidate insight days that meet the needs of both candidate and employer.
- Raising the profile of employers within the NHS with candidates and organisations that provide employment support.
- Working with professional bodies to support the employment of clinical staff within the NHS.
-Developing networks to enable employers within the NHS to collaborate on workforce issues.
- Providing advice to employers within the NHS on NHS recruitment practice and workforce planning matters.
- Working with the Ministry of Defence and its agencies and military charities to support the Armed Forces community in employment within the NHS.
- Ensuring this project would align with broader NHS workforce policy objectives such as the NHS People Plan.
- Measuring the success of the project.
- Developing an evidence base on the benefits to the NHS of employing members of the Armed Forces Community.

REGISTER YOUR INTEREST BY 02/06/21
Interest suppliers should read the details attached to the notice which specify further details about the requirement, how to register an interest in the possible procurement and the submission requirements for registering an interest.

Title: Southern Counties Pathology Procurement
Description:
Southern Counties Pathology (SCP) is a procurement consortium of NHS and Foundation Trusts that make up the NHS Improvement South 6 Pathology Network: -
      - Hampshire Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust (HHFT)
      - University Hospitals Southampton NHS Foundation Trust (UHS)
      - Portsmouth Hospitals NHS Trust (PHT)
      - Salisbury NHS Foundation Trust (SAL)
      - IOW NHS Trust (IOW)
      - One Dorset Pathology (Poole, Bournemouth and Dorchester) (ODP)
      
      Southern Counties Pathology is not currently a Legal Entity, but it is a procurement vehicle with the aim of delivering the early procurement objectives of the South 6 Pathology Network, which are: -
      - To enable the future formation of a consolidated pathology network over the next 5 years by standardising our suppliers and the equipment they supply us to deliver our High-Volume Routine Pathology Activity.
      
      - To make early cost savings by reducing the non-pay spend on our High-Volume Routine Pathology Activity and to enable us to improve our workforce efficiency and productivity individually within our services as currently configured.
      
      Southern Counties Pathology is therefore looking to: -
      - Procure a long-term strategic partnership with core Managed Service Provider(s) (MSP)
      - Appoint a single MSP provider to deliver a core managed service contract (MSC) for Lots 1 and 2 and to act as the Agent of the named Trusts for Lots 3 to 6, which will have their own MSC contractors.
      - Secure MSC providers who are committed to actively supporting SCP to achieve its reconfiguration objectives during the life of the contract.
      
      It should be understood that the members of SCP are not all at the same procurement point with some existing contracts having short and long-term periods still to run; therefore suppliers should expect implementation to be phased over the life of the MSC contract. In general terms for the purposes of this Tender the implementation schedule will be generally: -
      Now (At Contract Let)
      - Hampshire Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust (HHFT)
      - Portsmouth Hospitals NHS Trust (PHT) - Not including Microbiology
      Short Term (12 Months from Contract Let)
      - IOW NHS Trust (IOW)
      - One Dorset Pathology (ODP); Dorset County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, Poole Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, The Royal Bournemouth and Christchurch Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.
      Medium Term (18 to 24 Months from Contract Let)
      - Salisbury NHS Foundation Trust (SAL)
      Long Term (optional following  completion of existing contracts) 
      - University Hospitals Southampton NHS Foundation Trust (UHS)
      - IOW NHS Trust (IOW)
      - Portsmouth Hospitals NHS Trust (OHT)
      
      The Lots been contracted by individual Trust(s) in the; Now, Short Term and Medium Term timescales is defined by the test and activity scope contained within the Trust Offer Schedules.

Title: Provision of Termination of Pregnancy Services - North West London
Description:
The North West London (NWL) Collaboration of Clinical Commissioning Groups are seeking to re-commission a termination of pregnancy service which enables women within these CCG boroughs to receive high quality, efficient services delivered closer to home. This procurement will be run under the Any Qualified Provider process.  

The NWL collaborative is the working partnership between the following CCGs: 
•	NHS Brent CCG
•	NHS Central London CCG
•	NHS Ealing CCG
•	NHS Hammersmith and Fulham CCG 
•	NHS Harrow CCG
•	NHS Hillingdon CCG
•	NHS Hounslow CCG, and
•	NHS West London CCG.

The Provider is required to supply a Termination of Pregnancy Service for any patient registered with a GP practice or are resident within the area covered by the CCGs listed above.

The service will commence from the 1st April 2017; the contract will last for three years, with the option to extend up to a further 24 months.

The contract (NHS Standard Contract as mandated by NHS England) will be procured using the AQP Process. The AQP is a single stage process consisting of qualification and technical stages contained within one document. Accreditation to the contract will result from providers complying with all requirements contained within. 

Central Booking Service
The following CCGs are also seeking to procure a Termination of Pregnancy Service Central Booking Service which will be procured via a sole provider:
•	NHS Brent CCG
•	NHS Ealing CCG
•	NHS Hammersmith and Fulham CCG 
•	NHS Harrow CCG
•	NHS Hillingdon CCG
•	NHS Hounslow CCG, and
•	NHS West London CCG.

Please note: this procurement has been split into two LOTS. Bidders are invited to bid for the following services:
•	Lot 1 Termination of Pregnancy Service, 
•	Lot 2 Termination of Pregnancy Central Booking Service. 

Bidder Briefing Event
Interested providers are invited to attend a provider bidder briefing event on Thursday 8th December at 9:30am.  The event will take place at St Paul's Church, Hammersmith, W6 9PJ; close to Hammersmith Underground Stations. Further detail on the bidder briefing and a registration form is attached to this advert.
Attachments: Bidder Briefing Registration form (7).docx
Additional Text:
The North West London Collaboration of Clinical Commissioning Groups are holding a bidder briefing event for those organisations interested in bidding to qualify to provide a Termination of Pregnancy Service.
The bidder briefing will provide interested organisations with an overview of the proposed new service and the CCGs' requirements, as well as an overview of the procurement process.
The briefing will take place from 9:30 am on Thursday 8th December 2016 and will last no longer than two hours. The briefing will be held at St Paul's Church, Queen Caroline Street, London, W6 9PJ, close to Hammersmith Underground Stations

Organisation Name: SOUTH CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Framework agreement for Clinical Communication Tools 2021 for NHS Organisations
Description:
The National Health Service Commissioning Board on behalf of NHSX, which is a joint unit formed by both NHS England and NHS Improvement and the Department of Health and Social Care (the Commissioner).

The Commissioner is now looking to refresh (re-procure) the Clinical Communications Tool framework to continue with the core aims of modernising the communications and tasks management systems throughout the NHS.

NHS organisations require dedicated modern communications and task management systems to enable staff time to be saved by reducing their need to use the historic 'bleep' system or by sending emails and numerous telephone calls. Staff need to share clinical information quickly and securely whilst at work (including between NHS Organisations and associated service Providers to the NHS), using tools that can be turned off when not at work.
The National Health Commissioning Board is continuing to look at Clinical Commissioning Tools services in the NHS, which include the following interventions:

Address critical pain points for clinical and/or operational teams.
Release time for individuals and teams of NHS staff.
Enable streamlined care for patients.
Support with patients transfer of care within and between NHS organisations and associated service Providers to the NHS.
Readily be able to scale widely across the NHS with at least 1 established use case.
Have an online presence and/or WebApp available.
Be downloaded onto mobile devices or tablet devices.

The Market Engagement Questionnaire (MEQ) has been developed for completion by Suppliers. To access the MEQ, Suppliers need to register with the Commissioner's online portal  In-tend (eTendering portal). 

The Commissioner asks for completed MEQs to be returned in accordance with the instructions set out in the MEQ by 3rd  September 2021 at 12:00.

The proposed scope of services is:
Lot 1 - Secure CCT / Messaging app - two-way messaging including basic image / video sharing. Please note that detailed requirements will be set out in the application specification.
Lot 2 - Secure CCT / Messaging App premium plus Enhanced Functionalities (defined below)
Lot 3 - Secure CCT / Messaging App premium plus Enhanced Functionalities and Additional Functions (as defined below)
Enhanced Functionalities: image / video transfer, task management, API integration and Interoperability with other clinical solutions and alert functionality, (including crash bleep replacement & break through silence if available), NHS directory. Please note that detailed requirements will be set out in the application specification.
Additional Functions: signposting, platform for Clinical A&G dialogue / communications. Please note that detailed requirements will be set out in the application specification.
Suppliers will be able to bid for multiple Lots.
Additional Text:
This PIN is to enable the Commissioner to gather information. It is not the call for competition and does not constitute a commitment by the Commissioner to undertake any procurement exercise. The Commissioner reserves the right to change its approach or specifications.

Further material is available after registration on the In-Tend portal
https://in-tendhost.co.uk/scwcsu/aspx/Home
(https://in-tendhost.co.uk/scwcsu/aspx/Home)
This framework is being established for NHS Organisations in England and including Wales, Scotland Northern Ireland and any Public Sector Organisations.

Title: Provision of Education Input into to the NHS Graduate Management Training Scheme 2018 - Policy and Strategy Scheme
Description:
The NHS Leadership Academy (the Academy) is the current home for the NHS Graduate Management Training Scheme (GMTS). Set up in July 2012, the Academy brings together, for the first time, all national activity supporting leadership development in health and NHS funded services.

The principal purpose of the Academy is to develop outstanding leadership in health, in order to improve people's health and their experiences of the NHS. The challenges facing the NHS require our leaders to build on their existing strengths - and develop new ones.
Our philosophy is simple - great leadership development improves leadership behaviours and skills. Better leadership leads to better patient care, experience and outcomes. Our purpose is to work with our partners to deliver excellent leadership across the NHS to have a direct impact on patient care. We offer a range of tools, models, programmes and expertise to support individuals, organisations and local academies to develop leaders, celebrating and sharing where outstanding leadership makes a real difference.
The aim of the GMTS is to identify and recruit top graduate talent and develop them into the next generation of healthcare leaders.  It is an award winning scheme which has been running for 60 years. A selection of some of its received awards can be found here: http://www.nhsgraduates.co.uk/the-scheme/what-we-offer-you/#tab-award-winning
 The Scheme is hugely oversubscribed, and in 2015, we received over 16,500 applications for approximately 112 places. In 2016, we received 16,500 applications for approximately 130 places; to start in September 2017.  
During the 60 years the GMTS has been in existence, approximately 4,450 people have started it. The current and previous Chief Executive of NHS England is an alumnus of the GMTS.
The purpose of the NHS Graduate Management Training Scheme is to identify, grow and support the future leaders of the NHS. Great leadership development improves leadership behaviors and skills. Better leadership leads to better patient care, experience and outcomes. 
It is essential that the graduate scheme provides the NHS with future leaders who can demonstrate the personal qualities and will have the required values and behaviors, key skills, and energy that will be required to provide a new world class, patient-led healthcare system for England. The NHS needs emerging leaders who are skilled at:
•	Inspiring Shared Purpose - Valuing a service ethos; curious about how to improve services and patient care; behaving in a way that reflects the principles and values of the NHS
•	Leading with Care - Having the essential personal qualities for leaders in health and social care; understanding the unique qualities and needs of a team; providing a caring, safe environment to enable everyone to do their jobs effectively
•	Evaluating Information - Seeking out varied information; using information to generate new ideas and make effective plans for improvement or change; making evidence-based
