Notice Identifier: Personal Health Budget Support Services Framework
Title: Personal Health Budget Support Services Framework on behalf of NHS Wandsworth CCG
Description:
*NHS Wandsworth CCG are holding a Market Engagement Event on the 19th December 2016 at 14:00-16:00hrs (Rooms 1 & 2, 73 Upper Richmond Rd, London, SW15 2SR) please confirm your attendance by contacting Lola Triumph (Lola.Triumph@wandsworthccg.nhs.uk).

Please review the attached document 'Wandsworth CCG Personal Health Budget Market Engagement Event' which will outline the purpose of this event and what further information will be provided by the CCG.*

NHS Wandsworth Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) is inviting appropriately qualified and experienced providers to express their interest to be appointed to a new framework of suppliers January 2017 for a duration of 4 years.

Personal Health Budget (PHB) Support Service organisations will offer a range of Support Services such as :

•	Lot 1 - Support planning
•	Lot 2 - Payment service ( including Third Party /Managed Account)
•	Lot 3 - Employer advice and guidance

PHB Support Service organisations will support Adults and Children who have been approved to receive a PHB by NHS Wandsworth CCG or its representatives.

It is estimated that around 20 PHB holders will be available to receive support planning in January 2017. This number is expected to rise significantly in line with NHS England's Mandate to increase the number of PHB holders over the next five years. This equates to a minimum of 760 PHBs for NHS Wandsworth CCG.

The expectation is that the providers that meet the initial Award Criteria and requirement of the Service Specifications for Lot 1, Lot 2 and Lot 3 will be added to the approved list of providers and initially be allocated a contract on a rotation basis of first come first serve. 

It is therefore imperative that approved providers who are added to this framework and have met the Award Criteria are ready to go live in January 2017. 

If a provider cannot be ready by this date, the CCG will then move on to the next capable provider on the accreditation list until the first 20 PHB holders are cared for. 

After the initial rotational allocation as specified above, all contracts will then be chosen by the PHB holder from the list of NHS Wandsworth CCG approved providers who have all passed and met the defined Award Criteria and requirements of the draft Service Specifications for Lot 1, Lot 2 and Lot 3.

NHS Wandsworth CCG welcomes interested parties from all market sectors, including the Third Sector and the contracts will commence during January 2017.

Expressions of interest must be by way of completion and return of the attached Questionnaire by the date and time specified within.

A Draft Service Specification is available by contacting Lola Triumph (Lola.Triumph@wandsworthccg.nhs.uk) directly.
Attachments: Wandsworth CCG PHB Support Service Market Engagement Questionnaire.docx Wandsworth CCG Personal Health Budget Market Engagement Event.docx

Title: Access to NHS 40+ Health Checks and Flu Vaccinations
Description:
The Healthy NHS Workforce Programme aims to achieve improved NHS staff health and is spearheaded by a group of 12 leading NHS organisations. These include employers such as hospitals, mental health, ambulance and community trusts and clinical commissioning groups, in partnership with NHS England, NHS Employers and Public Health England.

NHS England is also focussed upon its own internal staff health and wellbeing which is aligned totally to the external programme, offer and steer towards improving health of 5,200 employees.

The programme offers a range of support to individual staff – some of which are universal whilst others are targeted to those who might need specific support. Included in the programme is the need for:

o	Provision of the NHS health check at work for NHS staff aged 40-74 years, so that they are able to access it more easily and receive local signposting and support, while testing new models of health assessments and health-related incentives; 

o	Increasing opportunities for employees to access the ‘flu vaccination’, to reduce the incidence and spread of preventable communicable diseases.

The service is required to deliver health checks and flu vaccination clinics at 11 sites across England.

NHS England requires a minimum of 564 staff members to be given a Health Check as part of this service and provide 11 flu clinics, which offer 70+ flu vaccinations per clinic.

Interested parties must be registered on Bravo Solutions in order to access the ITQ documents.  Please use the following address if you are not already registered:  

https://nhsengland.bravosolution.co.uk/web/login.html
Additional Text:
If you are not already registered on the NHS England e-tendering portal, please use the link above to access the Invitation to Quote documents.

The deadline for submissions is 30th August 2016 @ 16:00 hours.

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: NHS England South (South West) Provision of GP Services in Plymouth
Description:
NHS England South (South West) wishes to identify provider(s) for GP Services in Plymouth. NHS England South (South West) is looking for applications from providers for the following lots.

Lot 1 Ernesettle Primary Care Centre, (Raw List 4317)
Lot 2 Mount Gould Primary Care Centre (Raw List 2411)
Lot 3 Trelawny Surgery (Raw List 2660)
Lot 4 Barne Barton Surgery (new service)

Bidders may bid for one or more lots

NHS England South (South West) proposes to use either the NHS General Medical Services (GMS), NHS Personal Medical Services (PMS) or NHS Alternative Providers of Medical Services (APMS) contract for these services, depending on the type of contract held by the successful bidder. This will be by way of variation of the existing contract for GMS/PMS

Lots 1, 2 and 3 are currently one practice with a list size of 9388 over 3 premises leased from landlords who have indicated that they would be available for future providers. This catchment area covers the whole of Plymouth

Lot 4 Barne Barton does not have premises. NHS England South (South West) wishes to commission a service to be delivered from a new purpose built primary care facility on Miers Close next to the Tamar View Community Centre.

The successful provider(s) will need to provide the full range of primary medical services from 1st April 2017 for Lots 1-3 and on opening of the new purpose built primary care facility for Lot 4

Services to be provided
NHS England is looking for an innovative and patient-centred model that is user friendly and culturally sensitive and encompasses national and local public health targets. The model will include provision of the following: 

•	Essential Services 
•	All Additional Services 
•	Enhanced Services
•	Core opening hours and service delivery from 8am – 6.30pm Monday to Friday (except statutory bank and public holidays).
The full scope of the service can be seen in the service specification. It is essential that interested providers can demonstrate an ability to mobilise to service provision.
TUPE will apply to the contract.  Details will be provided on request 

Please note: South Central and West Commissioning Support Unit are working on behalf of NHS England

Further information can be obtained at: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/scwcsu/aspx/Home
Additional Text:
Interested providers will be able to view the tender opportunity via the 'current tenders' list on in-tend. 
https://in-tendhost.co.uk/scwcsu/aspx/Home 

In order to access the tender documentation providers will need to 'express an interest' and register on the system. Bidders are required to respond to Organisational & ITN (Stage 1) questions directly within In-Tend and attach any requested documents separately to the placeholders provided.


The Services are healthcare services within the meaning and scope of Annex XIV of Directive 2014/24/EU ("the Directive") and Schedule 3 to the Public Contract Regulations 2015 ("the Regulations"). The tendering process will be conducted in accordance with the requirements and flexibilities provided by Articles 74 to 76 of the Directive, and Regulations 74 to 76 of the Regulations. The Authority will run a transparent tender process, treating all bidders equally. For the avoidance of doubt, the Authority will not be bound by the Regulations or the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union or any other regulations or legislation except for the specific parts or circumstances that apply to the procurement of these Services. 
  
Neither the inclusion of a bidder selection stage, nor the use of any language or terms found in the Directive or Regulations, nor the description of the procedure voluntarily adopted by the Authority ("Open", "Restricted", "Competitive Procedure with Negotiation", "Competitive Dialogue" or any other description), nor any other indication, shall be taken to mean that the Authority intends to hold itself bound by the Directive or Regulations, save by the provisions applicable to services coming within the scope of Annex XIV of the Directive / Schedule 3 of the Regulations. The services are healthcare services falling within Schedule 3 to the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 ("the Regulations")  which are not subject to the full regime of the Regulations, but is instead governed by the "Light Touch Regime" contained within Chapter 3, Section 7 of the Regulations (Regulations 74 to 77).

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: NHS England South (Wessex) – Diabetic Eye Screening Programme
Description:
Project - Open early engagement - This means that a procurement idea is currently active; it is in the early stage of development and judging interest from potential providers. 

NHS England South (Wessex) (the Commissioners) invites expressions of interest (EOI) from suitably qualified and experienced providers including third sector and social enterprise organisations, private and NHS to deliver the NHS Diabetic Eye Screening Programme (NDESP) to people with diabetes registered in Dorset, Hampshire (excluding Portsmouth and South East Hampshire) and Isle of Wight. 

NHS England South (Wessex) will be the contracting and commissioning authority for the NHS NDESP. Commissioners are looking for providers to deliver a high quality service across two geographical areas, namely Dorset and Hampshire/Isle of Wight. 

The aim of the NDESP is to reduce the risk of sight loss amongst people with diabetes by the prompt identification and effective treatment if necessary of sight threatening diabetic retinopathy. In line with the national specification the screening programme must operate a 12 month screening interval for all people with diabetes invited for routine digital screening plus digital surveillance clinics for individuals who require more frequent screening. 

The Commissioners would like to encourage innovative solutions which will deliver value for money, improved services to patients and increased coverage.

Contract award is anticipated to be in October 2016 and the successful bidder will be expected to commence service provision on 1st April 2017.

If you wish to express an interest in taking part in a future procurement exercise to secure provision of these services in Dorset and Hampshire/Isle of Wight (excluding Portsmouth and South East Hampshire), please register on the In-Tend portal and submit a completed Provider Sounding Questionnaire by 12pm on 18th March 2016. 

The information received during this process will be used to inform potential future solutions. NHS England South (Wessex) will be holding a market event to discuss the forthcoming procurement: date to be advised. 

Please note that: 

• this notice has been issued purely as an information seeking exercise and is not part of any formal procurement process. NHS England will not be liable for costs incurred by any interested party in participating in this exercise. 

• NHS South, Central and West Commissioning Support Unit (SCWCSU), acting on behalf of NHS England South (South Central) (the commissioners)

NHS England South (South Central) (the Commissioners) invites expressions of interest (EOI) from suitably qualified and experienced providers including third sector and social enterprise organisations, private and NHS to provide the NHS Diabetic Eye Screening Programme (NDESP) to patients living and registered in Bath & North East Somerset, Swindon and Wiltshire (BSW).

Title: Career Advisory Service - NHS Leadership Academy - NHS/SoEPS/18.463
Description:
NHS South of England Procurement Services (SoEPS), acting on behalf of the NHS Leadership Academy (the Commissioner) are commencing a tender for the provision of a Career Advisory Service.

Aim

To establish a career planning and advisory service for clinicians complete with fully worked up processes, materials and resources that will be embedded within a range of offers provided by local Academy teams.

Purpose 

•	To enable aspiring clinical leaders to have a better understanding of their career path to take a more planned approach to their careers, helping them to ensure they end up in the best possible roles for them, their skills, abilities and values.
•	To equip aspiring clinical leaders with the tools and resources to given themselves the best possible chance of securing an executive role and successfully navigate the board appointment process.
•	Ultimately to increase the proportion of clinicians in senior executive roles.

Scope

This support would be initially targeted and piloted at those who are currently operating at one below board level with a clinical background, Deputy Medical Director or Director of Nursing, Clinical Directors, Band 9 and Band 8d nursing, medical and other senior clinical leaders.

The maximum value of this contract is £80,000 exclusive of any applicable VAT. 

Bidders are invited to access the procurement documentation at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/soepscommissioning

Please access the ITT procurement documents for further information.

The deadline for submission of completed ITT submissions is Friday 04 January 2019 at 12:00pm (midday).  Late submissions will not be accepted.  The e-portal system will shutdown at 12:00pm and any un-submitted bids not registered to the system at this time will not be accepted.  Therefore, please submit in good time prior to the deadline date and time.

Project title: Career Advisory Service - NHS Leadership Academy, please access the ITT for all documents.  Should Bidders have any queries regarding registration or are having problems using the portal, they should contact the In-tend dedicated Supplier Helpdesk by calling 0845 557 8079 Monday to Friday (9am to 5pm) or email support@in-tend.co.uk

All communications should be made via the messaging function on the In-tend E-Tendering portal.  During the tender exercise the Contracting Authority requests that all communications are channelled through the e-portal system via the appointed procurement specialist on behalf of NHS South of England Procurement Services and not with the Contracting Authority itself. No Bidder, Bidder Member, or any of such Bidder's advisors, consultants or subcontractors may have ex parte communications with the Contracting Authority or any of their employees, advisors, contractors or consultants regarding the ITT, the Procurement, other than as expressly permitted in this ITT.

Title: Prior Information Notice (PIN) and Market Engagement for the delivery of a Masters in Genomic Medicine - part of the NHS Genomics Education Programme, Health Education England - NHS/SoEPS/17.329
Description:
NHS South of England Procurement Services, acting on behalf of Health Education England (the Commissioner) will be commencing a tender for the delivery of a Masters (MSc) in Genomic Medicine to support workforce transformation, development and training that is intended to respond to the Department of Health's plans for an NHS that delivers personalised medicine. The MSc is preparing NHS Staff at many different levels for the future of genomics in contemporary healthcare. It is aimed at all members of the multi-professional team. It utilises innovative approaches to delivering masters level academic knowledge to genetics and non-genetics professionals to equip them to understand and embed genomics into their everyday practice. The qualification enables individuals at different levels in the workforce to implement change within their own sphere of practice, directing the workforce transformation required to make genomic services a reality in healthcare. It is envisioned that funded places will be issued to providers according to local demand with a maximum number allowed within each academic year. The total contract value is estimated to be up to £7.2 million.  Total funds to be shared between up to 10 providers

This Prior Information Notice (PIN) is to advise prospective providers of the Commissioners intention.

We also plan to hold a Market Engagement session in London at The Grange Holborn Hotel, WC1B 4AR on 12 July 2017 from 10:30-15:00. This will provide an opportunity for potential providers to find out more about the aims of the tender and contracts, the process involved as well as network with others. HEE will use the opportunity to gather intelligence from providers which may influence the final tender.

Please RSVP by Friday 7th July 2017 with the name, title and contact details for attendees (a maximum of two attendees per organisation) to: 

David Callaghan
Project Manager - Genomics Education Programme 

 E. david.callaghan@hee.nhs.uk
The commissioner reserves the right not to proceed with the Procurement, or any part thereof, or change the requirements as necessary at any time.

It is the intention of the commissioner that the procurement will be conducted as on OJEU Service Contract using an Open Procedure under the Public Contracts Regulations 2015.  The ITT is expected to be published in August 2017.  A separate advert will be released advising of this.
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and The Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West

Title: NHS Cheshire & Merseyside ICB (formerly NHS South Sefton CCG) - APMS Contracts
Description:
NHS Cheshire & Merseyside ICB (formerly NHS South Sefton CCG) - APMS Contracts

NHS Midlands and Lancashire Commissioning Support Unit (CSU) is working on behalf NHS Cheshire & Merseyside ICB to award 9 GP surgery contracts.

These 9 GP surgeries will be split into 5 LOTs as follows:

LOT 1: Hightown
LOT 2: North Park
LOT 3: Great Crosby and Thornton (covering the 3 GP practices of Crosby Village, Crossways and Thornton)
LOT 4: Seaforth, Litherland & Netherton (covering the 3 GP practices of Seaforth, Litherland & Netherton)
LOT 5: Maghull

The contract value is based on the basic GMS rate for 2022-23 which is £99.70 per patient and each LOT has been valued on the patient list size as January 2022.  The contract value excludes any contract enhancements that may be available to the successful Bidder such as Quality & Outcomes Framework (QOF), Local Quality Contract (LQC) and Directed Enhanced Services (DES).  The contract value also excluded premises costs.

The awarded contract length is 7 years, split into a 5-year contract with the option to extend for a further 2-year period.

Organisation Name: STAFFORDSHIRE AND LANCASHIRE COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: NHS Southport & Formby CCG and NHS South Sefton CCG - Support Service for Personal Health / Wheelchair Budgets
Description:
NHS Midlands and Lancashire Commissioning Support Unit (CSU) is working on behalf of NHS Southport & Formby CCG and NHS South Sefton CCG who are awarding a contract for a Support Service for Personal Health / Wheelchair Budgets.

This support service is for individuals who require support with Direct Payment Personal Health Budgets; Third Party Personal Health Budgets or Third Party Personal Wheelchair Budgets.

The support service will undertake support to individuals for Direct Payment Personal Health Budgets (PHBs).  Individuals are expected to buy and manage health services themselves and hold audit trails of their spend.  The support service will undertake to support individuals or their carers to manage the Direct Payments and keep an audit trail of these payments.  

The support service will also undertake support to individuals for Third Party Personal Health Budgets (PHBs).  This is where the organisation will hold the money on behalf of the induvial and pay for and arranges the care and support as agreed in a care plan.  Third Party Wheelchair Budgets operate in a similar manner where the organisation assists the individual to purchase mobility equipment from outside of the NHS.
Contact Address 1: c/o NHS South Sefton CCG and NHS Southport & Formby CCG
Additional Text:
The CCGs published a Future Opportunity Notice on 21st May 2021 inviting any provider to respond to a call for Expressions of Interest (EOIs).  Only 1 provider responded to the call for EOIs and was able to demonstrate that they had the skills, experience and capability to deliver the service.  Therefore, the CCGs are intending to award a contract to this provider, which is Sefton Carers Centre.

Following publication of the VEAT notice on Friday 15th October 2021, there will be a 10-day standstill period, concluding on Monday 25th October 2021. Following satisfactory conclusion of the standstill period, the CCGs will enter into a contract with Sefton Carers Centre for 3 years with the option to extend by 2 years.

Organisation Name: SOUTH CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Procurement for the Provision of Assisted Conception Services for Western Devon and Cornwall to NHS Devon CCG and NHS Kernow CCG
Description:
NHS Devon CCG and NHS Kernow CCG are launching a process to commission Assisted Conception Services for Western Devon and Cornwall.

This procurement consists of an initial 3 year contract at a value of £725,000 per annum. An extension of an additional period of up to 2 years is available, also at a value of £725,000 per annum.

The purpose of the Assisted Conception Service is to provide a range of appropriate assisted conception services for couples who meet the eligibility criteria. The service aims to treat confirmed infertility. The objective of treatment is to achieve a successful pregnancy quickly and safely with the least intervention required.

This procurement is being carried out by NHS South, Central and West Commissioning Support Unit (SCW) on behalf of the Commissioners.

Areas in scope of this procurement:
•	To  help couples suffering from subfertility or confirmed infertility who meet the criteria to access licensed treatment to achieve a successful pregnancy 
•	To offer licensed assisted conception treatment for patients suffering from subfertility or confirmed infertility who meet the criteria to access treatment. 
•	To offer storage of gametes or embryos for patients who are on the NHS funded pathway or will be at risk of requiring Assisted Conception treatment in the future (e.g. patients receiving treatment likely to impact on their future fertility). 
•	To provide a quality, safe, cost effective Assisted Conception Service ensuring that the risk of infection and other complications such as Ovarian hyper stimulation syndrome (OHSS) and multiple pregnancy to service users is minimised. 
•	To provide a personal service sensitive to the physical, psychological and emotional needs of service users. Including that patients will be offered counselling with a Specialist Fertility Counsellor in line with the HFEA Code of Practice. 
•	To ensure effective communication between service users and the service providers. 
•	To ensure effective communication between commissioners and the service providers. 
•	To ensure effective partnership working with the network of fertility service providers in the region, including providers of collaborative satellite care services.
•	To develop and implement data collection and monitoring processes which provide fertility services intelligence to support the future commissioning of fertility services.
•	To provide a diagnostic semen analysis service.
•	To procure and process gametes for licensed treatments.
Additional Text:
Interested providers will be able to view this notice via the 'current tenders' list on the e-procurement system In-Tend, available on the following link: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/scwcsu/aspx/Home 

In order to submit a bid, you will need to be registered on the e-procurement system and 'express an interest', and then complete a response as specified within the procurement documents. 

On registration, please include at least two contacts to allow for access to the system in times of absence.

Title: NHS 111 and NHS 111 Integrated Urgent Care Contingency Support Services
Description: South Central Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust (the Authority) is seeking to procure NHS 111 and NHS Integrated Urgent Care Contingency Support Services (the Services) from a single Sub-Contractor for a contract commencing on 1 September 2018 for a period of three years with the option to extend the contract by up to two years in one year increments.The Services will be based on the Integrated Care Commissioning Standards published in September 2015, to deliver to the public and healthcare professionals a single point of telephony access to urgent care, alongside their registered GP and affording the Authority the ability to coordinate urgent care intervention through the NHS 111 service, the Clinical Hub and an Out of Hours telephony & appointment service.The scope of the Service is to provide a managed service comprising call centre agents (Health Advisers), Nurse Advisors and supervisory staff for the duration of the Contract housed within the Sub-contractor's Call Centre.
Contact Address 1: Units 7 and 8 Talisman Business Centre, Talisman Road

Organisation Name: N E L Commissioning Support Unit
Title: Medicine Optimisation for NHS Newcastle Gateshead CCG and NHS South Tyneside CCG (Practice and Care Home Prescribing Support)
Description:
NHS Newcastle Gateshead CCG and NHS South Tyneside CCG are seeking providers to deliver a comprehensive, high quality medicines optimisation (pharmaceutical and prescribing support) service to all GP practices and practice staff within the Clinical Commissioning Group boundaries, to support the delivery of the CCG'S medicines optimisation strategy.

Newcastle Gateshead Clinical Commissioning Group comprises 65 practices with a single management structure. The CCG employs a small Medicines Optimisation Team directly, which will direct the work of the practice based team(s) that are the subject of this tender. Prescribing expenditure continues to be significant pressure for the CCG and medicines optimisation has a key role in the management of this budget.

Practice based prescribing teams have been in place for a number of years in both localities. The CCG is taking this opportunity to rebalance the service provision in the two localities.

The overall aim of the service is to support the CCGs to improve the quality, safety and cost effective use of medicines in primary care, reduce variation in practice and improve health outcomes for patients. This will be achieved through the implementation of a medicines optimisation action plan, approved by the commissioner and implemented by the provider through the provision of high quality medicines optimisation support to all practices within the boundaries of the CCGs

A fundamental component of the service is that it works in an integrated way with the CCG team, medicines optimisation commissioning support, GPs and GP practice teams to ensure multi-disciplinary working and a patient centred approach to achieve the optimal use of medicines and best outcomes for patients.

The service will have equitable access, ensuring that patients are treated with dignity and respect, are fully informed about their care and are able to make decisions about their care in partnership with healthcare professionals


NHS South Tyneside Clinical Commissioning Group (NHS STCCG) constitutes 24 GP practices.  There are 22 Nursing and Residential homes situated within South Tyneside.

The CCG's Medicines Optimisation Team will direct the work of the practice based team(s) that are the subject of this tender. Prescribing expenditure continues to be significant pressure for the CCG and medicines optimisation has a key role in the management of this budget.

The overall aim of the service is to support the CCGs to improve the quality, safety and cost effective use of medicines in primary care, reduce variation in practise and improve health outcomes for patients. This will be achieved through the implementation of a medicines optimisation action plan, approved by the commissioner 
The contract start date is 1st October 2017. The contract period will be 3 years (36 months) followed by an optional extension of up to 2 years (24 months). Therefore the maximum contract duration, including available extensions, is 5 years (60 months).

Title: Community podiatry services NHS Scarborough and Ryedale and NHS Vale of York CCGs
Description:
Community podiatry services NHS Scarborough and Ryedale and NHS Vale of York CCGs
The overarching aim of this service is the local provision of a high quality community podiatry service that is delivered for the GP registered patient population of NHS Scarborough and Ryedale CCG and NHS Vale of York CCG, which will improve patient outcomes within available resources. The service shall coordinate, promote, embed and provide, via the usual integrated structures for access, a holistic care pathway that has self-care, preventative care and medical care as the key components to improve the overall quality of life for patients and carers affected by foot health problems.
The primary purpose of the service is to provide an evidence based service through an agreed route of referral for podiatry patients. A service that is accessible and provides timely podiatric and bio-mechanical assessment and management of podiatric related issues by a highly skilled workforce, reflective of patient’s needs.

Organisation Name: MIDLANDS AND LANCASHIRE COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: NHS East Lancashire Clinical Commissioning Group & NHS Blackburn with Darwen Clinincal Commissioning Group - Dexa Services
Description:
NHS East Lancashire Clinical Commissioning Group and NHS Blackburn with Darwen Clinical Commissioning Group are seek interested providers for the provision of Dexa Services in the Pennine Lancashire footprint.

The Commissioner wishes to receive responses to the Invitation to Tender (ITT) from suitably qualified and experienced service providers with the necessary capacity and capability (or a demonstrable ability to provide the necessary capacity and capability) to provide the range of services required. 

Current services are approximately valued at £397,000 across the life of a three year contract but commissioners seek financial efficiencies through the tender.

Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA) scans are widely recognised as an efficient way of measuring bone mineral density (BMD) to predict people who are risk of fragility fractures as a result of osteoporosis or thinning bones. Identifying people who are at risk of fractures allows for appropriate interventions to be made. The scans also provide the ‘Gold Standard’ for diagnosing osteoporosis.

The demand for DEXA scans over the last few years has stabilised, although there is a potential for these to increase slightly as people age and particularly amongst post-menopausal women, and predictions for future populations indicate an ageing population.

The aim is to maintain scanning rates to a level which is in line with recognised good practice for the identification and management of osteoporosis, and able to cater for future demand (e.g. ageing population).

Key objectives of the Pennine Lancashire Procurement are to:

•	Provide patients with access to an NHS Community DEXA scan service
•	Ensure patients are seen and treated in a community setting most appropriate to their needs
•	Deliver an integrated model of DEXA service provision for Pennine Lancashire
•	Deliver affordable and value for money NHS Community DEXA scan service
•	Provide safe, high quality care

Interested parties should express an interest in the tender through the Bravo Solution e-procurement portal and complete the ITT by 27 May 2016 - https://mlcsu.bravosolution.co.uk/

Title: My Life A Full Life, Health & Care System Redesign (NHS England Vanguard) – Isle of Wight CCG, IOW Council, IOW NHS Trust, One Wight Health (GPs), and the Voluntary Sector
Description:
The Whole Integrated Systems Redesign (WISR) is a project to examine the current provision of health and care services on the Isle of Wight, the challenges in delivering them and then set out options to reshape them. The purpose of the review is to make sure health and care services on the Isle of Wight make best use of available resources and continue to deliver excellence for years to come.  The Isle of Wight Clinical Commissioning Group in partnership with the Isle of Wight Council, the Isle of Wight NHS Trust has appointed a consortium to lead on this work. 

The programme will be underpinned by detailed modelling aligned to in-depth public consultation split into two phases. The first phase – “detailing the case for change” – runs for two months, between March and May 2016. This phase seeks to make the public aware of the challenges facing the Island’s health and care services, as well as the opportunities to reshape them. It invites views on the current state of services and asks the public for any changes they might like to see. 

Alongside this activity, a programme of co-production is being established, looking at a number of priority areas and inviting people to participate in directly helping to reshape service. The outputs of this phase will then inform the development of a formal consultation that will set out specific options to redesign services on the Island, planned for autumn 2016, although this is subject to NHS England assurance processes. 

The WISR project is being carried out through the My Life a Full Life (MLAFL) programme.  MLALF is an NHS England Vanguard site and part of the national New Models of Care programme. It is a collaboration of organisations, including the Isle of Wight Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG), the Isle of Wight Council (IWC), the Isle of Wight NHS Trust (IWNHS Trust) and One Wight Health (a GP membership organisation), who work in partnership with the voluntary sector to fundamentally change and improve the lives of people on the Island. My Life A Full Life aims to provide for people’s individual needs to enable them to take control of their lives and plan for their future health and social care needs. This work is currently based on the partners’ five year vision for integrated health and social care on the Island.
Additional Text:
This invitation for expressions of interest is published as part of the preliminary market engagement exercise being carried out to inform the WISR project. Its publication does not commit the commissioners to carrying out any subsequent procurement exercise in any form. However, in the event that the commissioners do carry out a subsequent procurement, participants should note that a procurement of NHS commissioning contracts that has been commenced through the publication of an advertisement for expressions of interest as at this date will not be conducted under the Public Contracts Regulations 2015. In relation to any subsequent procurement, the publication of this notice does not indicate that the commissioners are binding themselves to follow any particular process under the Public Contracts Regulations. 
No potential participant will be disadvantaged, in relation to a subsequent procurement, through not taking part in this market engagement exercise.
To respond to this expression of interest, please respond to the email address WISR@iow.nhs.uk, with the reference “Provider expression of interest response” in the title.

Organisation Name: The East of England NHS Collaborative Procurement Hub (EOECPH)
Title: Provision and Support of Electronic Patient Record System
Description:
The East of England NHS Collaborative Procurement Hub (EOECPH) is issuing this Invitation to Tender ("ITT") to invite Suppliers to bid for Framework Agreement for Provision and Support of an Electronic Patient Record System (EPR). 

The EoECPH is working collaboratively with the National Ambulance Procurement Board on this procurement with an aim of providing a procurement compliant route to market for UK Ambulance Services wishing to procure Electronic Patient Record System.

The Framework awarded will have an initial framework duration of 2 with the option to extend framework duration by 2 x 1 year periods.

Call-Off Order Contracts awarded under the Framework can be valid for a period more than the Framework Agreement duration. Durations of Call-Off Order
Contracts awarded under the Framework, will be at the discretion of the Beneficiary using the Framework, who will take into consideration the type and complexity of project, and or the relationship the Beneficiary calling off from the Framework is looking to set up with its chosen Supplier and Partner. Any Framework extensions will only be extended and awarded following a full specification review that will take into account the changing digital landscape for the NHS.

The following benefits are intended:   
• Work in partnership with Ambulance Services in the UK to aggregate spend; 
• Drive cash releasing savings for reinvestment in front line services; 
• Review options to standardise & rationalise products and services across the UK;
•	Improve processes for staff in terms of accessing products and services that they require, when they need it; • A contribution to improvements in patient care;


The primary beneficiaries of the framework will be United Kingdom ambulance services as detailed below:

Title: Young People's Health Challenge
Description:
The Authority required a national provider or consortia to develop a "Young People's Health Challenge" award(s) for 7-14-year olds.  This will be a programme that aims to teach young people about the NHS and encourage them to undertake some social action activity to support their local community or the NHS.  The toolkit will be 'open access' meaning that any young people's organisation such as youth clubs, uniformed youth organisations or schools can pick up the module and deliver it with the young people they work with thereby providing the opportunity to influence a wide range of young people from diverse backgrounds.  The provider will develop a suite of resources using different mediums to ensure that the toolkit is accessible to all (i.e., online, paper and face to face) and can support a wide range of youth providers to deliver and support their young people to complete the module.

Young People's Health Challenge aims to teach young people aged 7 -14 about the NHS and encourage them to undertake some social action activity to support the NHS. This is key for the future of our NHS whilst providing young people with valuable skills and aspirations to work or volunteer within the NHS or engage in social action. In addition, educating young people about self-care and appropriate use of NHS services can have an impact on the entire family's use of NHS services and social action is known to provide health and wellbeing benefits to individuals.  Introducing social action at a young age can establish a lifetime of volunteering and social action, thereby providing a protective element to an individual's health and wellbeing. 
 
The NHS People Plan recognises the value of introducing young people into volunteering roles in the NHS with a view to encouraging them to think about a longer-term career in the NHS.  The NHS Long Term plan builds on this encouraging greater access for younger volunteers as part of the commitment to increase diversity of volunteers. NHS Cadets was established for this purpose, working with 14-18-year olds and is delivered in partnership with St John Ambulance.  At present we have no provision for younger aged children.  This programme builds further on this, working with younger children to start to introduce them to the NHS at a time when they will just be thinking about what they might like to be when they are older.

Title: Community Midwifery Services
Description:

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Commissioning Support Services for Non-Specialised Clinical Activity in London
Description:
East Berkshire Clinical Commissioning group (on behalf of The London Focus Group (LFG)) are intending to proceed with a one-year extension of their current contract with Optum for commissioning support of NHS healthcare services. Optum represent the London Focus Group in the contract negotiation and management (including raising data challenges and disputes) of 16 non-specialist providers in London. The total planned contract values that were managed by Optum in 2018/19 were c£64m. This contract extension will provide short term cover to the CCGs whilst they review the longer term provision of their commissioning support in light of changing national guidance and directives.
The London Focus Group ('LFG') consists of the following CCGs;
•	NHS East Berkshire CCG
•	NHS Berkshire West CCG
•	NHS Buckinghamshire CCG
•	NHS Oxfordshire CCG
•	NHS Dorset CCG
•	NHS Fareham and Gosport CCG
•	NHS South Eastern Hampshire CCG
•	NHS Portsmouth CCG
•	NHS Southampton CCG
•	NHS West Hampshire CCG
•	NHS North East Hampshire and Farnham CCG
•	NHS North Hampshire CCG
Pending clarification at national level of potentially new commissioning arrangements, the Commissioners intend to award a one-year contract extension to the incumbent service provider on grounds of proportionality, technical (specification) and economics. It is considered that:
•	For an extension period of just one year, no provider would be capable of offering a more economically advantageous tender for delivering the specification that has been developed during the course of the current five-year contract;
•	A competitive procurement should be undertaken only if there is clear potential for a material cost saving and benefits outweighing the costs of their generation. In this case the Commissioners consider that there is no such potential, the incumbent provider having (a) demonstrated its competitiveness against other providers through the award of two contracts spanning ten years and (b) having demonstrated acceptable performance throughout that period, generating significant cost savings; 
•	Furthermore, when designing and delivering procurements, the Commissioners are required to have proper regard for the bidding costs providers incur and must seek to avoid wasted costs where the likelihood of a change of provider is deemed very low;
•	The Commissioners' decision to award a contract extension to the incumbent provider without competition is therefore proportionate and appropriate on technical and economic grounds.

Organisations which believe they could provide the above service within the required timescale and offer better value for money are invited to express interest by email to mstanbrook@nhs.net. Please note that TUPE would be expected to apply to this contract in the event of a change of provider.
Attachments: LFG PIN.docx
Additional Text: Please note that a corresponding advert for this service has also been sent for publication in the OJEU.

Organisation Name: Taunton and Somerset NHS Foundation Trust
Title: RBa/TS/LOC/0381 Dynamic Purchasing System for Clinical Services
Description:
The Dynamic Purchasing System will cover services commissioned under the NHS Standard Contract that exists between the NHS Trusts in Somerset (Taunton and Somerset NHS Foundation Trust, Yeovil District Hospital NHS Foundation Trust and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation), the Somerset Clinical Commissioning Group and other associate commissioners.

Taunton and Somerset NHS Foundation Trust are establishing a Dynamic Purchasing System for use by NHS Trusts in Somerset, for the provision of clinical service providers to support waiting list initiatives and ad hoc service capacity issues.  These initiatives tend to be required at short notice for a minimum of 3 months, although some services may be outsourced for a shorter or longer period of time.    

Health providers deliver NHS funded clinical services under the terms of the NHS Standard Contract. It is becoming increasingly common for health providers to sub-contract delivery of certain clinical services to a third party. This subcontracting can take many forms. It can be the sub-contracting of an entire service or of delivery of part of a care pathway. It can be the sub-contracting to one sub-contractor or to multiple sub-contractors.  Information about the NHS Standard contract and Sub contracting can be found at https://www.england.nhs.uk/nhs-standard-contract/17-18/

Clinical specialities/clinical services may be included, but are not limited to the following clinical services:

Orthopaedic surgery (Joints - hips/knees & hands), Urology, General Surgery, Maxillofacial surgery Ophthalmology, Phacoemulsification cataract extraction and lens implant, Audiology (hearing tests) , Endoscopy, Lithotripsy, Termination of pregnancy, Radiology services (MRI and Cardiac MRI scans, Duplex Scanning). Histopathology reporting. 

Mini competitions will be run from the Dynamic Purchasing System which will reflect the specific clinical service requirements in order to ensure that the sub-contract provider will:
-	meet quality requirements, 
-	meet relevant conditions from  Terms and Conditions of the NHS Standard Contract, 
-	reflect the NHS price for the service 
-	provide assurances that they are capable of delivering the agreed service requirements that have been set
-	comply with any referral protocols.  

Requests to participate in the Dynamic Purchasing System must be addressed via the Pro Contract procurement portal located at https://procontract.due-north.com/Login/Index?ReturnUrl=%2fHome%2fAbout

Title: Termination of Pregnancy Services - Sussex NHS/SOEPS/18.468 ITT

For provision of services across all 3 Sussex Clinical Commissioning Group areas:

Commissioners are seeking bids from Healthcare Providers for provision of Termination of Pregnancy Services across Sussex. The provider will deliver Termination of Pregnancy Services that adhere to national clinical guidelines, to the population of Sussex across 3 Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) areas, under the standard NHS Contract. The anticipated value of the service is approximately £2,195,000.00 per annum. The value stated represents the total value over the potential full term including extension period, of 7 years. Title: Community Pharmacy Consultation Service (CPCS) Continuing Professional Development (CPD) Workshops - Health Education England - NHS/SoEPS/19.582 PIN
Description:
HEE, in partnership with NHS England & Improvement, is seeking to engage providers to deliver continuing professional development (CPD) workshops for pharmacists working in community pharmacy, providing services under the Community Pharmacy Contractual Framework: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/819601/cpcf-2019-to-2024.pdf.  

This is an initial 1 year contract with a maximum value of £2,000,000. These figures include VAT. Please note payment relates to financial years. The Framework, agreed by DHSC, NHS England and NHS Improvement, and the Pharmaceutical Services Negotiating Committee (PSNC),  was released in July 2019, and describes how community pharmacy will support delivery of the NHS Long Term Plan. A new NHS Community Pharmacist Consultation Service (CPCS), launched in October 2019, forms part of the Community Pharmacy Contractual Framework. CPCS will enable patients to be better connected with community pharmacy, allowing delivery of an effective service that is convenient for patients and demonstrates the value of community pharmacy.

HEE is intending to commission continuing professional development (CPD) workshops to drive forward the workforce elements of the Pharmacy Integration Fund and develop and strengthen the role of community pharmacists. The integration of pharmacy professionals into locally delivered care pathways will yield benefits for the patients and the service, resulting in a more responsive and clinically effective NHS primary care patient pathway whilst meeting the public's expectations for a modern NHS community pharmacy service.

The Community Pharmacy Consultation Service (CPCS) Continuing Professional Development (CPD) Workshops will provide the opportunity to enhance community pharmacists' knowledge, skills and confidence to undertake effective patient-facing consultations, assessments and communications as part of the NHS urgent care pathways. The ambition is that pharmacists are valued across all sectors and recognised by patients and the public, and by all professions and industry leaders, for their impact and contribution to healthcare. 

This PIN is to advise prospective providers of the Commissioners intention.
 
Community Pharmacy Consultation Service (CPCS) Continuing Professional Development (CPD) Workshops: Market Engagement Workshop will be held on:
Wednesday 23rd October 2019 from 10:00 to 13.00 at a central London location, TBC.

This will provide an opportunity for potential providers to find out more about the aims of the tender, the procurement process and contracting arrangements as well as proving an opportunity for networking. HEE will use the opportunity to gather intelligence from providers which may influence the final tender.

RSVP by Wednesday 16th October 2019 with the name, title, email address and telephone number for attendees (a maximum of two attendees per organisation) to:  

hee.phif@hee.nhs.uk
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and The Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West
Additional Text:
The Commissioner reserves the right not to proceed with the Procurement, or any part thereof, or change the requirements and timescales as necessary at any time.

It is the intention of the Commissioner that the procurement will be conducted as a Service Contract using an Open Procedure under the Public Contracts Regulations 2015. The ITT is expected to be published in November 2019 with delivery training to commence from March 2020.

A separate advert will be released advising when the procurement is live for submissions.

Notice Identifier: NHS Vale Of York CCG Procurement
Title: NHS Vale of York CCG Anticoagulation Warfarin Monitoring and Management Service
Description:
NHS Vale of York CCG is seeking providers to deliver a Level 4 Anticoagulation Warfarin Monitoring and Management Service for the following practices:
•	East Parade Medical Practice, York 
•	Beech Tree Surgery, Selby 
•	Escrick Surgery, Escrick 
•	Sherburn Group Practice, Sherburn in Elmet 
•	Tadcaster Medical Centre, Tadcaster 

The Anticoagulation Warfarin Monitoring and Management Service in the NHS Vale of York CCG area was, in the main, historically provided by York Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust through a traditional phlebotomy-based service. The CCG is now transferring this service from secondary care into the community, using a near patient testing model.

NHS Vale of York CCG are looking for providers to provide on an equitable basis, a safe and effective initiation, stabilisation, monitoring, dosing and prescribing for a community-based anticoagulation service (warfarin monitoring and management). The community provider will be the first line treatment service for anticoagulation therapy and any patients who have been under the management of York Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust anticoagulation service will be transferred to the community provider for continued management.

Currently there are circa 4000 patients across the NHS Vale of York CCG footprint who utilise the Anticoagulation Monitoring and Management Service and the service is predominantly provided in primary care apart from the 5 practices listed below. However, if any existing primary care providers opt out of providing this service in the future, we reserve the right (subject to the agreement of all parties) to potentially add additional practices at any point throughout the duration of this contract

•	East Parade Medical Practice, York 
•	Beech Tree Surgery, Selby 
•	Escrick Surgery, Escrick 
•	Sherburn Group Practice, Sherburn in Elmet 
•	Tadcaster Medical Centre, Tadcaster 

NHS Vale of York CCG wish to establish a single Provider contract for the provision of the Anticoagulation Warfarin Monitoring and Management Service for the above 5 practices

Providers must use INRstar as the appropriate computerised decision support software (CDSS), which requires a secure NHS connection. All providers are expected to purchase the INRstar software licences and all hardware required to provide a point of care anticoagulation testing and dosing service.

The contract is due to commence on 1 January 2019 and the new provider must transfer 100% of all patients from York Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust to their service, no later than 31 January 2019.
Contact Address 1: NHS Vale of York CCG, West Offices
Additional Text:
This procurement is not subject to the Public Contract Regulations

Suppliers Instructions How to Express Interest in this Tender~: 1. Register your company on the eSourcing portal (this is only required once) - Browse to the eSourcing Portal: https://www.nhssourcing.co.uk and click the link to register -
Accept the terms and conditions and click 'continue' - Enter your correct business and user details - Note the username you chose and click 'Save' when complete - You will shortly receive an email with your unique password (please keep this secure) 2.
Express an Interest in the tender - Login to the portal with the username/password - Click the 'PQQs / ITTs Open To All Suppliers' link. (These are Pre-Qualification Questionnaires or Invitations to Tender open to any registered supplier) - Click on the
relevant PQQ/ ITT to access the content. - Click the 'Express Interest' button at the top of the page. - This will move the PQQ /ITT into your 'My PQQs/ My ITTs' page. (This is a secure area reserved for your projects only) -You can now access any attachments by clicking 'Buyer Attachments' in the 'PQQ/ ITT Details' box 3.
Responding to the tender - Click 'My Response' under 'PQQ/ ITT Details', you can choose to 'Create Response' or to 'Decline to Respond' (please give a reason if declining) - You can now use the 'Messages' function to communicate with the buyer
and seek any clarification - Note the deadline for completion, then follow the onscreen instructions to complete the PQQ/ ITT - There may be a mixture of online & offline actions for you to perform (there is detailed online help available) You must then submit your reply using the 'Submit Response' button at the top of the page. If
you require any further assistance please consult the online help or contact the eTendering help desk

Notice Identifier: Bravo Project Reference: 1395 - Invitation to Tender (ITT) 1654 Any Qualified Provider
Title: NHS England (Wessex) AQP Provision of Intermediate Oral Surgery Services in Wessex
Description:
NHS England (Wessex) is responsible for the GP registered populations of Dorset, Bournemouth, Poole, Hampshire, Isle of Wight, Portsmouth and Southampton. They have commissioned intermediate oral surgery services to this population on an AQP basis to ensure that patients who need treatment which falls outside the scope of a General Dental Practitioner, but who do not require the facilities of a general hospital site, can be seen in the right place, at the right time, by the right person first time. It is expected that services will be available from a range of locations across the Wessex area, at times convenient to patients across 7 days per week.    

Two levels of service provision have been commissioned:

Lot 1. Services led by a Specialist on the General Dental Council or     General Medical Council specialist registers or Consultant

Lot 2. Services led by non-specialist Dentists with additional qualifications

The service will be subject to continuous development and review following publication of the NHS England Commissioning Guide for oral surgery.  The review will be undertaken and implemented through the Local Professional Network (Dental).

 
The period of Contract for the AQP accreditation will be for five (5) years from the 1st November 2015 with a two (2) year extension option. 

NHS England (Wessex) may open up additional qualification 'windows' during the lifetime of the contract.
Additional Text:
All interested parties should note that this Service Procurement falls within the scope of “Part B Services” as defined in the Public Contracts Regulations 2006 (as amended) and Directive 2004/18/EC. Therefore the 2006 Regulations and the 2004 Directive are only applicable to the Service Procurement to the extent required for Part B Services. 

For the procurement of healthcare services for the purposes of the NHS within the scope of the National Health Services (Procurement, Patient Choice and Competition) (No. 2) Regulations 2013 (the "NHS Regulations"), there is a temporary exemption from the Public Contracts Regulations 2015, which generally means that healthcare services, when procured by CCGs and NHS England, will continue to be subject to the Public Contracts Regulations 2006 (the "2006 Regulations") until 18 April 2016. 

NHS England has decided to follow an Any Qualified Provider (AQP) tendering procedure for the Service Procurement. Bidders should note that this should not be taken as an acceptance by NHS England that any part of the 2006 Regulations or the 2004 Directive (other than those provisions specifically applicable to Part B Service Procurement) apply to this Service Procurement.

Title: Design, development and delivery of supported internships in the NHS for young people across the North of England
Description:
Expressions of interest are being sought from organisations/partnerships with a proven record in delivering work placement experiences for young people within the North region, to design, produce and deliver high quality and focused support prior to, and during and after, the work experience interventions designed to provide insights into the work of the NHS, and the wide range of careers available. 

The aim of internships is to give young people access to paid work experience in the NHS, including students from disadvantaged backgrounds. HEE North wants to expand the paid internships it supports across the geography of the North region during 2018 and in doing so support the delivery of the following objectives:
•	Raise the profile of the wide spectrum of roles within the NHS, including apprenticeship options
•	Proactively encourage new organisations and new NHS Mentors to become involved in supporting students, especially students studying Health and Social Care
•	Support the NHS Mentors to provide ongoing mentoring to the students during the academic year
•	Support students from lower income families, to gain the confidence, skills and networks to achieve their potential in the future
•	Enable students to learn from employers about work and the skills that are valued in the work place and to have first-hand experience of the workplace
•	Raise awareness of opportunities for students to explore the possibility of undertaking volunteering work in the NHS after their internship ends
•	Develop innovative options for the internship experiences, possibly spanning more than one school/college holiday period/NHS department
•	Support NHS organisations to find new ways to provide the internship placements, and support the development of role descriptions, interviews of the students as part of the overall experience etc
•	Support the ongoing delivery of two key HEE strategies - Talent for Care and Widening Participation, and the local career agendas of the NHS Sustainability and Transformation Partnerships (SPTs) across the North of England.

Organisation Name: N E L Commissioning Support Unit
Title: South East London Integrated Urgent Care (NHS 111) Market Engagement
Description:
South East London CCGs are keen to test the potential provider market for the Provision of Integrated Urgent Care.

The services currently expected to fall within the urgent care pathway will include, but are not limited to, the following core services: 
•	NHS 111 
The NHS 111 Service operates within national standards across England through a local commissioned delivery model that is most appropriate for any given area. 

The NHS 111 commissioning standards will apply to the services which are the subject of this process. Further information on the NHS 111 service development can be sourced through registration at: http://www.networks.nhs.uk/nhs-networks/nhs-111-service-development.

The principal aims of the proposed NHS 111 service are to: 
o	Improve the public experience accessing urgent healthcare
o	Get people to the right service first time, including self-care where appropriate 
o	Provide the CCGs with management information regarding usage of services
o	A more streamlined patient pathway
o	A consistent model of care across South East London

Potential providers with relevant capability to deliver this service are requested to express an interest in bidding for this service should the CCGs decide to carry out a competitive tender exercise and publish a Contract Notice for this requirement.

The CCGs actively encourage smaller and new providers to attend the event. We welcome interest from collaborations of providers.

The CCGs will be holding an information event on 24th August 2017, from 9:30 to 11:30  at  Neighbourhood Room
Coin Street Community Builders
Coin Street Neighbourhood Centre
108 Stamford Street
South Bank
London SE1 9NH
which will be the second market engagement event for this procurement.  If you would like to receive an invitation to this event please send your contact details to email address below.  Depending on the responses, spaces may be limited, therefore the CCG's may apply a limit on numbers from each organisation. 

You can express an interest in this market testing exercise by sending an e-mail to nelcsu.clinical-procurement@nhs.net.  The deadline for submitting a response for this market testing exercise is at 5pm on 21st August 2017.  

Please note that this is a market testing exercise to inform the CCGs' decision making process.  This does not commit the CCGs to a carry out a procurement process.
Attachments: Directions market event.docx
Additional Text: The market event will take place on Thursday 24th of August 2017 commencing at 9:30. Please see advert for venue and booking details.

Your e-mail must include details about your organisation's technical capability and previous experience of delivering an integrated  111/OOH Service or similar services. 

Please note that this is a market testing exercise to inform the CCGs' decision making process.  This does not commit the CCGs to a carry out a procurement process.

Organisation Name: NHS Shared Business Services Ltd (NHS SBS)
Title: Provision of GP Out of Hours (GP OOH) Integrated Urgent Care Services - NHS North & Mid Mersey NHS CCGs (Halton, Knowsley, Liverpool, South Sefton, Southport & Formby, St Helens, Warrington)
Description:
This procurement is for the provision of GP Out of Hours (GP OOH) Integrated Urgent Care Services for the NHS Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) in Halton, Knowsley, Liverpool, Southport & Formby, South Sefton, St Helens and Warrington. The CCGs with NHS Liverpool CCG acting as the co-ordinating or lead commissioner, have a vision for their 'out of hours' Urgent Primary Care Medical Services as part of an integrated single model of urgent care services across the whole health economy, providing a high-quality clinical service with a clear patient centred focus.
The CCGs have come together to procure a single service that will work closely alongside and integrate service delivery with the North West NHS 111 service, in line with the national expectations for an integrated 'consult & complete' delivery model.
The main aim of the service is to provide evidence based urgent primary care which optimises health and wellbeing and reduces the impact of ill health during the out of hours period, avoiding where possible the need for acute care.
The anticipated, maximum total contract value (including any potential extensions) is £82,845,310 (ex VAT).  The Contract will have an initial term of 5 years (plus an option of one extension for a further 2 years) from the commencement date of 1st October 2020.

Organisation Name: NHS Shared Business Services Ltd (NHS SBS)
Title: PROVISION OF A TIER 2 COMMUNITY DERMATOLOOGY SERVICE ON BEHALF OF NHS BLACKPOOL Clinical Commissioning Group AND NHS FYLDE & WYRE Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG)
Description:
NHS Blackpool CCG and NHS Fylde & Wyre CCG (NHS Fylde and Wyre acting as Llead Ccommissioners, Blackpool CCG as Associate Commissioner) wish to invite suitably qualified and experienced providers to submit tenders for a new Tier 2 Community Dermatology Service which will achieve the following outcomes:
•	Equitable access and treatment of dermatology patients presenting with dermatological problems within different levels of deprivation.
•	Increased overall patient's satisfaction with Dermatology Services.
•	Provider services closer to patients' home.
•	Improved communication between community, secondary and primary care services provider, specialist clinicians and Primary care.
•	Improved quality of care within primary and community settings regardless of provider.
•	Increased patient choice.
•	Improved access to advice and information, increased knowledge and awareness of the management of dermatology for patients.
•	Reduced waiting time for patient's access to specialist care in the community.
•	Improve access to advice and information with increased knowledge and awareness of the self-management of their condition. 
The contract duration will be for 3 years, which is intended to run from 1st of November 2018 until 31st October September 2021 with the possibility of one extension of up to 2 years. The anticipated, maximum total contract value (including any potential extensions) is £3,605,441 with an annual value estimated at £ 721,088.
The Services to which this Procurement relates fall within the scope of Schedule 3 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (the "Regulations"). 
As such, the procurement of the Services is being run as a bespoke, single-stage application process akin to the Open Procedure. 
This opportunity is also advertised on the Official Journal of the European Union.
Interested Providers, intending to participate in the procurement process are now invited to register their interest and access the procurement documents (Qualification Questionnaire, Service Specification, Bidder Instructions etc.) via the electronic procurement portal EU-Supply available at https://nhssbs.eu-supply.com.

Attached to this notice is a guide to using EU Supply. If you need technical support on the EU-Supply Portal, please contact the EU-Supply Helpdesk on 0800 840 2050 or support@eu-supply.com

Organisation Name: NHS Shared Business Services Ltd (NHS SBS)
Title: THE PROVISION OF A TIER 2 COMMUNITY OPHTHALMOLOGY SERVICE - NHS Blackpool CCG and NHS Fylde & Wyre Clinical Commissioning Group
Description:
NHS Blackpool Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) and NHS Fylde & Wyre CCG (NHS Fylde and Wyre CCG acting as Lead Commissioners and Blackpool CCG as Associate Commissioner) wish to invite suitably qualified and experienced providers to submit tenders for a new Tier 2 Community Ophthalmology Service which will achieve the following outcomes:
• Appropriately clinically triage referrals made to Ophthalmology Services and ensure that the service user is referred onto the appropriate service. 
•Deliver community-based Ophthalmology Services for a defined range of eye problems.  
•To provide targeted assessment and follow ups and co-management of specific chronic eye conditions within the community against an agreed set of protocols.
•To demonstrate improved service user experience, quality of life and improved access for service users.
•To deliver high quality eye care to service users registered with Blackpool and Fylde and Wyre GPs.
•Ensure that referring GP's are given prompt and full information about their patient's diagnosis or treatment in line with national standards. 
•To achieve a fundamental shift of care from the acute providers into the community so the service users can access effective and high quality services closer to home.
•To provide service users with a choice for the management of the specific eye conditions included in the specification.  
•Ensure that all eligible patients are managed through the service. 
•Reduce pressure on the hospital eye service by delivering eye care outside the hospital where at all possible and ensuring that those that are referred are appropriate and fully worked up.
The contract duration will be for 3 years, which is intended to run from 1st of October 2018 until 30th September 2021 with the possibility of one extension of up to 2 years. The anticipated, maximum total contract value (including any potential extensions) is £2,339,946 with an annual value estimated at £467,989.
The Services to which this Procurement relates fall within the scope of Schedule 3 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015.
As such, the procurement of the Services is being run as a bespoke, single-stage application process akin to the Open Procedure. This procurement opportunity is also advertised on the OJEU.

Organisation Name: East Of England NHS Collaborative Hub
Title: Independent Investigation Services for the NHS
Description:
The NHS is required under the NHS Serious Incident Framework/Patient Safety Framework (and/or any iterations) and the Department of Health Article 2 of the European Convention on Human Rights and the investigation of serious incidents to commission an independent investigation.

The NHS has created a Framework for Independent Investigation Services that meets the technical and geographic requirements for the NHS. This framework agreement provides a flexible and responsive framework to enable the NHS to comply with the NHS Serious Incident Framework.

The framework Agreement is split into five lots:

Lot 1 - Independent Expert Investigations
Lot 2 - Partnership Investigations
Lot 3 - Local Care System Investigations
Lot 4 - Health & Social Care & Partners Investigations
Lot 5 - Systematic Independent Investigations
Bidders will continue to have the opportunity to apply to join the Framework Agreement on an annual basis.

It is anticipated that applications will be accepted on the following dates:

May 2020 - For commencement of contract on 01 November 2020
May 2021 - For commencement of contract on 01 November 2021
May 2022 - For commencement of contract on 01 November 2022
May 2023 - For commencement of contract on 01 November 2023
May 2024 - For commencement of contract on 01 November 2024 (dependent on extension of Framework Agreement)
May 2025 - For commencement of contract on 01 November 2025 (dependent on extension of Framework Agreement)

The Services to which this Procurement relates fall within Schedule 3 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (the "Regulations"). As such, the procurement of the Services has been run as a bespoke, Open Process Procedure, involving the completion of a Qualification Questionnaire to qualify for acceptance onto the Framework Agreement. Successful bidders will be asked to participate in Mini Competitions for contracts for lots in which they have been successful or may be subject to the direct award of a contract.

Attain has conducted this procurement exercise as agent for and on behalf of the Contracting Authority (the NHS) and in partnership with East of England Collaborative Procurement Hub (EoECPH). 

The contract will be for an initial 48 months (indicative contract value for 48 months is £10,000,000 GBP), with the option to extend for a further 24 months (indicative contract value for 60 months is £15,000,000 GBP).
Contact Address 1: The NHS Commissioning Board, Skipton House, 80 London Road

Title: The Supply of Architect Services
Description:
NHS Property Service (NHS PS) is a NHS-owned organisation that provides procurement and property support to its member organisations and other customers across the NHS.

NHS PS is a member of NHS Commercial Alliance, a partnership with NHS East of England Collaborative Procurement Hub, and also of the NHS Collaborative Procurement Partnership, an arrangement between the four NHS collaborative procurement organisations. To enable organisations to obtain property architecture and design services, NHS PS is procuring a framework agreement to which a number of service providers will be appointed. Although principally intended as a procurement vehicle for NHS organisations in England, the framework agreement will be available to all public sector organisations in the United Kingdom.

This procurement is being managed by Proxima Group on behalf of the NHS Property Service (NHS PS).

The framework agreement is intended to facilitate the provision of Architecture Services in relation to the development of an estates strategy, the design and planning of new buildings and the adaptation/extension of existing facilities, and the overall management of the estate. The framework agreement is not intended to specifically provide for the services of any of the following construction-related experts: project managers; building surveyors; quantity surveyors; building services engineers; structural engineers; or CDM co-ordinators except where they may perform duties in relation to the services.

The contract term is three years, with the option to extend at the NHS PS discretion for an additional 12 months (four years in total).

The Framework is broken into five lots: Lot 1- North West, Lot 2 North East Central, Lot 3 - West Midlands East, Lot 4 - South West, Lot 5 - South East

Please refer to Section V: Award of contract for information relating to the awarded group of contractors.

The initial estimated total value of the contract is £50,000,000.00 GBP which has been averagely proportioned across each of the five lots.

Title: The Provision of Any Qualified Provider (AQP) for MRI and NOUS Services for NHS Wandsworth & NHS Merton CCG
Description:
NHS Wandsworth Clinical Commissioning Group and NHS Merton Clinical Commissioning Group are undertaking a joint AQP procurement to optimise existing contractual arrangements for diagnostic services. A key output would be enhancement of clinical activity by reducing and/or increasing clinical thresholds, possible increase of diagnostic modalities and geographical coverage through Merton and Wandsworth AQP procurement.

This Direct Access MRI and NOUS services will aid early diagnostics and avoid the need for unnecessary referral to secondary care. It will ensure a local service with staff qualified to appropriate levels of skill and experience, using equipment which complies with the most up-to-date guidance set by the Royal College of Radiologists, connection to NHS image transfer solutions, the ability to integrate with the e-Referral system, robust performance management systems and stringent levels of clinical governance.

Title: Provision of a Faculty Framework -  NHS Leadership Academy, Health Education England - NHS/SoEPS/18.412 PRIOR INFORMATION NOTICE
Description:
**Please note that the anticipated approach to market date, with the ITT open for submission, is now 05 October 2018**

NHS South of England Procurement Services, acting on behalf of NHS Leadership Academy (the Commissioner) will be commencing a tender for the Provision of a Faculty Framework. The key aim of this tender process is to put in place a faculty framework  of highly expert practitioners, attuned to the needs of leaders in the health and public sector, embracing the best of what we know about effective leadership and leadership development, who have values congruent with the NHS Constitution.  The faculty should be representative of the participants we work with and the communities we serve, reflecting the importance we place on inclusive leadership.

It is the intention of the commissioner that the procurement will be conducted as a Schedule 3 Service using the  Light Touch Regime under the Public Contracts Regulations 2015. The ITT is expected to be published in early October 2018 with establishment of a Framework by February 2019. 

All contracts issued to providers to become members of this Framework will be zero value guaranteed.

A separate advert will be released advising when the procurement is live for submissions, at which time all documentation in relation to this procurement will become available. 

The commissioner reserves the right not to proceed with the Procurement, or any part thereof, or change the requirements and timescales as necessary at any time.
