Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH OF ENGLAND PROCUREMENT SERVICES
Title: e-portfolio for NHS Dental Foundation Training & Dental Core Training - NHS/SoEPS/ 18.441
Description:
**Please be advised that the submission deadline date has been extended to 05 September 2018 at 12 noon**

NHS South of England Procurement Services (SoEPS), acting on behalf of Health Education England (the Commissioner) is commencing a tender for the provision of e-portfolios for NHS Dental Foundation Training and Dental Core Training.

Both NHS Dental training programmes are currently using (different) e-portfolios. Through this procurement we intend to unite the programmes and their approximately 2,000 trainees (plus trainers and administrators) onto one e-portfolio platform that fits our specification as closely as
possible. As this procurement is for an off-the-shelf e-portfolio system rather than a bespoke commission, we fully appreciate that not all of our high priority requirements may be available in one system and that there will inevitably need to be an element of compromise involved in the selection and implementation of the system. Nonetheless, we intend to be guided in our decision-making by the extent to which systems can meet our highest priority user needs.

The maximum value of this contract is £249,000. This figure is exclusive of any applicable VAT.

HEE would like to invite potential service providers to respond to this Invitation to Tender (ITT) for the provision as set out in the service specification and this document sets out the requirements and the criteria to be used in the evaluation.

Please access the ITT documentation at https://intendhost.co.uk/soepscommissioning  for further information.
Attachments: Instructions for Registering on the SoEPS Commissioning Support In-tend Portal.pdf
Additional Text:
Bidders are invited to access the procurement documentation at https://intendhost.co.uk/soepscommissioning. The deadline for submission of completed ITT responses is Wednesday 5th September 2018 at 12:00pm. (midday). The e-portal system will shutdown at 12:00pm and any unsubmitted bids not registered to the system at this time will not be accepted. 

Therefore, please submit in good time prior to the deadline date and time. Should Bidders have any queries, or are having problems using the portal, they should contact the In-tend dedicated Supplier Helpdesk by calling 0845 557 8079 Monday to Friday (9am to 6pm) or email support@in-tend.co.uk. 

During the tender exercise the Contracting Authority requests that all communications are channelled through the e-portal system via the appointed procurement specialist on behalf of NHS
South of England Procurement Services and not with the Contracting Authority itself. No Bidder, Bidder Member, or any of such Bidder's advisors, consultants or subcontractors may have ex parte communications with the Contracting Authority or any of their employees, advisors, contractors or
consultants regarding the ITT, the Procurement, other than as expressly permitted in this ITT.

Title: Dermatology Services for NHS Telford and Wrekin CCG and NHS Shropshire CCG
Description:
This Invitation to Tender provides information pertaining to the procurement for Dermatology Services. The purpose of this procurement is to secure a Service Provider to deliver Dermatology Services to the county of Shropshire (comprising 2 CCGs).

- Telford & Wrekin Clinical Commissioning Group (http://www.telfordccg.nhs.uk )
- Shropshire Clinical Commissioning Group (http://www.shropshireccg.nhs.uk )

It is the intention that the community dermatology provision will support the patients and General practitioners of both Telford and Wrekin CCG and Shropshire CCG by making available an effective community dermatology service; reduce waiting times and increase access for patients whilst providing value for money.

The consultant-led dermatology service will provide assessment and treatment for skin disorders and will focus not just on treating skin disorders, but also on raising awareness and understanding of the importance of long term skin care and the prevention of skin disease, in particular skin cancer.

The service will include some activity but not limited to:
- Phototherapy Dynamic Therapy
- PUVA
- Patch Testing
- Hyperhydrosis
- Those surgical procedures which cannot be undertaken within primary care
- Low risk Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC)
- Skin conditions requiring medication normally prescribed only in secondary care, such as retinoids, disease modifying agents, biologicals/biosimilars and all drugs with NICE Technical Appraisals.

The CCG's are looking to appoint a Service Provider or Consortium to deliver this Service for a period of 3 Years with an optional 2 Years extension available.

The successful Provider will be required to sign the NHS Standard Contract for the service and accept all terms and conditions.
Contact Address 1: NHS Telford & Wrekin Clinical Commissioning Group, Halesfield 6, Halesfield

Title: High Intensity User Service NHS/SOEPS/21.825 ITT
Description:
Invitation to Tender (ITT)
Urgent Care 
Provision of a High Intensity User Service (Reference: NHS/SOEPS/21.825 ITT)
NHS Brighton and Hove Clinical Commissioning Group
NHS East Sussex Clinical Commissioning Group

The Commissioner is seeking bids from suitably qualified Providers for provision of a High Intensity User Service, offering patients with high attendance at Emergency Departments psychosocial support, crisis planning, sign-posting in the community and support to use more appropriate services for their psychosocial needs. The service is to be situated in both Brighton and Hove and East Sussex and delivered under the standard NHS Contract. The anticipated value of the Service is a maximum of £343,952.00 per annum and the contract duration will be 3 years from 28th September 2022, plus an optional (option of the Commissioner) extension period of up to a further 24 months.

Key Aims and Objectives of the Service
The High Intensity User Service (HIUS) is based on the 'Blackpool model' developed by Blackpool CCG, as published in the Commissioning for Value Casebook, February 2015.  
The model offers a robust way of reducing HIU activity to EDs, 999, NHS 111, Primary Care services as well as unscheduled hospital admissions. The HIU service liberates front line resources to focus on those who need it most and helps reduce costs.  
The objective of the service is to work closely with identified frequent users of emergency urgent departments, with an aim to reduce unheralded attendances at ED and associated non-elective (NEL) admissions, whilst improving the service user's quality of life and outcomes.  
This will be delivered by:
•	Identifying patients who frequently attend ED and associated non-elective (NEL) admissions
•	Identifying patients who are evidentially on a trajectory to becoming a high intensity user of emergency services
•	Proactively connecting and engaging with the patient
•	Supporting the patient to manage their needs using a personalised approach.

Title: NHS App
Description:
The NHS App was announced by the Secretary of State for Health at Expo 2017. It was launched in January 2019 and provides a simple and secure way for people to access a range of NHS services on their mobile device or computer. The NHS App is currently available for download in both the Apple and Google Play stores and is also available to access from a browser via a desktop or laptop computer.
The NHS's Long-Term Plan objectives state that the NHS App will create a standard online way for people to access the NHS and that the app will work seamlessly with other services at national and local levels and, where appropriate, be integrated into patient pathways.
The NHS App seeks to empower patients by giving them access to core NHS transaction services and visibility of their records.

Title: The Provision of a Laboratories Managed Service on behalf of NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde
Description:
NHS Shared Business Services (NHS SBS) are acting on behalf of NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde, to obtain a Contractor for The Provision of a Laboratories Managed Service. NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde (NHS GG&C) require a Provider/Contractor to provide a Managed Laboratory Service  for the large majority of analyses performed within the NHS GG&C Laboratory Medicine Department across the full range of laboratory specialties. The maximum affordability limit for the total Contract (including any potential extensions and VAT) is £447,936,000 and the Contract will be for the duration of a 7 year initial period with either the option to extend for 2 further periods of 7 years and 2 years or a single further period of 2 years only, with a service commencement date of 12th September 2023. NHS GG&C is the largest of 14 territorial NHS Boards in Scotland. It serves a population of 1.2 million and employs circa 39,000 staff.  Therefore it is essential that the proposed solution to provide the Managed Service is customised to the operational and clinical requirements of all Departments.  The individual requirements for the Procurement are:-
- A - General - includes Board IT Requirements
- B - Biochemistry & Immunology - includes electrophoresis & POCT
- C - Haematology and H&I - includes electrophoresis & POCT
- D - Genetics
- E - Pathology
- F - Microbiology, Virology and Reference Laboratories - includes POCT
- G - Blood / Urine / Fluid Collection Systems
- H - Ultra Low Freezers/Incubators/Centrifuges/Gases
It is anticipated that the proposed solution will provide new equipment and therefore any costs related to this should be costed within the submission. Further information on the full services required can be found within the Tender pack and Providers wishing to express an interest in participating in this Invitation to Tender (ITT) should register their interest on www.publiccontractsscotland.gov.uk to access the documentation required to provide the Service. The ITT documentation should be completed and submitted by 5pm on 20th May 2022. A PIN notice has been advertised using the below references:-
ocds-h6vhtk-02e9d8
FTS 025194-2021
To view a copy of the PIN, please use the PIN link here: https://www.publiccontractsscotland.gov.uk/search/show/search_view.aspx?ID=OCT430003
Contact Address 1: NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde, Procurement Department, Glasgow Royal Infirmary, 84 Castle Street

After consideration of the most recent clarification question and previous questions, NHS GG&C have carefully considered a number of different submission options to ensure the least impact and inconvenience for Suppliers regarding the size limits of Bid submissions.  
Therefore, bid submissions are required to be submitted slightly differently than as described in the Bidder Instructions.  
To ensure size limitations are mitigated, all Bid responses must be provided on a word document, containing a link to a Secure File Transfer, which should be uploaded to the PCS website. The word document should contain the name of the Supplier and third parties with a direct clickable link to the secure file transfer location. It is NHS GG&Cs preference that no password is used, however, if a password is required, then this should also be included within the Word document. It is the responsibility of the Supplier to ensure that the Link works and is accessible to NHS GG&C. Any responses received after the deadline of 3pm on 14th June 2022 will not be accepted.   
It can also be confirmed that any documents or bid submissions with time stamps after this deadline will be disqualified and Suppliers will be excluded from the Procurement process. NHS SBS on behalf of NHS GG&C will review time stamps when completing the tender download following the tender deadline.  
For the avoidance of doubt this decision has been taken to ensure the least detrimental impact on suppliers and to ensure fairness, non-bias, transparency and equality.

Title: NHS Flex for the Future Evaluation
Description:
This is a requirement for an external evaluation process for NHS Flex for the Future, a modular programme being delivered by the NHS England and NHS Improvement (NHSE&I) national Flexible Working team in partnership with Timewise.  The programme commences on 30th September 2021.  93 NHS organisations have applied to take part, with some working across a complete ICS.

Our aim with this programme is to draw on the collective knowledge and experience of NHSE&I and Timewise to provide NHS organisations with a step-by-step programme to create their own local action plan to deliver more flexible working opportunities in all roles, meeting the People Plan commitments. 

We wish to procure a further evaluation, by an independent organisation, focusing on the value for money in terms of the impact of the programme particularly in supporting organisations to address the changes needed to engage with and improve access to flexible working including: 
•	How would they rate their progress as an organisation at achieving the change they need to fully support the commitments to flexible working in the People Plan?
•	Did they achieve the outcomes identified above in the information about the programme
•	What was particularly useful about the programme / what was less useful?
•	Were the experiences/ outcomes of those attending as an ICS different from those of individual organisations and what learning is there about this for future cohorts and the design of the programme?
•	Do the organisations feel that they would have got to the point they are at with flexible working in their organisation without being part of this programme? Why? Why not?
•	What did they value about the programme and how could the programme could be improved? This needs to include the taught programme sessions, the materials provided, the drop-ins and the overall structure in the context of the support it provided to change teams on the ground
•	What advice would they give to future cohorts?
•	What recommendations can be drawn from the evaluation in order to support organisations and ensure value for money for NHS England & NHS Improvement and the NHS?

Title: Health and Wellbeing SMS helpline NHS staff crisis support
Description:
Description of the Requirement
The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need of establishing a suitable health and wellbeing offer for all our staff.  As a result, we have operated a 24/7 national text helpline since April 2020, to support our NHS staff who are under enormous pressure every day. 

Common themes have emerged in the past year and we want to continue supporting our staff with the below, but are not limited to:
•	COVID-19 
•	Anxiety/Stress 
•	Depression/Sadness 
•	Isolation/Loneliness 
•	Relationships 
•	Suicide 

The requirement is for an SMS based helpline, to continue to provide a psychological support offer for all NHS staff. This service will be provided for all staff during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, and beyond.

The text service will offer NHS staff the opportunity to converse with trained crisis support workers, and if required will have access to qualified clinical support where needed. The requirement will be to run a 24/7 service, that can operate nationally, and is able to cater to all age groups and demographics. A 24/7 service is essential, crisis support late at night is a key requirement.

Additionally, the supplier should be able to provide anonymized and vital data, to the commissioning organisation, based on text conversations, in order to provide further understanding of emerging concerns and issues related to mental health among our workforce. Finally, the supplier should be able to provide some expertise in supporting communications and marketing, to raise awareness of the helpline. 

Description of Deliverables
-	24/7 SMS based crisis helpline, able to be setup and delivered nationally, to all ages of NHS staff, with clinical oversight, providing immediate (in the moment), anonymous and confidential support for any NHS staff member requiring mental health or crisis support at any time
-	Regular service data and statistics reporting, including identifying current/emerging themes on the helpline
-	Regular service review meetings with commissioning organisation to support delivery of the service
-	Regular marketing consultancy support
-	Marketing content packages to promote the helpline
-	Agreement to work with NHS England and Improvement on any deep dive or evaluation activities relating to the helpline


Pre-market Engagement
NHS England & Improvement are currently undertaking an options appraisal and as part of this have issued a Notice to the market to gauge supplier interest and capability in relation to delivering this service.

Current thinking is that NHS England & Improvement will enter into a 1-year contract with an approximate total value of £90,000 exclusive of applicable VAT.

REGISTER YOUR INTEREST BY 01/07/21
Interested suppliers should read the details attached to the notice which specify further details about the requirement, how to register an interest in the possible procurement and the submission requirements for registering an interest.

Organisation Name: NHS Arden and Greater East Midlands Commissioning Support Unit
Title: NHS Derby and Derbyshire CCG Integrated Community Equiment Service (DICES)
Description:
This procurement is being managed in 2 Lots
Lot 1 - NHS Derby and Derbyshire CCG Integrated Community Equipment Services
Lot 2 - NHS Derby and Derbyshire CCG All Age Consumables Service

Bidders may bid for 1 or both lots.

Lot 1 - Derby Integrated Community Equipment Service provides a range of equipment on loan to people of all ages ordinarily resident in the city of Derby, following assessment and prescription by a recognized prescriber. It is a partnership service, commissioned jointly by NHS Derby and Derbyshire CCG and Derby City Council, with a pool of prescribers drawn principally from Derby City Council, University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust, Derbyshire Community Health Services NHS Foundation Trust and Derbyshire Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust. The partners are represented on a Partnership Board, which meets quarterly to provide oversight and strategic direction to the Service. An Operational Managers Groups reports into the Partnership Board and is responsible for ensuring that Board decisions are implemented effectively by all partners, and resolving any operational issues.
The service being commissioned is non-clinical and relates purely to the logistics of supplying, collecting and maintaining the equipment. Clinical input to the service is provided through the pool of recognized prescribers, a clinical commissioning function provided by NHS Derby and Derbyshire CCG, and a multi-agency Equipment Review Group, which meets quarterly to consider changes to the range of equipment provided. The provider will work within this framework, ensuring that the agreed clinical governance arrangements, both for individual items of equipment and strategic decisions about the equipment to be provided/policies and procedures for equipment provision, are followed appropriately.

Lot 2 - NHS Derby and Derbyshire Clinical Commissioning Group wish to appoint a provider to manage the logistical arrangements for providing medical equipment and consumables for patients living in the community. Supporting patients of all ages to be independent and looked after in their communities, rather than in residential or acute medical settings is a key priority for Joined Up Care Derbyshire, the STP for the Derby and Derbyshire footprint.

Organisation Name: NHS Arden and Greater East Midlands Commissioning Support Unit
Title: NHS East Kent CCG Urgent Treatment Centres
Description:
NHS Arden and Greater East Midlands CSU (AGCSU) on behalf of The East Kent CCGs (NHS Ashford CCG, NHS Canterbury and Coastal CCG, NHS South Kent Coast CCG and NHS Thanet CCG) (referred to as the Commissioner(s)) are inviting suitably qualified and experienced providers to deliver the service(s).

The NHS Long Term Plan explains the need to redesign health systems, including the urgent and emergency care services in England for people of all ages. It states that across the NHS, urgent and emergency care services will be redesigned to integrate between Emergency Departments (ED), traditional GP out-of-hours services, urgent care centres (UCC), NHS 111, and ambulance services; highlighting the fact that 'services need to be integrated around the patient in the context of developing Primary Care Networks (PCNs).

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Digitisation of Lloyd George medical records for GP practices across NHS Lancashire and South Cumbria ICS
Description:
Lancashire & South Cumbria Integrated Care System have been part of the national NHSX teams Acceleration Programme in which they have secured funding to enable Morcambe Bay Clinical Commissioning Group to fully digitise their Lloyd George medical records. This is in accordance with the General Medical Services Contract Reform 2019 to digitise all Lloyd George records in a phased approach across the Integrated Care System
footprint by 2023. 

Morecambe Bay has funding to fully digitise their Lloyd George medical records to a cloud solution which will not only create efficiencies within General Practice but free up much needed space within the practice. Morcambe Bay Clinical Commissioning Group covers 33 GP Practices with a typical practice size of circa 7,200 patients. 

This procurement for Morecambe Bay Clinical Commissioning Group is part of a larger digitisation programme and the first of 5 phases covering the 5 Integrated Care Providers for Lancashire & South Cumbria. There will be potential, where funding becomes available, to roll out to the rest of Lancashire & South Cumbria. This includes a further 200 practices across 4 Trusts and 7 Clinical Commissioning Groups totalling circa 1.3 million records. 

Lancashire & South Cumbria Integrated Care System are leading the procurement on behalf of Clinical Commissioning Groups and Integrated Care Partnerships in Lancashire & South Cumbria. Participating Clinical Commissioning Groups and Integrated Care Partnerships include:
NHS Morecambe Bay CCG
NHS Greater Preston Clinical Commissioning Group
NHS Chorley and South Ribble Clinical Commissioning Group
NHS Blackburn with Darwen Clinical Commissioning Group
NHS East Lancashire Clinical Commissioning Group
NHS Blackpool Clinical Commissioning Group
NHS Fylde and Wyre Clinical Commissioning Group
NHS West Lancashire Clinical Commissioning Group
Additional Text:
Interested providers will be able to view this notice via the 'current tenders' list on the e-procurement system In-Tend, available on the following link: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/scwcsu/aspx/Home

In order to submit a bid, you will need to be registered on the e-procurement system and 'express an interest', and then complete a response as specified within the procurement documents.

On registration, please include at least two contacts to allow for access to the system in times of absence. 

The services are deemed to be subject to the full regime of current EU procurement legislation and as such this tender will be conducted in accordance with, and governed by, the Public Contracts Regulations 2015. This contract will therefore be awarded in accordance with the provisions applicable in Section 5 (sub-section 7) of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015.

The contracting authority intends to observe the provisions and 10 day standstill period described in the Public Contracts Regulations 2015. Unsuccessful Bidders and applicants will receive scores and reasons for the decision, including the characteristics and relative advantages of the winning bid and the reasons why the Bidder/applicant was unsuccessful. Deadlines for lodging appeals should be in accordance with the Regulations.

Description:
NHS Arden and Greater East Midlands CSU (AGCSU) on behalf of The East Kent CCGs (NHS Ashford CCG, NHS Canterbury and Coastal CCG, NHS South Kent Coast CCG and NHS Thanet CCG) (referred to as the Commissioner(s)) are inviting suitably qualified and experienced providers to deliver the service(s).

The NHS Long Term Plan explains the need to redesign health systems, including the urgent and emergency care services in England for people of all ages. It states that across the NHS, urgent and emergency care services will be redesigned to integrate between Emergency Departments (ED), traditional GP out-of-hours services, urgent care centres (UCC), NHS 111, and ambulance services; highlighting the fact that 'services need to be integrated around the patient in the context of developing Primary Care Networks (PCNs).

Organisation Name: NHS Arden and Greater East Midlands Commissioning Support Unit
Title: NHS England Commissioning of Specialised Services for Women with Complications of Mesh inserted for Urinary Incontinence and vaginal prolapse
Description:
NHS Arden and Greater East Midlands CSU (AGCSU) on behalf of NHS England Specialised Commissioning (referred to as the Commissioner(s)) is inviting suitably qualified and experienced providers to deliver the specialised services for women with complications of mesh inserted for urinary incontinence and vaginal prolapse. 
NHS England (National) Specialised Commissioning (Specialised Services) will be the contracting and commissioning authority.

The aim of the procurement is to commission specialised services for women with complications of mesh inserted for urinary incontinence and vaginal prolapse for NHS England patients across the geographical areas of England in the UK. 
NHS England will be seeking to appoint contracts for up to 7 (seven) centres in 7 (seven) LOTS as advertised as part of a multi-lot procurement: 

Lot 1	North East and Yorkshire 
Lot 2	North West 
Lot 3	East of England 
Lot 4	London 
Lot 5	Midlands 
Lot 6	South East 
Lot 7	South West 

The objectives of the procurement for this service are to: 
•	Fully implement the scope and aim of the service described in the final Service Specification; 
•	Ensure that appointed providers have the capacity and capability to provide the quality and patient outcomes for the service required as commissioned by NHS England; 
•	Provide appropriate access for NHS England patients, provide assessment and, where required, surgery; 
•	Mobilise services to assess patients waiting for review, provide consultation, treatment and aftercare. 
•	To develop a clinical network of centres delivering services to patients nationally in regional geographies.

This opportunity will be published in the Official Journal for European Union (OJEU) and Contracts Finder (UK.gov) websites. All documentation describing and outlining information relating to this procurement can be found published with the invitation to tender response forms in the EUsupply eTender/Procurement portal. All communications regarding this opportunity will be managed via the EUsupply messaging service. 

All professional and/or trade registration requirements are specified within the tender documentation. To register, please visit https://uk.eu-supply.com/login.asp?B=UK 

Quote/tender reference: 36290 - NHS England Commissioning of Specialised Services for Women with Complications of Mesh inserted for Urinary Incontinence and Vaginal Prolapse. 

Should you need to contact the EU Supply Helpdesk regarding system operations, details are as follows: 

The EU Supply Helpdesk telephone number is 0800 840 2050, during office hours only (08:00 to 17:00).  

Emails can be sent to uksupport@eu-supply.com at any time of the day but responses will only be sent between 08:00 and 17:00 weekdays.

The AGCSU EU Supply e-tendering portal is available 24/7.

Title: *AMENDED NOTICE*  NHS Bradford, Calderdale, Greater Huddersfield, North Kirklees & Wakefield CCG's: Information Technology and Networking Services
Description:
NHS Calderdale CCG (as primary contract holder) on behalf of - (Calderdale, Greater Huddersfield, North Kirklees and Wakefield) and NHS Bradford District CCG (as primary contract holder) on behalf of - (Bradford City, Bradford District and Airedale, Wharfedale and Craven CCG's) intend to commission a range of information technology services for the 7 CCG's and their GP practices in two separate contractual arrangements, with an expectation of a single lead provider. 

The service is anticipated to need a range of flexibility in terms of scope to meet the developing technological maturity of the NHS and changing requirements of the General practice landscape over the life of the contact.  It is anticipated that the supplier will hold a contract for up to 7 and 8 years, and include General IT supporting functions of a comprehensive range of services and support innovation and transformation to meet a defined set of outcomes and performance measures.  

The services to be provided will include (among others):
1.	Services for Clinical commissioning Groups headquarter corporate functions 
2.	Services for General Practice clinical 

And will need to include Service desk, desktop management, infrastructure, server, Network services and management and cyber security services, NHS Registration card service provision and Email services and NHSMail management, Data storage, a range of innovation and development services, software web developments and project management, business change and clinical training services 

The contract and winning bids will be partially determined through the process being undertaken.  The value should be treated as essentially near approximation.

The purpose of this PIN is to initiate market engagement and is not being used as a call for competition.

The PIN is intended to:
Inform the market of the potential future procurement process for IT services in the described CCGs areas above to therefore enable the market to begin to plan for this.

It is expected that the contract will be awarded to a single lead provider for the entirety of the service provision.

Contract details
Start Date: 
NHS Calderdale CCG - 1 April 2019
NHS Bradford CCG - 1 April 2020

Contract Values:
NHS Calderdale CCG - Circa £16.5 Million over the 8 years contract life.
NHS Bradford District CCG - Circa £8.8 Million over the 7 years contract life

Organisation Name: NHS Midlands and Lancashire Commissioning Support Unit
Title: NHS Halton CCG - GP Access Fund (GP Extra)
Description:
NHS Halton CCG - GP Access Fund (GP Extra)

NHS Midlands and Lancashire Commissioning Support Unit (CSU) is working on behalf of NHS Halton CCG for a GP Access Fund for patients living in the Borough.

NHS England has introduced a new initiative called "GP Access Fund" with the aim that no patient should have to attend A&E as a walk-in patient as a result of being unable to get an appointment with a GP. NHS Halton CCG is looking for a provider of Primary Care services as part of NHS England's initiative. NHS England have developed 7 core national requirements for the delivery of the Access Fund in order to bring parity to the Access Fund offer across the country and these requirements are:

• Timing of Appointments
• Capacity
• Measurement
• Advertising and ease of access
• Digital
• Inequalities
• Effective Access to wider whole-system services

This service will be accessible by all of the patients of the 14 GP practices that are covered by NHS Halton CCG. The GP Access Fund Services will improve access and experience for patients by providing additional capacity for pre-bookable and also urgent on the day appointments, which are more convenient for patients and offer shorter waits, both during and outside traditional general practice hours. These appointments will be evening appointments from Monday to Friday between the hours of 18:30 and 21:00 and also during Saturdays and Sundays from 09:00 to 15:00.

Potential suppliers should be aware that clarifications to the documents should be submitted before 12pm on Friday 17th August 2018 and Selection Questionnaires should be submitted before 12pm on Friday 24th August 2018.

There will be an initial contract period of 1 year commencing on 1st April 2019.  There will be the option to extend for a further 1-year period. The contract value is set at £1.444M over the entire 2-year contract period.

Submission of the Selection Questionnaire and procurement specific information: this exercise will be conducted on the Midlands and Lancashire CSU portal at https://mlcsu.bravosolution.co.uk

Candidates wishing to be considered must register their expression of interest & provide additional procurement-specific information (by registering on the Bravo portal). Candidates should register on the portal at https://mlcsu.bravosolution.co.uk (registration and use of the website is free of charge). If your organisation has registered previously, you do not need to re-register.

For technical support in submitting your expression of interest contact the Bravo Solution Help-desk on 0800 368 4850 or E-mail: help@bravosolution.co.uk.
Contact Address 1: c/o NHS Halton CCG, 1st Floor Town Hall
Attachments: Annex_2_GPAF_DRAFT Service Specification.docx Annex_3_GPAF_Blank_APMS_Agreement.docx

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: NHS England South West - Provision of Dental Services in Southmead, Bristol
Description:
AWARD NOTICE - Due to the termination of an NHS contract, NHS England South West (the Commissioner) sought to recommission dental services for the delivery of 8,800 Units of Dental Activity (UDAs) for patients living in and around the Southmead area of Bristol. The procurement was carried out by NHS South, Central & West Commissioning Support Unit (SCW) on behalf of the Commissioners.

The 8,800 UDAs are expected to provide dental services for approximately 4000 patients (based on the NHS England South West average of 2.2 UDAs per patient). 

The UDAs will be offered at a fixed price of £25.00 per UDA, which is non-negotiable.

There was an opportunity for any successful provider to operate the service from within an existing NHS property based at Southmead Health Centre, Ullswater Road, BRISTOL, Avon, BS10 6DF. Should providers have wished to operate the service from alternative premises, this had to be located within a 2 kilometre radius of BS10 6DF. 

The Commissioner will be contracting for the Services using the standard Personal Dental Services (PDS) Agreement. The Contract is offered for a 2 year period which is anticipated to commence on 1st July 2018*.

It was expected that any successful provider would be able to immediately accept new patients from contract commencement, and provide continuity of NHS dental care for those patients that have been displaced following the termination of the current service. 

The successful bidder will also be required to work closely with the NHS England Commissioning Team in order to co-ordinate and promote patient access. 

The service specification works in relation to and not instead of the NHS (General Dental Services /Personal Dental Services Contracts) Regulations 2005.

*The Commissioner anticipates services to commence on the 1st July 2018, however the final implementation plan will be confirmed and the contract start date negotiated as appropriate between the Commissioner and the successful provider during mobilisation.

Title: National Information Advice Service for NHS Continuing Healthcare
Description:
NHS England is holding a Market Engagement session on 5th September 2017 at 12 noon BST. Please confirm you attendance by emailing the enclosed address. You will then be sent joining instructions. 
NHS England wishes to appoint a suitably qualified provider, in the field of NHS Continuing Healthcare (NHS CHC). The contract will provide a national advice and information service for patients who are undergoing assessment, or have been assessed, for NHS CHC. Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) are the responsible bodies delivering NHS CHC to individuals, in accordance with the Department of Health's  National Framework for NHS CHC (including the Operating Model). A core component of the Operating Model is to provide consistency and improve the individual and family experience of NHS CHC.  
The service was launched as a pilot in 2015 and has seen an exponential growth in the number of patients and health care staff seeking advice and guidance:

• 38,000 visits to the information on the website;
• 2,200 comprehensive written guides sent out to individuals;
• 8,500 telephone consultations; and
• 1,400 written consultations (web portal and email).

The type of advice includes:

• understanding of the complex operational patient pathways; and
• detailed understanding of guidance & legislation for CHC.

Title: Getting the most from developmental reviews of leadership and governance using the well-led framework in the NHS
Description:
NHS Improvement wishes to seek views from potential suppliers about how we can maximise the benefit from developmental reviews using the well-led framework, which will be commissioned by NHS provider trusts.

BACKGROUND
In-depth, regular, and independent reviews of leadership and governance are good practice across all industries. Rather than solely assessing the current position of providers in the NHS against the well-led framework, these reviews should identify the areas of leadership and governance of organisations that would benefit from further targeted development work to secure and sustain future improvement.                  

Independent and objective assessment as part of these reviews is vital to safeguard against the optimism bias and group think to which even the best organisations may be susceptible. Our guidance therefore recommends that trusts commission an external supplier to coordinate and facilitate the reviews every 3 - 5 years.  Please see the framework guidance for more details: 
LINK https://improvement.nhs.uk/resources/well-led-framework/                                                     

Reviews are likely to take the form of commissioning consultancy firms with expertise across the eight domains of the new well-led framework, published in June 2017.  Assuming an even spread of reviews across the suggested period, there may be c.50 reviews commissioned by individual trusts per year.  

INVITATION TO CONTRIBUTE                                                   
As part of increasing the value derived from these reviews, and enhancing the knowledge sharing between providers across the NHS, we are establishing a system of peer review to support trusts in their development and preparing new guidance to promote better practice in commissioning suppliers. 

We would like to explore the questions that arise from this approach to developmental well-led reviews with a range of potential suppliers.  As a supplier, this would give you the opportunity to consider your offering to providers in the NHS in the future, consistent with the new well-led framework and the approach to peer review.

ENGAGEMENT EVENT: 
We are holding a market engagement event to discuss the questions attached to this notice. This will take place in the afternoon on WEDNESDAY 12 JULY 2017 in London. A dial in facility will be available, but in person attendance would be preferred. 

If you would like to attend, please email the names of your delegates (maximum 2 per organisation) to v.partridge@nhs.net BY 5pm on THURSDAY 6 JULY 2017; further details of the meeting will be sent to those who respond by this date.              

If you are not able to attend the meeting, you are welcome to provide written feedback to v.partridge@nhs.net by on 5pm 12 July 2017.
Attachments: NHSI_WLF_MarketEngagement_jun17.pdf
Additional Text:
NHS Improvement wishes to seek views from suppliers about how we can make sure their engagement enables maximum benefit to be derived from developmental reviews.  


The two key areas for comment are in relation to:
•	Developing new guidance that promotes better practice in commissioning suppliers to deliver effective developmental well-led reviews
•	Embedding peer review as part of the external teams to enable the sharing of experience more widely in the NHS Trust sector.

QUESTIONS TO BE CONSIDERED AT EVENT
In particular, we would like to explore the following questions regarding developmental well-led reviews:
•	What can providers in the NHS do to improve commissioning of reviews leading to improved products that will enhance supplier take-up as well as leading to lasting improvement in the NHS provider sector?  

•	What issues within specifications make it easier for suppliers to deliver an appropriate service; what has been less helpful? 

•	What is your appetite for working with peer reviewers from the NHS? 

•	How would you need to adapt your approach to make use of peer input? 

•	What needs to be considered before peer reviewers can be engaged, e.g. regarding the management of liabilities? 

•	In what ways could we harness the learning from suppliers undertaking multiple reviews?

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: NHS England South (South East) - Provision of a Diabetic Eye Screening Programme for Surrey
Description:
NHS England seek to commission a Diabetic Eye Screening Programme for the residents of Surrey. The contract will serve a population of around 1 million, of whom 52,000 are eligible individuals over the age of 12 currently identified as diabetics in need of screening. Estimates suggest that there are a further 8,000 people who may be as yet undiagnosed. Currently about 80% of people invited attend for screening.

The successful bidder will be required to deliver a screening programme which is fully compliant with all relevant national standards and pathways and which include the following elements:

•	Identification and invitation of the eligible diabetic population for screening at regular/appropriate  intervals (i.e. call/recall) in accordance with national guidance;
•	Taking and grading of digital images of service users’ eyes;
•	Provision of Digital Surveillance Clinics, clinics with Slit Lamp Biomicroscopy (SLB) assessments within the commissioned service in accordance with national guidance;
•	Referral of service users to appropriate Hospital Eye Services/Treatment Services in accordance with nationally agreed protocols and treatment pathways.

The population served by the programme will be those covered by the following 6 CCGs: NHS East Surrey, NHS Guildford and Waverley, NHS North East Hampshire and Farnham (Farnham area only), NHS North West Surrey, NHS Surrey Heath and NHS Surrey Downs.

Whilst there are no specific changes to the geographic footprint and population covered by this service anticipated at this point, the provider must be prepared to work with commissioners to implement any such alterations that do arise due to developments during the life of the contract. 

A prior information/early engagement notice was published in relation to this procurement in February 2016, seeking expressions of interest. Please note that this previous notice was an information gathering exercise rather than a call for competition in its own right. Although those who responded to that notice will be advised that this contract notice has been published, there will be no process exemptions or preferential treatment afforded to any parties who expressed an interest at that stage.

NHS England will not be liable for costs incurred by any interested party in participating in this process.

Interested parties who wish to take part in the procurement are invited to take part in an Invitation To Tender (ITT) process, based on the Open procedure, and designed to identify the Most Economically Advantageous Tender and therefore determine the incoming provider. 

Additional details/description is continued in Additional Text below.

All ITT responses must be returned by 12 Noon on 1st July 2016, at the latest.

The Services are healthcare services within the meaning and scope of Annex XIV of Directive 2014/24/EU ("the Directive") and Schedule 3 to the Public Contract Regulations 2015 ("the Regulations"). The tendering process will be conducted in accordance with the requirements and flexibilities provided by Articles 74 to 76 of the Directive, and Regulations 74 to 76 of the Regulations. For the avoidance of doubt, the Authority will not be bound by the Regulations or the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union or any other regulations or legislation except for the specific parts or circumstances that apply to the procurement of these Services. 
  
Neither the inclusion of a bidder selection stage, nor the use of any language or terms found in the Directive or Regulations, nor the description of the procedure voluntarily adopted by the Authority ("Open", "Restricted", "Competitive Procedure with Negotiation", "Competitive Dialogue" or any other description), nor any other indication, shall be taken to mean that the Authority intends to hold itself bound by the Directive or Regulations, save by the provisions applicable to services coming within the scope of Annex XIV of the Directive / Schedule 3 of the Regulations.

Title: NHS DPP (Digital Prevention Programme).
Description:
Following the launch of NHS DPP on 22.3.2016 NHS England is seeking to explore the feasibility of using a digital delivery channel to support at risk individuals to reduce their risk of Type 2 diabetes.
Following this feasibility phase NHS England may choose to take forward a procurement.
A digital prevention programme would be separate from the current NHS DPP procurement which is based on the current evidence base for face to face interventions.
We recognise that the NHS DPP will not be suitable for all and that the intensity of time commitment required on the diabetes prevention programme may limit access in certain groups (e.g. working age people / rural communities).
As such, a digital prevention programme could potentially provide an opportunity to expand access to a wider audience in a cost-effective way.
We are keen to run an open discussion workshop with providers / developers of digital behaviour change propositions and would be particularly interested with companies that have an interest in diabetes (both prevention and structured education).
We recognise that the evidence base for effectiveness of digitally delivered behaviour change is currently limited, as part of the discussion we would be particularly interested in understanding:
— Evidence on the effectiveness of digital approaches to support behaviour change;
— The demographic of individuals that would be most likely to access services through digital channels;
— How digital channels could compliment face to face services or be used as viable alternative to face to face provision;
— How outcomes including weight and blood glucose could be accurately monitored and reported as part of a digital intervention;
— How digital approaches could be implemented and scaled.

The workshop will be held on Thursday 19 May, at the Hilton London Metropole, 225 Edgware Road London W2 1JU, where we will explore these further.

Nearest Tube Stations:
•	Edgeware Road (Bakerloo) (0.1 miles)
•	Edgeware Road (Circle) (0.1 miles)
•	Marylebone (0.4 miles)

Start time - The workshop will still be held on the afternoon of Thursday 19th May 2016 (13.00-16.00).  Please note registrations will open at 12.15pm with a prompt start for 13.00. (Lunch will not be provided). 

To register your interest please e-mail the NHS England Commercial Team at nhsengland.commercial@nhs.net
Please title the e-mail sent ‘NHS DPP Workshop Expression of Interest’.

Numbers - Due to the large amount of interest in the workshop, there is a limit of 2 delegates per organisation.

Confirmation email - Following the closing date for registration, a confirmation email will be sent out to all delegates.

Questions - If you have any questions in relation to the Digital DPP, please submit these via the portal by 16.00 on Monday 9th May, 2016.

Title: NHS Leeds West CCG Patient Empowerment Program (PEP)
Description:
NHS Leeds West CCG is looking to commission an organisation to provide a social prescribing service, signposting services between GPs and Voluntary Sector Organisations. The service will be provided across all 37 practices within NHS Leeds West Clinical Commissioning Group (LWCCG) and will include self-referral. The service will have a specific focus on LWCCG areas with the highest health inequalities – increasing engagement from areas of high deprivation adopting a proportionate universalism approach. 

The service will aim to :- 
- Empower patients and communities to actively self-manage their health issues through peer support.
- Provide signposting and increase awareness, support and access about local services and voluntary groups in a managed way.
- Provide links to innovative and creative support for patients, which is rooted within patients communities and local networks, reducing isolation and ensuring people live in healthy and sustainable communities.
- To expand treatment options, providing greater choice and control for patients, empowering people with the knowledge, skills and resources to promote their own and their families wellbeing.
- Improve mental health, wellbeing and quality of life for patients, addressing the wider determinants of health.
- To encourage self-management for those with long term conditions providing right information, advice and support closer to home to allow people to live positive lives.

All provisions of this service will be expected to meet and comply with NHS standards for IT Governance, Data Protection, security of general and personal information, data and records held and processed and transmitted (via and over all mediums).

The successful provider will be required to sign the short form NHS Standard Contract for the service and accept all terms and conditions.

Potential Providers are asked to please note the Following:
•	Service specifications, Standard NHS Contract and the electronic application form can be found online at www.nhssourcing.co.uk.
•	Applications will be received until 09/05/2016 12:00
•	Applicants are advised to review the service conditions and general conditions for the NHS standard short form contract before making their applications, these can be found at the following link:
NHS England » 2016/17 NHS standard contract
•	If applicants are asked clarification questions during the evaluation stage they will have 48 hours to respond.
The contract will last for three years

Title: AQP (Any Qualified Provider) GP Direct Access Adult Hearing Service - NHS Swale CCG - NHS/SoEPS/16.276
Description:
NHS South of England Procurement Services, acting on behalf of NHS Swale Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) (the Commissioner) is commencing an AQP Offer for the provision of a GP Direct Access Adult Hearing Service for NHS Swale CCG patients. 

The aim is to provide a comprehensive service for adults experiencing hearing and communication difficulties who feel they might benefit from hearing assessment and rehabilitation including the option of trying hearing aids with aftercare and support, in line with the National Commissioning Framework, other national guidance and local requirements.

All providers of Adult Hearing Services must ensure that there are local arrangements for referral into more specialist medical services in line with British Academy of Audiology (BAA) Guidelines for Direct Referral of Adults with Hearing Difficulty to Audiology Services (2016 - currently in draft) and British Society of Hearing Aid Audiologists (BSHAA) Protocol and Criteria for Referral for Medical or other Specialist Opinion (2011).

The purpose of the Adult Hearing Service is to ensure:

•	Equitable access to high and consistent quality care for all people using the service;
•	A safe hearing service that conforms to the accreditation standards set out in the Improving Quality In Physiological Diagnostic Services (IQIPS) Accreditation Scheme;
•	The service should also recognise published clinical guidelines and good practice

The CCG will have regular performance meetings (quarterly) with accredited AQP providers to review performance of the service.  Please note that as this is an AQP there are no guaranteed or indicative volumes of activity within the contract. 

Please access the procurement documents for further information.
Attachments: Instructions_for_Registering_on_the_SoEPS_Commissioning_Support_In-tend_Portal.pdf
Additional Text:

Title: AQP (Any Qualified Provider) Direct Access Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) Service and Direct Access Non-Obstetric Ultrasound (NOUS) Service - NHS Swale CCG - NHS/SoEPS/16.296
Description:
NHS South of England Procurement Services, acting on behalf of NHS Swale Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) (the Commissioner) is commencing an AQP Offer for the provision of a Direct Access Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) Service and a Direct Access Non-Obstetric Ultrasound (NOUS) Service for NHS Swale CCG patients. 

Please note that this is a reopening of the window for new providers to apply and a reaccreditation/due diligence exercise for already accredited AQP NOUS and MRI service providers to Swale CCG.  Therefore, all providers that wish to provide the service to Swale CCG from 01 August 2017 must respond to this procurement whether they are new providers or providers already contracted with Swale CCG providing this service under AQP.

Please note that providers can apply to become qualified for MRI only services, NOUS only services or both MRI and NOUS services.

The CCG will have regular performance meetings (quarterly) with accredited AQP providers to review performance of the service.  Please note that as this is an AQP there are no guaranteed or indicative volumes of activity within the contract.

Title: Department of Health & NHS Business Services Authority - Future Operating Model for NHS Logistics Procurement, 'Home Delivery Services' - Additional Lot
Description:
The Department of Health (DH) and the NHS Business Services Authority (NHSBSA) have decided to procure the Home Delivery Services as a separate lot within the scope of the Future Operating Model for NHS procurement, supply chain and logistics services.  
'Home Delivery Services' is the logistics services for the delivery of continence products and potentially other products on behalf of the NHS Business Services Authority; to the residential homes, care homes and domestic premises. There are currently quarter of a million of users of the service in England.
DH is to hold a Market Engagement Day at Quarry House, Leeds on Monday, 27th March 2017.  The early engagement is to ascertain interest in the market for a potential 3 year term contract with two one year extension options. The prospective contract would be with a single provider. The estimated value of the contract will be £40m over 5 years The Market Engagement day will be in the form of presentations by DH explaining the FOM, HDS logistics operation, procurement process and proposed contract. It will also provide an opportunity for attendees to feedback to the DH both on the day and through follow up one-to-one engagement. To register for this event please email - fom.logistics@dh.gsi.gov.uk by Tuesday, 14th March 2017 at 12:00 noon. Places will be restricted to two attendees per organisation at this initial meeting. Please provide names of the attendees when registering.

For clarity, the original notice for an additional Lot to the FOM Logistics procurement which covered Healthy Start Vitamins Services has now been withdrawn from Contracts Finder.  This service will now be released as a separate procurement rather than an additional Lot to FOM Logistics.  Any future market engagement for this service will be managed as a stand alone activity.
Additional Text: Please note that all organizations who register an expression of interest for this event will (if they have not already done so) be required to sign a Non-Disclosure Agreement. Only organizations that have registered will be allowed entry to the Event. Organizations not attending the Market Engagement Event, but who still wish to participate in future sessions are advised to register their interest as per the instructions above, stating that they will not be attending in January.

Organisation Name: STAFFORDSHIRE AND LANCASHIRE COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: NHS Fylde & Wyre Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) and NHS Blackpool CCG - Dermatology Services
Description:
NHS Fylde & Wyre Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) and NHS Blackpool CCG are exploring their options in regard to Community Dermatology Services.  They are seeking information from interested suppliers on their views on proposed services in Fylde & Wyre / Blackpool areas.  This is likely to lead to procurement activity in the future.  Supplier contributions at this stage may affect the design of the services eventually purchased.

Suppliers are asked to send submissions to Stephen Newton, Senior Procurement Manager, NHS Midlands & Lancashire CSU by 20th August 2015 - 17:00
Attachments: FW - RFI - Dermatology.docx

Title: Veterans Mental Health Pilot Services - NHS England
Description:
NHS England commissions services for the armed forces and their families and in some circumstances services for veterans. These include prosthetics and mental health services.

In the Spring 2015 Budget, the Chancellor made available to the NHS in England additional monies for veterans mental health services to support the most vulnerable in the community.

The Forces in Mind Trust has recently undertaken research into veterans’ health needs; this has identified a number of gaps in service. NHS England is seeking Bidders to develop and pilot mental health services to address these identified gaps.

These pilot service contracts are split into 3 Lots as follows:

Lot 1 - Joint Substance Misuse and Mental Health Pilot for Veterans
Lot 2 - Severe PTSD Outpatient Service Pilot
Lot 3 - Overcoming Barriers to Mental Health Service Access for Early Service Leavers

NHS England (the Contracting Authority) expects each Contract to start before 31st October 2015 and they will run until 31st March 2016.

Each Contract/Lot will have a maximum permissible contract value of £400,000 (Ex VAT).

Bidders will not be limited in how many Lots they are able to bid for and the Contracting Authority may award multiple Lots to one Bidder (where Bidders express an interest in being awarded multiple Lots).

In light of the short term nature of the pilot contracts, the challenging timescales for mobilisation and service delivery and given the nature of the services themselves, the Contracting Authority has stipulated the following mandatory criteria for this procurement:

1) Voluntary Sector involvement - It is a mandatory requirement for Bidders to include a form of voluntary sector involvement in their service delivery proposals (see Section A questions for further details). The Authority will accept various forms of relationships including, but not limited to, Bidders who propose to subcontract services to, form a partnership with, or enter into a joint venture with, one or more charity organisations in the support of the delivery of the Services. 

2) Mental Health service providers – It is a mandatory requirement that a current provider of NHS-commissioned Mental Health services is involved in the service delivery alongside the successful provider in some capacity (i.e. as the Lead Bidder or a significant subcontractor) due to the knowledge, experience and other value that such providers would bring to these challenging, short-term pilot contracts.

The procurement process will adopt the “Open Procedure” as a template in that no formal Pre-Qualification Questionnaire (PQQ) process will be followed. The ITT will be split into stages and the ITT pack contains Eligibility questions which Bidders must pass in order for their ITT bids to be progressed to the evaluation stage. See the ITT documentation for further details. 

Full advertisement wording is outlined on the attachment to this notice.
Attachments: NT028P_Advert Wording_v1.docx

Title: Clinical Managed Services (including Managed Maintenance Services and Consultancy Services to support the Managed Service Provision)
Description:
NHS Shared Business Services Limited (NHS SBS) act in an Agency capacity for and on behalf of its customers (Approved Organisations) - existing and new. These comprise of NHS and Social Care organisations (whether acting individually, or on behalf of, or together as members of any consortia) along with any other public or private sector bodies which NHS SBS authorises to use the resulting Framework.
NHS SBS intends to put in place a Framework Agreement for the provision of  Clinical Managed Services and related Goods and Services for Healthcare to be used by NHS SBS Approved Organisations.
Our Approved Organisation list can be found on: 

https://sbs.nhs.uk/proc-framework-agreements-support
We are committed to working with suppliers who are dedicated to Sustainability and Social Value and there will be a significant weighting on these elements in the tender.
This Prior Information Notice (PIN) is to signal an intention to commence market engagement with those within the Clinical Managed Services market.
The Request for Information Questionnaire can be requested from the e-mail address shown. 

Please complete and return the RFI (Request for Information) by 12 noon on, Friday, 10th February 2023 to the below email address: 
nsbs.health@nhs.net

NHS Shared Business Services Limited (NHS SBS) reserves the right to withdraw this notice at any time. NHS SBS is not bound to accept any proposals submitted by Bidders and is not liable for any costs incurred as a result of Bidders engaging with this process. This early market engagement exercise does not guarantee that a Procurement will take place and NHS SBS reserves the right to defer from any Procurement entirely.
NHS SBS intends to hold market engagement sessions throughout February & March 2023 with industry experts and suppliers

Organisation Name: NHS ARDEN AND GREATER EAST MIDLANDS COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Prior Information Notice for Alternative Provider Medical Services for GP practices in Coventry, and North Warwickshire
Description:
NHS Arden & Greater East Midlands Commissioning Support Unit (AGCSU) on behalf of NHS Coventry & Rugby CCG and NHS Warwickshire North CCG will shortly be publishing a tender opportunity for the provision of primary medical care services, contracted through a number of Alternative Provider Medical Services contracts for the GP Practices listed below. This PIN is to notify and invite potential providers of two market engagement events which will inform and shape the forthcoming procurement exercise.

•	Stoke Aldermoor Clinic, Coventry - patient list size = 3,454
•	Foleshill Surgery, Coventry - patient list size = 3,797
•	Broad Lane Surgery, Coventry - patient list size = 3,936
•	City of Coventry NHS Healthcare Centre, Coventry - patient list size = 5,506
•	GP Led Health Centre, Camphill Family Centre, Nuneaton - patient list size = 4,393
•	The Chaucer Surgery, Attleborough, Nuneaton - patient list size = 2,885
•	Satis House Medical Practice, Water Orton - patient list size = 3,572

NHS England has delegated its commissioning authority to NHS Coventry & Rugby CCG and NHS Warwickshire North CCG, and as a result under delegated functions NHS Coventry & Rugby CCG and NHS Warwickshire North CCG will act on behalf of NHS England & NHS Improvement - Midlands 

The Commissioners are looking to re-procure primary medical care services that are currently delivered through time limited APMS contracts which will expire on the 31st March 2020. 

The provision of the services will enable the Commissioners to maintain access to good quality primary medical care for their populations. Improving patient outcomes are focal points of the procurement of healthcare services within NHS Coventry & Rugby CCG & NHS Warwickshire North CCG. In line with the national strategy, the Commissioners intend to work with  primary care providers to mobilise a new model of pro-active preventative care, develop an urgent care offer that provides a coherent, streamlined locally accessible and convenient alternative to accident and emergency services for patients that do not require hospital care and to equip the workforce to deliver excellent patient centred care, whilst recognising the geographical spread of the contracts and the emerging importance of Primary Care Networks.   The Commissioners are looking to appoint Providers that wish to engage fully in this agenda.   
     
The lotting strategy is yet to be devised. This will be formed following engagement with potential providers, although it is intended that bids for a single contract will be permissible and that there will be the opportunity to submit bids as a single provider as well as collaborative bids with other providers. The list sizes of the contracts that the Commissioners are looking to procure range from circa 3,000 to 5,500.

The contracts are due to commence on 1st April 2020. The length and value of the contracts will be discussed with Providers at the market engagement event.
Additional Text:
The Commissioners are inviting potential providers to attend a market engagement event. To encourage engagement and attendance the Commissioners will be holding two events to be held in Coventry on 30 July 2019 and Warwickshire North area (Nuneaton) on 31 July 2019, venues are yet to be confirmed. Registration for the event will begin at 11.00am, with the actual event starting promptly at 11.30am.  

The Market Engagement event will give potential providers an overview of Services requirements and the opportunity to discuss the contract type and length, the procurement process and anticipated timelines.

At these market engagement events, the Commissioner will be giving potential providers the opportunity for one to one discussions with the Commissioning Team. The objective of the one to one sessions is to gather information that will be useful to inform the procurement process to help the Commissioner to design the services; to understand any provider issues and concerns, and any issues that would stop a potential provider from tendering for the opportunity. 

The appointments will last no more than 20 mins per provider. 

To book an appointment, please select one of the time slots from below, and message your preferred time slot through the messaging facility on the EU Supply portal; 

Providers must note that if your time slot is not available, then the next available nearest time slot will be allocated to you; 

A time slot will only be booked once the provider has confirmed acceptance of the allocated timeslot. 

Deadline for registration for the events and booking one to one sessions is 4.00pm on 26 July 2019. Please see bookable appointment slots below: 

30 July 2019 (Coventry event) 
2.00pm, 2.20pm, 2.40pm, 3.00pm, 3.20pm, 3.40pm, 4.00pm, 4.20pm, 4.40pm


31 July 2019 (Warwickshire North event) 
2.00pm, 2.20pm, 2.40pm, 3.00pm, 3.20pm, 3.40pm, 4.00pm, 4.20pm, 4.40pm 2.20pm

The Tender will be published around September 2019, and will be available through the Arden & GEM Procurement Portal https://uk.eusupply.com/login.asp?B=AGCSU&target=&timeout=

Arden & GEM CSU are using a procurement portal to run the expression of interest through the link below , potential providers should complete the expression of interest to confirm their interest to attend the event .The tender number for the expression of interest is Tender  36119.

https://uk.eu-supply.com/login.asp?B=AGCSU&target=&timeout=
Please note that an expression of interest in this market engagement exercise will not automatically entitle potential providers involvement in any future procurement exercise. Any procurement conducted as a result of this event will be advertised separately and all organisations wanting to participate will need to respond to the procurement advertisement as and when it is published.

Organisation Name: East Of England NHS Collaborative Hub
Title: Medical Gas Cylinders
Description:
The East of England NHS Collaborative Procurement Hub (the Authority) intends to procure a framework agreement for the provision of Medical Gas Cylinders including supply, rental and delivery of filled medical gas cylinders and associated products / consumables. The primary gases required include:
- Medical Air,
- Oxygen,
- Carbon Dioxide,
- Nitrous Oxide.

The tender is anticipated to be undertaken under the open procedure. The Authority intends to apply an appropriate technical threshold and award bidders meeting this threshold to the framework agreement on an un-ranked basis. Based on current intelligence, it is anticipated that 3 (three) suppliers will be awarded.

The resulting framework agreement will be for East of England NHS Collaborative Procurement Hub (EoECPH) Members.

Associate members are publicly funded entities, not EoECPH members, who sign the framework customer access agreement and are subsequently granted access to the framework agreement.

Subject to successful application for associate membership this Framework Agreement will include, and be for the benefit of any publicly funded (both wholly and partially funded) entity in the United Kingdom, including Northern Ireland, Scotland, Wales and England. This will include, but is not limited to: Acute, Ambulance, Mental Health, Clinical Commissioning Groups, Health and Care Trusts, Area Teams, Local Authorities and Special Health Authorities, HSC in Northern Ireland, NHS Scotland and NHS Wales, including any successor or emerging organisations, which will include but is not limited to the emerging landscape of combined health and social care commissioners and providers. Please follow the links below to identify specific organisations:

- NHS trusts: http://www.nhs.uk/ServiceDirectories/Pages/AcuteTrustListing.aspx,
- Clinical Commissioning Groups: http://www.nhs.uk/ServiceDirectories/Pages/CCGListing.aspx,
- Area Teams: http://www.nhs.uk/ServiceDirectories/Pages/AreaTeamListing.aspx,
- Local Authorities: https://www.lgbce.org.uk/records-and-resources/local-authorities-in-england,
- Special health authorities: http://www.nhs.uk/ServiceDirectories/Pages/SpecialHealthAuthorityListing.aspx,
- HSC in Northern Ireland: http://online.hscni.net/other-hsc-organisations,
- NHS Scotland:http://www.scot.nhs.uk/organisations/,
- NHS Wales:http://www.wales.nhs.uk/ourservices/directory.

Indicative framework value: 4 300 000 over two year initial fixed term. 8 600 000 GBP over potential 4 year term where extensions are utilised.

Organisation Name: NHS Newcastle Gateshead Clinical Commissioning Group
Title: Community Eye-care Services for Intraocular Pressure and Children's Cycloplegic Refraction services.
Description:
This is a Contract Award Notice notifying the market of the successful conclusion of the procurement for Community Eye-care Services for Intraocular Pressure and Children's Cycloplegic Refraction services.
North of England Commissioning Support (NECS) managed this procurement process for and on behalf of NHS Newcastle Gateshead, NHS North Tyneside, NHS South Tyneside, NHS Sunderland and NHS Northumberland Clinical Commissioning Groups the (Contracting Authorities).
The Contracting Authorities have commissioned Community Eye-care Services for Intraocular Pressure and Children's Cycloplegic Refraction Services in the Newcastle, Gateshead, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland and Northumberland areas.
The service has been awarded under one contract with NHS Newcastle Gateshead Clinical Commissioning Group as the coordinating commissioner with associates NHS North Tyneside, NHS South Tyneside, NHS Sunderland and NHS Northumberland CCGs.
The basic principles of the Open Procurement route were followed for this procurement to test the capacity, capability, and technical competence of Tenderers in accordance with The Public Contracts Regulations 2006(as amended). Regulation 120 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 provides for a temporary exemption and saving for certain NHS procurements. Regulation 120 provides that nothing in the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 affects any contract award procedure that relates to the procurement of health care services for the purposes of the NHS within the meaning and scope of the National Health Service (Procurement, Patient Choice and Competition) (No. 2) Regulations 2013(b), that is commenced before 18.4.2016 and any subsequent contract awarded as a result of such a procedure. The current Part B regime of the Public Contracts Regulations 2006 (as amended) and NHS (Procurement, Patient Choice and Competition) (No. 2) Regulations 2013(b) will continue to apply to the commissioning of these services until 18.4.2016.
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [Primary Eyecare (North East) Ltd|2 Woodbridge Street,, London|||No|No]

Organisation Name: HealthTrust Europe LLP (HTE) acting as agent for the University Hospitals of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust (UHCW)
Title: United Kingdom-Birmingham: Venepuncture, blood sampling devices
Description: 'This tender is to establish a framework agreement for the supply of Blood and Other Specimen Collection Devices and Accessories to Acute and Primary Care and Educational settings. II.1.I]. The scope of this framework agreement includes Blood collection devices and other devices for the collection of specimens such as Faeces, Urine, Saliva, Sputum or other bodily fluids/specimens  and any accessories to support or aid collection; might includes, needles, lancets, tourniquets, leuer adapters and transfer devices. HTE is a central purchasing body who is able to carry out this tender exercise by virtue of its appointment as an agent of UHCW. Notwithstanding HTE's relationship with UHCW, it is HTE that will conduct this tender exercise and will execute the resultant framework agreement with successful bidders. This tender exercise is for the benefit of all the public and voluntary bodies listed further below in this Section II.1.5. Title: NHS England-NW- Award for Prescribed Specialist Services-Blackpool Teaching Hospitals NHS FT
Description: In 2016/17 NHS England set out our approach to ensure that prescribed specialised services are commissioned from the most capable providers through a rolling Strategic Service Review Programme with priorities published in commissioning intentions.From service reviews and from locally led change through sustainability and transformation plans, we expect there to be more networks of specialist providers and re-shaping supply models and contracting approaches to integrate care around patients.Service reviews will also provide opportunity for providers to propose sustainable solutions in line with clinically developed requirements. Service review implementation will also enable new payment approaches in order to incentivise improvement in care quality and patient experience.

Title: NHS Ambassador Programme Evaluation
Description:
The purpose of this Invitation to Quote is to commission an independent evaluation into the impact of the NHS Ambassadors programme. 
HEE has been working in partnership with Education and Employers since 2018 to promote and drive forward NHS Ambassadors. The programme enables opportunities for NHS employees to volunteer their time at educational events in schools and colleges to talk about their roles as well as highlight the breadth of potential careers within the NHS and thereby encouraging school children to consider a career within the NHS. 
NHS Ambassadors illustrate an important connection between the classroom and potential career opportunities within the NHS and help to breakdown stereotypes and perceived barriers to entry to different professions. There are over 3,000 NHS Ambassadors in the United Kingdom who support a range of educational events including careers' talks, mentoring, CV workshops and interview preparation.

Title: Evaluation of the NHS GP Induction and Refresher Scheme Assessments
Description:
Background Information.

The NHS GP Induction and Refresher (I&R Scheme) Scheme provides a safe, supported and direct route for qualified GPs to join or return to NHS general practice.

It is designed for GPs who have previously been on the GMC Register and NHS England's Medical Performers List (NMPL) and would like to return to general practice after a career break, raising a family or time spent working abroad.

The scheme also supports the safe introduction of overseas GPs who have qualified outside the UK and have no previous NHS experience.

All GPs are required to be on NHS England's NMPL before they can practise. The I&R scheme must be completed before GPs can be approved for full inclusion on to the NMPL as an independent general practitioner. GPs not currently working in general practice can apply to return to the NMPL for up to two years after which they will need to apply to join again and complete the I&R Scheme.

A revised Induction and Refresher scheme was launched in March 2015 to enable doctors who hold a recognised qualification in general practice and GMC registration to begin or return to practice as a GP. It is aimed at GPs who have qualified overseas and not worked in the NHS before (induction) and those who have worked as a NHS GP before but been away for over two years or more (refresher).

Scope of Evaluation

The review should look at the application process, MCQ assessments, simulated surgery and the workplace based assessment (WPBA) and suggest potential changes to improve efficiency, equity and transparency with regard to process; comments about validity, reproducibility and appropriateness of the assessments would also be useful. A full psychometric analysis is not however required.

HEE would like answers to the following questions:

•	Is the current programme of assessment fit for the purpose?
•	Are the current standards appropriate to ensure patient safety and patient -centred practice, particularly with regard to patient safety during the placement period?
•	Does the programme avoid "setting up doctors to fail" in complex environments through assumptions that they have sufficient basic medical knowledge as well as awareness of NHS systems and ethos?
•	Are there adequate "educational prescriptions" which include qualitative feedback and support for communication skills?
•	Are levels of challenge appropriate?
•	Is fairness to candidates sufficiently considered at all stages of test design and delivery?
•	Are enhancements to test development, standard setting and quality assurance methodologies needed currently?
•	Are there emerging evidence-based assessment methodologies that we should consider ensuring that the processes in place remain fit for purpose and adaptable?

Timescales 

Delivery of final report by end March 2019.
