Organisation Name: STAFFORDSHIRE AND LANCASHIRE COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: NHS Greater Preston and NHS Chorley & South Ribble CCGs Night Sitting Service
Description:
NHS Greater Preston CCG and NHS Chorley & South Ribble CCG wish to procure a night sitting service for end of life patients within the localities of the two CCGs. This will cover  safe, effective and appropriate symptom and side-effect management which as a minimum, will include: 
o	generalist medical services (including GPs) 
o	nursing services (defined as visiting, rapid response services and provision of one-to-one care at home, including overnight)
o	personal care services
o	access to pharmacy services 
o	access to equipment and adaptations
o	specialist palliative care advice for generalists on symptom and side-effect management.

The North West Model for Life Limiting Conditions covers the breadth of end of life care from stable progressive life-limiting condition; incurable, symptoms treatable all the way through to bereavement care.   The requirement of this service provision is to focus on the later stage of element 2 & all stage 3, Advancing Disease & Increasing decline (months and weeks) and last days of life (days and hours). 

The Commissioners are planning to support those patients whose preferred place of death is home by means of providing an End of life respite service to enable patients to remain in their usual place of residence whilst receiving 1:1 support. This service will support carers and family members to take breaks from caring for their loved one, whilst knowing they are being care for.

The contract is for a period of two years (24 months) with an option to extend for 12 months and has a financial envelope of £150, 000 per annum.
Additional Text:
This procurement is for Social and other specific services which are Light Touch Regime services for the purpose of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 as specified in Schedule 3 of the Regulations ('Regulations') http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2015/102/schedule/3/made  
Accordingly, the Contracting Authority is only bound by those parts of the Regulations detailed in Chapter 3 Particular Procurement Regimes Section 7 http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2015/102/part/2/chapter/3/made
The Contracting Authority is not voluntarily following any other part of the Regulations.  The procedure which the Contracting Authority is following is set out in the procurement documents. 
As the CCG is a relevant body for the purpose of the National Health Service (Procurement, Patient Choice and Competition) (No 2) Regulations 2013 these Regulations also apply to this procurement.  
Right to Cancel: The Contracting Authority reserves the right to discontinue the procurement process at any time, which shall include the right not to award a contract or contracts and does not bind itself to accept the lowest tender, or any tender received, and reserves the right to award a contract in part, or to call for new tenders should it consider this necessary. 
The Contracting Authority shall not be liable for any costs or expenses incurred by any candidate or tenderer in connection with the completion and return of the information requested in this Contract Notice, or in the completion or submission of any tender, irrespective of the outcome of the competition or if the competition is cancelled or postponed.  
All dates, time periods and values specified in this notice are provisional and the Contracting Authority reserves the right to change these.  
Transparency: The Contracting Authority is subject to the Freedom of Information Act 2000 (FOIA) and the Environmental Information Regulations 2004 (EIR) and may be required to disclose information received in the course of this procurement under FOIA or the EIR.  
In addition, and in accordance with the UK Government's policies on transparency, the contracting authority intends to publish procurement documentation and the text of any resulting contractual arrangements, subject to possible redactions at the discretion of the Contracting Authority.  
Any redactions, whether in relation to information requests under FOIA, the EIR or policies on transparency will be in accordance with those grounds prescribed under the Freedom of Information Act. If and when this requirement is offered to tender, this will be done via electronic means using the internet. Midlands and Lancashire CSU is conducting this procurement exercise as a central purchasing body for another NHS body with whom the successful bidder(s) will enter into contracts for the supply of the services.

Title: Department of Health & NHS Business Services Authority - Future Operating Model for NHS Logistics Procurement
Description:
Further to the PIN published by the Department of Health (DH) and the NHS Business Services Authority (NHSBSA) in the Official Journal of the European Union ref 2015/S 231-389103 on the 30th October 2015 regarding the procurement of the future model for NHS procurement, supply chain and logistics services.

DH is to hold a Market Engagement Day at Quarry House, Leeds on October 27th 2016 specifically to present to the market the proposed logistics services contract of the Future Operating Model (FOM).   The early engagement is to ascertain interest in the market for a potential 3 year term contract with two one year extension options, tied to performance outcomes.  The prospective contract would be with a single provider on an open book plus management fee basis.  The Market Engagement day will be in the form of presentations by DH explaining the FOM, logistics operation, procurement process, proposed contract and proposed payment model.  It will also provide an opportunity for attendees to feedback to the DH both on the day and through follow up one-to-one engagement. 

To register for this Market Engagement day please email fom.logistics@dh.gsi.gov.uk by 17:00 October 13th 2016.  Places will be restricted to two attendees per supplier at this initial meeting.  Please provide names when registering.
Additional Text: Please note that all organisations who register an expression of interest for this event will (if they have not already done so) be required to sign a Non-Disclosure Agreement.  Only organisations that have registered will be allowed entry to the Event.  Organisations not attending the Market Engagement Event, but who still wish to participate in future sessions are advised to register their interest as per the instructions above, stating that they will not be attending on 27th October.

Title: Department of Health & NHS Business Services Authority - Future Operating Model for NHS Logistics, Procurement and Supply Chain Services
Description:
Department of Health Procurement Transformation Programme ("The Programme") Future Operating Model ("FOM") for NHS Procurement, Supply Chain and Logistics Services.

Further to the PIN published by the Department of Health ("DH") and the NHS Business Services Authority ("NHSBSA") in the Official Journal of the European Union 2015/S 213-389103 on the 30th October 2015, and following the success of the Market Engagement Event held by the DH on 27th November 2015.  

The DH and the NHSBSA would like to advise all interested parties that a second Supplier Market Engagement Event will now take place on Thursday, 21st April 2016, at Skipton House, 80 London Road, London, SE1 6LH.
Attachments: Appendix_A__Substantial_Market_Engagment_Activity_and_Time_line.docx
Additional Text:
The purpose of this second Market Engagement Event is to set out to the market in more detail the proposed model for the Procurement Services (Category Towers) and IT and Supporting Technology elements of the Future Operating Model, and to invite feedback in respect of the current thinking and proposed approach to these specific service areas. 

Please note - that other service elements of the FOM, such as Transactional  Services and Logistics including Warehouse Management and  Transport Services, will be covered in future engagement events-  the dates of which will be published in due course.

The Market Engagement Event (for Procurement Services (Category Towers) and IT and Supporting Technologies) will be the first event in a three month substantial market engagement process, with Programme representatives,  based on the activities and indicative time lines outlined in Appendix A. 

Please note that all organisations who register an expression of interest for this event will (if they have not already done so) be required to sign a Non-Disclosure Agreement. Only organisations that have registered will be allowed entry to the Event. Organisations not attending the Market Engagement Event, but who still wish to participate in future sessions are advised to register their interest as per the instructions below: 
Suppliers will be limited to two attendees per organisations. Please provide details of these representatives to nhs.procurement@nhs.net
by close of business Monday 18th April. 

If your organisation has not yet completed and returned the Programme Non-Disclosure Agreement, please request a copy from the email address above and provide a completed response prior to attendance.

Please note that registration for the follow up one to one session(s) will be taken during the event by a member of the Programme Team. A digital copy of the entire presentation will be provided following the event.

Title: Value Based Commissioning Service Provision for the benefit of NHS Haringey and NHS Islington Clinical Commissioning Groups (the CCGs)
Description:
NHS Haringey and NHS Islington Clinical Commissioning Groups (the CCGs) are working together to put outcomes at the heart of how they commission for people with diabetes and older people with frailty. The approach is called ‘value based commissioning (VBC)’. As part of the process, the CCGs now wish to assess whether there are providers who would have the willingness, capability and capacity to be able to successfully lead delivery of VBC for patients within North Central London across specific projects. 

Value Based Commissioning is seen as a key strategic initiative within the Five Year Strategic Plan for the CCGs. Value based commissioning is about working collaboratively with our providers to achieve the best possible outcomes for patients for every pound spent.  Developing a shared common goal unites the interests of all - patients, commissioners and providers - in support of a sustainable and high quality health care system.  In addition, this approach drives different providers to work together to better co-ordinate care for patients, improving patient experience and outcomes.  Where such an approach has been implemented, as in stroke care across London, measurable improvements in outcomes have been achieved. 

The aim of the CCGs’ value based commissioning programme is to promote a greater focus on measuring and achieving the outcomes that matter to patients. The CCGs are focusing first on older people living with frailty across Haringey and people with diabetes across Islington and Haringey.  The CCGs are aiming to embed this approach within 2015/16 and therefore interested in hearing the views of providers and other stakeholders to ensure the proposed approach achieves the best outcomes for service users.

The Memorandum of Information that accompanies this Contract Notice provides further detail on the project scope, the outcomes measured and the service design attributes. The scope of the service is currently being developed and such that the financial envelope remains an estimate (between £25 - £35 million per annum) and could increase or decrease accordingly. The contract is expected to be for the duration of three to five years (providing the outcomes within the contract are delivered) with an option to extend it for a further two years. 

Registration is through the Pro-Contract e-tendering portal which can be accessed at www.supplying2nhs.com. Please refer to the guides and documents available on Pro-Contract supplier opportunities portal to help guide through the registration and electronic submission process.  The Memorandum of Information provides further on the overall process.
Attachments: MoI_CCGs Value Based Commissioning - final.pdf Instructions to suppliers.pdf

Organisation Name: NHS North West London Integrated Care Board
Title: NWL0162 Provision of a medicine management tools to optimise prescribing and medicine related care to patients
Description:
NHS NW London ICB is considering procuring a contract for the provision of medicine management tools to optimise prescribing and medicine related care to patients. The aim of the service is to provide NHS North West London ICB Medicines Management team with access to reliable, trusted, evidence-based support and resources and tools that improve medicines-related care to patients.

NHS NW London ICB currently has an arrangement in place with PrescQIPP CIC to deliver the above services. PrescQIPP CIC is an NHS funded not-for-profit organisation that supports quality, optimised prescribing for patients. With subscriber input and collaboration across NHS organisation, the platform provides system wide support across the ICB and it's ICS members to benefit from insightful resource provision.

The purpose of this notice is to be transparent about NHS NW London's intention to explore options to procure this service and to undertake a further competition, if possible. NHS NW London ICB is currently of the view that this is a niche service and PrescQIPP CIC is the only capable provider that is best placed to successfully deliver this service. As such, should PrescQIPP CIC be the only capable provider, it is NHS NW London ICB's intention to award a further contract (NHS Standard contract-short form) to PrescQIPP CIC from 1st October 2023 for up to 2 years and 6 months (estimated value, £65,500.00 per annum).

Key Service Requirements include:
•	An NHS resource that provides data and evidence-based resources that supports the MM Team in their delivery of efficiencies as well as optimising medicine use within primary care and ensuring that prescribing is of high-quality and as safe as possible.
•	Examples of the above include:
-	Webkits (with practical tools and materials such as patient information and letters, pathways and audits)
-	Bulletins and briefings (with clinical evidence, information and guidance about a range of treatments and conditions)
-	Data and analysis (to help commissioners benchmark their activity and identify where they can make the biggest difference)
-	Clinical webinars (to support learning on a variety of relevant topics)
-	Clinical masterclasses
-	Horizon scanning
-	Primary care rebates
•	An ISO 9001: 2015 certified organisation that is also registered with the BSI.

Capable providers may come forward by 17:00 on 9th August 2023 to engage with the ICB via nhsnwl.contracting@nhs.net - In your response to this opportunity, in up to 500 words, kindly demonstrate and describe ready and available solution that meets the set out key requirements above. 

The NHS NW London ICB is committed to assess the needs of the service users and consider how (if relevant) it needs to secure the needs of the people who use the services, and improve the quality and efficiency in the provision of the services including through the services being provided in an integrated way.
Contact Name: NHS North West London Contracts Team

Title: Help Us, Help You' Creative Development and Production
Description:
The NHS England Campaigns Team deliver national social marketing campaigns to support the NHS. 

Our campaigns are delivered under two overarching campaign brands:
• The 'We are the NHS' campaign aims to inspire people to join the NHS and retain those already working in it. It promotes the NHS as a first-choice employer, focusing on priority recruitment of professions including: Nursing; Allied Health Professionals; Healthcare Support Workers; and 999 & 111 Call Handlers; also supporting the recruitment of NHS Reservists.

• The 'Help Us, Help You' campaign is designed to save lives by changing the way people access services to reduce pressures on the NHS and maintain capacity, by driving effective use of the NHS, encouraging people to get help in the right place and at the right time.

This contract is for an advertising agency to lead the strategy, creative development and production work for the 'Help Us, Help You' campaign.

The 'Help Us, Help You' campaign is delivered through a number of different phases aimed at different audiences and with separate aims and objectives.

All our campaign activity supports the successful delivery of the organisational priorities of NHS England and the wider NHS. These are set out in the NHS Long Term Plan and the annual NHS Priorities and Operational Planning Guidance.
Policy Context: 'Help Us, Help You'

The term is 3+1 years

pharmaceutical waste, offensive/hygiene waste, hazardous and non-hazardous healthcare waste for NHS Trusts within the Cheshire and Merseyside region:

TERMS AND CONDITIONS/ACTIVITY BASED INCOME (ABI) The terms and conditions of this framework agreement and any resulting call-off contract is appended to the ITT. These terms include provisions requiring the payment by the supplier of an ABI management charge in consideration of the award of this framework agreement, The management and administration by HTE of the overall contract structure and associated documentation, as well as the requirement to submit regular management information to HTE.

Clinical Waste will be described within the following categories: Hazardous Waste, Pharmaceutical Waste
and Sharps Waste.
Clinical Waste is defined as: "...any waste which consists wholly or partly of human or animal
tissue, blood or other body fluids, excretions, drugs or other pharmaceutical products, swabs or
dressings, syringes, needles or other sharp instruments, being waste which unless rendered safe,
may prove hazardous to any person coming into contact with it; and any other waste arising from
medical, nursing, dental, veterinary, pharmaceutical or similar practice, investigation, treatment,
care, teaching or research, or the collection of blood for transfusion, being waste which may cause
infection to any person coming into contact with it."
Clauses 4.7 and 4.8, Environment and Sustainability Health Technical Memorandum 07-01: Safe
management of healthcare waste.

Title: Procurement of Restorative and Just Training
Description:
Description of the Requirement

The NHS People Plan 2020/21 outlines a commitment to reduce bullying and harassment in the workplace, and clearly states that all employers are responsible for preventing and tackling bullying, harassment and abuse against staff, and for creating a culture of civility and respect.  

The NHS England and Improvement (NHSEI) Civility and Respect team would like to commission an accredited Just and Learning Culture training programme on behalf of the NHS.  The programme would be aimed at professionals and practitioners across the NHS and will provide them with skills that will enable them to influence work in their own organisations and help promote cultures based on just and restorative approaches.  The range of interventions they adopt may support the organisation at individual and team level to manage these situations in a positive manner, to avoid blame and negativity, and to create cultures where staff feel supported and safe. 

The training will incorporate aspects of the national objectives and restorative and just culture context shown below:  

1.	Civility and Respect principles and practice

2.	National context and objectives such as:
-	NHS Health and Wellbeing Framework - Get Started (2018)
-	NHS Health and Wellbeing resources www.england.nhs.uk/people
-	NHS Long term Plan (2019)
-	NHS People Plan (2020/21) 

3.	Just and Restorative Culture from the NHS perspective - regulatory, evidence, learning, best practice and co-production i.e. 
-	What is a Just and Restorative Culture?
-	Context:
-	NHS Resolution Annual Report and Accounts (2019/20) 
and the associated
-	Being Fair Report (Advise, Resolve & Learn) which incorporates a Just and learning Culture Charter 
-	Patient Safety Incident Response Framework (2020)
-	NHS Patient Safety Strategy (2021)

4.	Incident responding and reporting - case studies, learning, sharing, solutions and approach
5.	Restorative V retributive culture - case studies, learning, sharing, solutions and approach
6.	Impact of COVID-19 - case studies, learning, sharing, solutions and approach
7.	Current HR and OD policies versus reasons to change/amend to achieve a Just and restorative culture
8.	Live expert speakers
9.	Recommended reading
10.	Individual participant approach to Civility and Respect and produce implementation plan for own organisation.
11.	Reflection


The contract for training delivery will commence from contract start date (August 2021) until completion of the training and check in event (end of March 2022).  The maximum contract value is estimated at £330k Exc VAT.

REGISTER YOUR INTEREST BY 02/08/21
Interested suppliers should read the details attached to the notice which specify further details about the requirement, how to register an interest in the possible procurement and the submission requirements for registering an interest.

Organisation Name: NHS ARDEN AND GREATER EAST MIDLANDS COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Prior Information (without call for competition) and notice of Engagement Exercise regarding "Locally Commissioned Services" for Norfolk and Waveney CCGs
Description:
The five CCGs in Norfolk and Waveney, NHS North Norfolk Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG), NHS South Norfolk CCG, NHS Norwich CCG, NHS West Norfolk CCG and NHS Great Yarmouth and Waveney CCG, wish to invite Stakeholders and Potential Bidders to register for and attend an Engagement Event, that is supported by NHS Arden and Greater East Midlands Commissioning Support Unit (AGCSU). 

The Engagement Event will be to advise the Market and Stakeholders of the CCGs intention to secure service provision via direct awarding (without competition) to secure service provision for now and until 30/09/2020, before a procured (utilising competition under the Light Touch Regime of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 or any superseding law) service(s) can be delivered from 01/10/2021. 

The CCGs wish to invite any interested party / Provider to attend a Market Engagement Event, on the 29/11/2018, where the CCGs will present its proposals and invite feedback on these, and for interested parties to engage further throughout the planning of the proposed competitive procurement, and aid the development of service specification(s), aims and objectives, and financial model. 

The engagement event will be on the 29th November 2018, in Norwich. Further agenda and location details will be sent to delegates prior to the event, following registration (instructions below). 

The CCGs also wish to seek any disagreement to the plans to direct award contracts for service provision for the shorter term, so they are able to plan and align resource to the project appropriately.

Further information regarding the CCGs' strategy, intentions, and background, is available on the procurement portal, Bravo (https://ardengemcsu.bravosolution.co.uk/web/login.html). 
 
Aims and objectives of service

The Norfolk & Waveney CCGs (NHS North Norfolk CCG, NHS South Norfolk CCG, NHS Norwich CCG, NHS West Norfolk CCG and NHS Great Yarmouth & Waveney CCG) are undertaking a piece of work to identify the appropriate commissioning strategy and delivery vehicle for their Locally Commissioned Services and potentially other services going forward. This work is aligned to the Norfolk & Waveney CCGs' STP plan and is set against a backdrop of the NHS Five Year Forward View, the development of new models of care and the local challenges facing the CCGs and general practice. 

The geographic scope of the contract will be aligned to the Norfolk & Waveney CCGs' localities and will cover 108 general practice populations, which is equivalent to a combined list size of approximately 1 million. The contract will, however, be structured to allow for growth in the number of patients.

It is the CCGs' intention to let 5 contracts, one at each CCG level, to deliver a range of locally commissioned services. It is also the intention of the CCGs to structure the contract to allow for additional services to be included in the scope of the contract during the period of the contract.
Attachments: READ ME - INSTRUCTIONS TO REGISTER FOR EVENT AND GIVE FEEDBACK Contracts Finder FINAL V1 01.11.18.pdf
Additional Text:
Services in scope

The CCGs wish to engage with the market and stakeholders regarding appropriate in-scope services, however to enable interested parties to understand the types of services that may be included, a list of services being considered is included below, however this is subject to change to remove services and also add services to this list:

General ECG & 24 hour Ambulatory ECG Monitoring
•	24hr ECG
Blood Services
•	Anti-Coagulation
•	Phlebotomy
Treatment Room
•	Nursing and Diagnostics Service
•	Regular Medication Injections including B12 & Sustanon
•	Ring Pessary Insertion and Changes
•	Spirometry
DVT
•	DVT
Eating Disorders and Weight Management
•	Community Eating Disorders
•	Eating Disorders
Minor Injury
•	Minor Injury
•	Post-Operative Care
•	Simple Dressings and Wound Care.

Integration, Innovation and Transformation 

The CCGs' shared strategy is to design a delivery model that is both innovative and transformational. The CCGs' vision is to deliver relevant services in a fully integrated and patient centric manner across the whole of the health and social care spectrum. They will therefore need to ensure that the locally commissioned services can be delivered in a way which supports progress towards integration of services.

The objective of this work is to ensure that the portfolio of local services commissioned by the CCGs is appropriately aligned with their strategic vision, as well as best quality of outcomes for patients. 

Interim Service Provision

The CCGs believe that for the above strategy to be fully delivered they should undertake a 2-year Interim Service Provision of at-scale working through GP federations, the "Review Period". This will commence on 1st October 2019. The key outputs will be to test and refine service pathways, contract mechanisms and outcome metrics before committing to a longer-term contract ensuring that the service is ready to enable the vision described above to be delivered. This sets a clear deadline for a full open procurement process, which would / should commence in October 2020 for service commencement in October 2021.


Further Details and How to register for the event

The service is a Schedule 3 Service and is being procured under the Light Touch Regime (LTR) of the Public Contract Regulations 2015. 

Providers wishing to seek more detail, and / or to register for the Engagement Event should visit the procurement portal: https://ardengemcsu.bravosolution.co.uk/web/login.html and REGISTER FOR and SUBMIT pqq_535.

This PQQ is only being used to enable registration details for the event, and interested parties, to be sent to AGCSU and the CCGs; please note submission of this online PQQ form is NOT submission of a "Pre-Qualification Questionnaire" for a competitive procurement exercise

Organisation Name: NHS England (Cumbria and the North East)
Title: Impact and Process Evaluation of the Healthy Workforce Programme
Description:
The NHS Five Year Forward View made a commitment ‘to ensure the NHS as an employer sets a national example in the support it offers its own staff to stay healthy’.

Working with colleagues at 12 NHS organisations from around the country, NHS England has established a programme to: 

•	improve the health and wellbeing of our staff; 
•	reduce sickness absence and the associated costs; and
•	demonstrate that the NHS is ‘getting our own house in order’ as we make a case for the role of work in supporting health and wellbeing.

NHS England is providing a range of support to a group of 12 NHS organisations as they extend the health and wellbeing offer to their staff. This includes funding new or enhanced health and wellbeing services, encouraging a culture change in leadership, and training managers. These are: 

•	NHS Health Checks: lifestyle checks for staff aged 40-74 
•	Services to prevent and treat muscular-skeletal problems;
•	Services to prevent and treat mental ill-health; 
•	A culture of strong leadership and management of staff health; 
•	A range of healthy lifestyle support services

These 12 NHS organisations will have a significantly more extensive health and wellbeing offer for their staff than is common across the NHS. 

The intention is to roll this programme out nationally but before this is done; NHS England wishes to carry out an impact and process evaluation to establish the efficacy of the current roll out. 

NHS England has gone out to tender utilising the the UK Shared Business Services Market Research Framework RM1086 MR130001 Lot 2: Strategic Planning & Development.

Title: Public Health and GP Lead Provider Services - PIN and Market Engagement - Health Education England - London and Kent, Surrey & Sussex - NHS/SoEPS/19.535
Description:
NHS South of England Procurement Services (SoSEPS) acting on behalf of Health Education England - London (HEE - The Commissioner) will be commencing a tender for the provision of Public Health and GP Lead Provider Services.   

This Prior Information Notice (PIN) is to advise prospective providers of the Commissioners intention
Health Education England gives notice of the intention to engage providers with the ambition and capacity to provide high quality and innovative human resource and employment services by becoming a Lead Employer to General Practice Specialty Trainees (GPSTs) and Public Health Specialty Trainees. This requirement is to have an organisation(s) as a Lead Employer in order to provide trainees with continuity of service whilst working across a range of placements in both NHS and non-NHS organisations (in particular with Local Authorities and out of hours providers).

HEE is looking to procure a Lead Employer for the following: -

Lot 1: Public Health Specialty Trainees - London and KSS: One lead employer for London and KSS who is capable of providing full employment and human resource for approximately 135 trainees. 

Lot 2: General Practice Specialty Trainees (GPSTs) - North London:  One lead employer for North London capable of providing full employment and human resource for approximately 1000 trainees. 

Lot 3: General Practice Specialty Trainees (GPSTs)- South London: One lead employer for South London capable of providing full employment and human resource for approximately 600  trainees. 

The numbers may be subject to change following HEE Business Plan objectives to increase the number of doctors working in general practice.

HEE are looking to procure a Lead Employer (s) for a contract term of five years with agreed review dates which will start on the 1st August 2020. The intention is that the contract(s) will be signed by 1st May 2020 to allow for appropriate time for mobilisation period for the contract to commence by 1st August 2020.

This commissioning ambition builds upon the recommendations that will arise from the Doctors in Training Improvement Programme that is jointly led by Health Education England and NHS England and NHS Improvement. The aim of the programme is to improve the induction and rotation process for all doctors in training enabling rotations between NHS and non-NHS organisations to be efficient and to avoid unnecessary duplication of employment, deployment and induction processes. 

The intention of the programme continues to focus on improvement across the core principles: www.nhsemployers.org/your-workforce/recruit/streamlining-programme/doctors-in-training
Additional Text:
We are also holding a Market Engagement session in London at the Auditorium, Stewart House, 32 Russell Square, WC1B 5DN on Monday 11th November 2019 from 13:00 to 16.00.

This will provide an opportunity for potential providers to find out more about the aims of the tender, the procurement process and contracting arrangements as well as proving an opportunity for networking. HEE will use the opportunity to gather intelligence from providers which may influence the final tender.

Please RSVP by Monday 4th November 2019 with the name, title, email address and telephone number for attendees (a maximum of two attendees per organisation) to:  

Email: qpscprocurement@hee.nhs.uk

The Commissioner reserves the right not to proceed with the Procurement, or any part thereof, or change the requirements and timescales as necessary at any time.

It is the intention of the Commissioner that the procurement will be conducted as a Service Contract using an Open Procedure under the Public Contracts Regulations 2015. The ITT is expected to be published in December 2019 with service commencement from August 2020.

A separate advert will be released advising when the procurement is live for submissions.

Notice Identifier: NHS Vale of York CCG PIN
Title: NHS Vale of York CCG  Anticoagulation Warfarin Monitoring and Management Service Market Engagement
Description:
NHS Vale of York CCG wishes to engage with the market in relation to the provision of an Anticoagulation Warfarin Monitoring and Management Service. NHS Vale of York CCG are inviting potential providers of this service to respond to this expression of interest and indicate if they would be interested in bidding for this opportunity. The current level of activity is circa 550 patients and the current budget is circa £108K per annum. The initial contract would be for a period of 3 years.

The Anticoagulation Warfarin Monitoring and Management Service in the NHS Vale of York CCG area was, in the main, historically provided by York Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust through a traditional phlebotomy-based service. The CCG is now transferring this service from secondary care into the community, using a near patient testing model.

The new service will be predominantly provided in primary care. However, the CCG is looking for a single/lead provider to ensure service provision for patients from all of the following practices:

•	East Parade Medical Practice, York - 27 Patients
•	Beech Tree Surgery, Selby - 209 Patients
•	Escrick Surgery, Escrick - 77 patients
•	Sherburn Group Practice, Sherburn in Elmet - 119 patients
•	Tadcaster Medical Centre, Tadcaster - 117 patients

NHS Vale of York CCG would be looking to publish the tender mid - end August 2018 and the contract would commence at the end of January 2019. The provider will be expected to take responsibility for 100% of appropriate patients at contract commencement.

The provider will obtain the sample, test and dose and must use INRstar as the computerised decision support software. The supply of all adequate and appropriate equipment including test strips and control strips will be the provider's responsibility.

As part of the quality requirements of this service, the provider will be expected to minimise any need for warfarin monitoring at weekends and bank holidays. The provider must ensure that, where there is clinical need, their patients have monitoring over weekends and bank holidays. 

If you would be interested in this opportunity, please could you respond by email to annabourne@nhs.net  in the first instance and also include a brief summary of your experience in providing a similar service model. NHS Vale of York CCG would be looking for a single / lead provider to deliver this service, so can you also include any challenges this may bring and how you would propose to mitigate these. Expressions of interest need to be received no later than 5pm on Monday, 9 July 2018.

This exercise is not part of any prequalification or selection process. It is intended as an awareness, communication and information gathering exercise offering an opportunity for potential providers to advise their interest and capability in providing an Anticoagulation Warfarin Monitoring and Management Service.
Attachments: Anticoagulation Service PIN.docx

Title: Pharmacists in NHS111/Integrated Urgent Care Workforce Development Programme, Health Education England - NHS/SoEPS/16.316 Request For Information
Description:
The Pharmacy Integration Fund (PhIF) has been created through the community pharmacy review that is led by the Department of Health, as part of the package of proposals under consideration to transform the way pharmacy and community pharmacy services are commissioned from 2016/17 and beyond . For 2017/18, £40m will be used to fund a range of workforce developments for pharmacists and pharmacy technicians working in a range of settings to better integrate pharmacy into NHS primary care services. 
HEE is working in partnership with NHS England to drive forward the workforce elements of the Pharmacy Integration Fund. This work is part of a broader HEE agenda to drive workforce transformation across the NHS to support locally delivered integrated care models.
One of these elements is the development and delivery of a workforce development programme for pharmacists who will be working in NHS 111  or similar Integrated Urgent Care (IUC) settings.
From 2017/18, an NHS England national programme will recruit pharmacists to work in NHS 111/IUC to clinically assess and treat patients using their expert knowledge of medicines.  They will be prescribers (or training to become one) and will work with/alongside colleagues of other disciplines in a multi-disciplinary team. They will provide leadership on person-centred medicines optimisation and quality improvement, with the role having the potential to significantly improve patient safety and the quality of care. HEE anticipates that the workforce development programme will support pharmacists (and in turn their employers) to realise these goals.
There are specific areas of knowledge, or specific competencies, required more frequently from pharmacists working in this setting. But while it is important for the pharmacist be competent in key responsibilities and activities, HEE recognises that a pharmacist's confidence, preparedness and adaptability for this setting are also key to achieving the desired outcomes.
HEE expects that this workforce programme will lead to the development of a highly-skilled pharmacist, confident to operate remotely from patients and from colleagues, and able to offer expert medicines advice and patient care through NHS 111/IUC.
The Commissioners will value your views and asks a number of set questions. We expect you will find some questions more relevant to you and easier to respond to than others at this moment, however please try to respond to as many as you can. Your views are valuable whether or not you have come across all of the aspects covered.  This is an initial two-year contract with a maximum value of £1,080,000. These figures include VAT. Please note payment will be related to Financial Years. 
Please access the RFI document at: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/soepscommissioning
The deadline for returns is 21 August 2017 at 12 noon, via the In-tend portal.
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and The Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West

Description:
Surrey Heartlands ICB, Surrey County Council, Frimley ICB and NHS England are seeking to secure a model of care for children's community health services across Surrey (and North East Hampshire as per individual service specifications). These community services focus on prevention of ill health, advising on child development and providing targeted and specialist medical, nursing, immunisation or therapy services when needed (for example because a child has a developmental delay, disability, or significant health difficulties). Safeguarding and early intervention are central to this.  
    
    Commissioning organisations would like to hear from organisations who have the experience, capability and capacity to deliver the ambition laid out in this PIN notice. This is not an invitation to tender.
    
    The commissioning organisations warmly invite you to take part in market engagement activities for potential and existing providers of Children's Community Health provision to support us in defining the scope of services and to test our aspirations. Interested organisations are invited to review and respond to the questions included in this PIN and are also invited to register to attend virtual 1:1 Provider Sessions where the commissioning organisations will outline our plans for the procurement and contract for the provision of children community health services. 
    The Children's Community Health Services will be commissioned via a joint NHS contract: NHS Surrey Heartlands ICB (SHICB) are the Awarding Authority for these services, on behalf of itself and Commissioners as listed below:  
    1.	NHS Frimley ICB
    2.	Surrey County Council
    3.	NHS England
    Surrey County Council will be leading the procurement process on behalf of itself, Surrey Heartlands ICB, Frimley ICB and NHS England. 
    
    We will be contracting a standard NHS contract, with standard terms and conditions.
    
    Children's Community Health Services in Surrey comprise a wide range of community-based services that support physical and emotional health and wellbeing amongst children and young people from birth up to 19 years of age and their families and carers. These services focus on:
    •	preventing ill health
    •	promoting and supporting child development
    •	providing targeted and specialist medical, nursing, immunisation, and therapy services.
    
    The purpose of this market engagement will be to:
    -	Share with you our vision and priorities for the development of Children's Community Health provision in Surrey.
    -	Learn together about what is working well and what we can improve in how we commission and deliver Children's Community Health Provision in Surrey.
    -	Explore the shared values and ways of working that will help us collaborate effectively in the future, as we begin the process of recommissioning the future Children's Community Health Provision offer; and
    -	Develop a joint understanding of the outcomes for children and young people that we want to enable through the provision of Children's Community Health Provision in Surrey
    
    For this purpose, contracting authorities may for example seek or accept advice from independent experts, or from market participants. That advice may be used in the planning and conduct of the procurement process. 
    
    The commissioning organisations assure all participants that the advice received will not have the effect of distorting competition, and we abide b
    
    The commissioning organisations assure all participants that the advice received will not have the effect of distorting competition, and we abide by principles of non-discrimination and transparency. 
    
    The commissioning organisations would like to invite Providers with relevant experience, capability, and capacity to deliver these services to register for the Market Engagement 1:1 Provider Sessions in relation to Children's Community Health services. The detailed service requirements are still in development, and information gathered from these sessions will inform key outcomes as well as the procurement process.

Title: Framework Agreement for the Provision of NHS Health Checks
Description:
Leicestershire County Council and Rutland County Council (the Authorities) are undertaking a procurement process to identify and appoint a number of Service Providers to provide NHS Health Checks services in the geographical areas of Leicestershire and Rutland.

The Authorities are inviting tenders for the provision of NHS Health Checks.  Leicestershire County Council will be the lead Authority to procure NHS Health Checks.  The Authority is conducting this procurement under the Light Touch Regime for Social and Other Specific Services, as set out in the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (SI 2015/102) (as amended) ("The 2015 Regulations").

The Leicestershire and Rutland NHS Health Check programme should be delivered in accordance with the contractual and statutory requirements of the GMS/PMS/APMS contracts/agreements.

Contracted suppliers must comply with all applicable statutory and other legal requirements and regulations, all relevant voluntary and compulsory codes of conduct, all relevant professional standards and all applicable National Health Service and County Council directives, guidelines and codes, as stipulated in the service specification.

The NHS Health Check is a health check-up for adults in England aged 40 to 74. It's designed to spot early signs of stroke, kidney disease, heart disease, type 2 diabetes or dementia. As we get older, we have a higher risk of developing one of these conditions. An NHS Health Check helps find ways to lower this risk

The NHS Health Check programme aims to improve the health and wellbeing of adults aged 40-74 years through the promotion of early awareness, assessment, and management of the major risk factors for CVD - risk factors that are associated with premature death, disability and health inequalities. This will in turn reduce levels of Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) and associated premature mortality in Leicestershire County and Rutland County through primary care; ensuring systematic and proactive identification and management of patients with greater than or equal to 10% or greater risk of CVD event in next 10 years (based on a 10-year risk equation).

This contract is similar to a Framework Agreement but under the Light Touch Regime, which will commence on 01 April 2023.  This will be in place for an initial period of 1 year, with an option to extend for a further period or periods up to a total of 36 months in twelve monthly increments, taking the contract term to a maximum of 4 years.

Title: Greener NHS Engagement Campaign
Description:
The NHS is a world-leading healthcare system with a long history of firsts. It was the first healthcare system free at the point of service. In October 2020, the NHS became the world's first healthcare system to commit to reaching net zero

Reaching this goal matters. The core purpose of the NHS is to improve patient and community health outcomes. Climate change threatens this purpose, undermining the foundations of good health and putting the NHS, its staff, and the people it serves at risk. Tackling climate change is lifesaving, with health benefits gained through cleaner air, active lifestyles, and improved diets. As the UK's largest employer, contributing 4.6% of carbon emissions, the NHS is part of the challenge and the solution. It has a collective responsibility to act, with all 1.3 million staff having a role to play.

Complementing other targeted communications activity within and beyond the NHS, we will launch a staff engagement campaign in the second week of July - following on from the NHS Birthday, as a means to look forward - after what has been moment of reflection and thanks for what has gone before. The campaign will launch ahead of the Olympics, leading up to our Net Zero Ambition Anniversary [30th September], and culminating in COP26.

Title: 210301 - Medical Priority Dispatch System (MPDS) and NHS Pathways Review
Description:
The East of England Ambulance Service NHS Trust (EEAST) operates three control rooms termed Ambulance Operation Centres (AOC) who receive both 999 calls from the public as well as calls from HealthCare Professionals and directly transferred from NHS 111 Providers. Ambulance Trusts utilise one of two approved triage tools to support non-clinical call handlers in the assessment, categorisation and provision of advice in relation to 999 calls.  These are known as Medical Priority Dispatch System (MPDS) and NHS Pathways. EEAST utilises MPDS which then requires a separate clinical module and interface to provide the clinical "hear and treat" function. Alongside some Ambulance Trusts for their 999 triage system, NHS 111 Providers also all utilise NHS Pathways. Some Ambulance Trusts provide the NHS 111 function directly in an integrated way with their 999 service (using Pathways for both services). In doing this other ambulance services have taken on a crucial coordination and gatekeeping role by providing coordinated delivery of 111, clinical assessment services and 999 from the point of the call. EEAST has a long-term aspiration to progress towards a similar model in the future.

The Trust is therefore seeking to carry out a review of its triage system (MPDS) against the alternative (NHS Pathways) to inform future strategic decision making. 

The review needs to be completed by 31st March 2021.
Additional Text: Access to the opportunity is via the e-Tendering Portal - Bravo solution.  Please follow the link shown and ensure you are registered with the portal to access the opportunity.

Title: Grant for NHS Apprenticeships Senior Leadership Engagement
Description:
Apprenticeships are a key feature of the Government's educational policy, with specific ambitions to increase apprenticeships within the NHS. The Apprenticeship Benefits Realisation Strategy includes objectives to: 
•	meet the skills needs of employers; 
•	create progression for apprentices; 
•	widen participation and social mobility; and 
•	create more quality apprenticeships. 
To deliver these benefits within the NHS, Trusts and Sustainability and Transformation Partnerships (STPs) need support to become informed apprenticeship customers and to develop apprenticeship strategies that meet the needs of their workforce strategies. 
If the NHS were treated as a single employer, it would be the biggest employer in England. It is a major contributor to both the apprenticeship levy and public sector apprenticeship target. It is expected to deliver over a third of all public sector apprenticeships.  The NHS has an estimated annual public sector target of around 28,000 new apprentice starts. 
The ESFA is looking to award a grant to a delivery organisation who will engage with senior leaders within NHS Trusts and STP's.
In particular we are looking for the following outcomes to be achieved:
•	Engage senior leaders within NHS Trusts, e.g. Finance Directors, HR Directors and Chief Executives
•	Secure their active support as apprenticeship champions within their organisations, ensuring operational staff have the necessary leadership and resources.
•	'Open doors' for our account managers to reach decision-makers.
The successful bidding organisation will need to be able to demonstrate that they are a not-for-profit (e.g. voluntary, community and social enterprise (VCSE) organisations), impartial organisation, with national reach across England and have:
o	an understanding of apprenticeships; 
o	an understanding of and experience with working with the NHS;
o	proven experience of senior stakeholder management and influence; and
o	experience in activities that are aligned with the purpose of the grant.
Additional Text:
The successful bidding organisation will need to be able to demonstrate that they are a not-for-profit (e.g. voluntary, community and social enterprise (VCSE) organisations), impartial organisation, with national reach across England.  The Authority will not be liable for any bid cost, expenditure, work or effort incurred by a supplier in acting on the basis of this notice. 
The competition is being run via the DfE / ESFA eTendering Portal. Providers interested in applying need to register on the Portal. Providers can access this system at https://education.app.jaggaer.com. When you create your account and log in you should click on:

The deadline for receiving all bids is 09 Oct 2019, 17:00BST. The Authority reserves the right not to accept bids submitted after this time.

Title: IM&T Graduate Pathway in the NHS - Provision of a Local Area Model that can be Expanded Nationally
Description:
The Building A Digital Ready Workforce (BDRW) Programme is one of the 33 Digital Transformation Portfolio (DTP) programmes, the portfolio of programmes commissioned by the National Information Board (NIB) to deliver on the strategic objectives originally set out in the NHS Five Year Forward View (FYFV) and the Personalised Health and Care 2020 Framework (PHC2020). It is joint led by NHS Digital, Health Education England and NHS England and has an end of March 2021.

The FYFV made a commitment that, by 2020, there would be "fully interoperable electronic health records so that patients' records are paperless". This was supported by a Government commitment in PHC2020 that "all patient and care records will be digital, interoperable and real-time by 2020". all this requires information to flow more effectively across health and care to support the delivery of direct patient care and it requires a workforce who are equipped with the skills, knowledge, values and behaviours to lead and undertake this change and work within this environment. The BDRW programme delivers upon the workforce elements of PHC2020 and its scope is across the entirety of health and care (1.6 million social care staff, 1.4 million NHS staff in England).

Subsequently, the Martha Lane Fox Review for NIB in 2016 pointed to the need to develop the basic digital skills of the NHS workforce to ensure that everyone has the digital skills needed to support people's health needs. Additionally, the Wachter Review for the Secretary of State (SoS) in 2016 recognised a lack of clinical and non-clinical informatics professionals (notably CIO, CCIO level) to deliver change, and led to the SoS making a commitment to establish a NHS Digital Academy, one of the key deliverables of the BDRW programme.

In summary, the outcomes we are aiming towards:
•	Improved change/transformation programmes e.g. due to:
-	More effective leadership decision making resulting from leadership campaigns for NHS Trust and care boards, based on an understanding of digital issues that include data security.
-	CIOs/CCIOs being equipped with the skills and knowledge to perform their roles effectively, including those relating to health information systems & technologies; user-centred design & citizen-driven informatics; leadership & transformational change; and decision-support, knowledge management & data analytics.
•	Improved quality of services; e.g., due to digital literacy skills as an enabler for better quality care resulting from increased capability and competence, better understanding of data, information, knowledge and technology, better decision making; and a more flexible workforce.
•	An environment where the 'informatics contribution' outside day-to-day clinical work plays a part in supporting the revalidation process. 
•	Improved staff satisfaction, recruitment & retention; e.g., due to opportunities for individuals to advance their careers with clear opportunities and career paths, and recognition of thei

Title: ESCC LH Workforce NHS Health Checks
Description:
East Sussex County Council (ESCC) intends to commission a service provider to deliver an NHS Health Check Service to its eligible workforce, by offering NHS Health Checks in the workplace across ESCC work sites.
      
      The service seeks to complement the existing provision offered by East Sussex General Practitioner (GP) practices to their patients, by increasing reach and access to working age adults who may find it difficult to access their Health Check during the working day with their GP.
      
      The Department of Health (DH) introduced the NHS Health Check programme in 2009, as a systematic and integrated programme of vascular risk assessment and management for those aged between 40 and 74 years. 
      
      As of April 2013, Local Authorities are required to commission a mandatory programme of NHS Health Checks to enable all of the registered or resident eligible population to be invited for a Health Check, so that the whole eligible population are invited over a 5 year period.
      
      The provider will be expected to provide a minimum of 1216 Health Checks by the project end in December 2018.
      
      The service will be delivered in line with the latest best practice guidance for NHS Health Checks issued by Public Health England and NHS Health Check best practice guidance and NHS Health Check programme standards.

Title: NHS LA Claims Management System (CMS) IT Support
Description:
There is a requirement for the maintenance and support for the NHS LA Claims management system(CMS); and also for the hosting and disaster recovery.
In 2004 the NHS LA commissioned the development of its case management systems (CMS and to align with the changing business processes of the organisation, CMS has rapidly and continually been updated/developed/enhanced to the point where it now forms part of a suite of mission critical and interdependent services utilised by NHS LA staff, our panel of solicitors and members of our schemes. The system now comprises:

•	Intranet
•	Case Management System 
•	Document Transfer System, 
•	Extranet, discussion forums
•	Claims Reporting Service
•	Disaster recovery hosting 

The NHS LA owns CMS and its suite of systems and the direction of travel for the system is that it will continue to be developed to drive automated business processes in the systems of our panel of solicitors and further streamline processes both internally and within the wider NHS in terms of closer collaboration and information sharing. 

A “re-platforming” of the system, (virtualization) has recently been completed and a full sustainability review of the system was undertaken in 2014

NHS LA is now seeking to procure a supplier for the support, development and maintenance of the system. Note: NHS LA are not looking to procure a new Claims Management System .

This notice is to seek suppliers that can provide this support, maintenance, hosting and disaster recovery to the organisation.

More details in the tender documents.

Title: NHS Partnership Commissioning Unit - Personalised Commissioning in York and North Yorkshire Hea
Description:
NHS Partnership Commissioning Unit representing:
•	NHS Hambleton, Richmondshire and Whitby CCG
•	NHS Harrogate and Rural District CCG
•	NHS Scarborough and Ryedale CCG
•	NHS Vale of York CCG
Are hosting a Market Engagement Event in York on the 26 July 2016 and wish to engage with providers to share future commissioning intentions and discuss plans to implement personalised healthcare, including personal health budgets.  

The Commissioners are looking to put in place arrangements that support personal health budgets and explore more personalised ways of delivering healthcare in the future.  

Extensive engagement has already taken place with service users, carers and other stakeholder groups which we will share at the event. 
 
We are looking for providers who can bring added value to the local network of personalised support for our most vulnerable patients. As outlined in the NHS Five Year Forward View and Care Act 2014 the local NHS is committed to providing increased choice and control for patients, particularly those with long-term or enduring health conditions.

Our local offer for Personal Health Budgets is aimed at those with CHC funded care, and we aim to extend this for young people, those receiving Section 117 aftercare, and people with complex Learning Disabilities.
Attachments: Document 0 - Responding to a Tender.pdf
Additional Text:
The market engagement event will comprise of an overview presentation and interactive sessions to better understand the views of the market. Organisations will be able to discuss and share their experiences of the services, best practice and scope for innovation. 

The event will take place in York on Tuesday 26th July 2016 from 1400-1700.

To register please complete and return the registration form in the attachment area on the NHS Sourcing Portal (www.nhssourcing.co.uk) Project_ 20419, pqq_29281.  Further information regarding the venue will be available on receipt of a completed registration form. 

Attendance will be limited to two delegates per organisation.

Title: NHS Leeds South & East CCG Children’s MSK Service
Description:
NHS Leeds South and East CCG, on behalf of the three Leeds CCGs, wish to contract with providers for a Children’s MSK Service for patients registered with a Leeds GP Practice.

Brief Description of Service Requirements: 

To provide a community based specialist physiotherapy service for children and adolescents; to achieve the best health and well-being outcomes for young people suffering with non-acute musculoskeletal conditions. 
In addition, the service will: 
•	Ensure patients are seen and treated in an environment most appropriate to their needs.
•	Improve patient choice and convenience;
•	Ensure a child-friendly environment and flexible appointment system to meet the needs of patients and carers
•	Ensure joined up care and pathways across the whole health community. 
•	Deliver a service which has the ability to flex its resource base to meet capacity 
•	Improve the patient pathway; the service is responsible for developing localised protocols and referral documentation 

A programme of audit and review will be undertaken at predefined intervals to monitor service standards, outcomes and patient satisfaction and the results shared with the commissioner.

All provisions of this service will be expected to meet and comply with NHS standards for IT Governance, Data Protection, security of general and personal information, data and records held and processed and transmitted (via and over all mediums).
The successful provider will be required to sign the NHS Standard Short Form Contract for the service and accept all terms and conditions.

The contract will last for three years with the option to extend for a further 2 years.

Title: 1516-138 Camden and Islington Adult Healthy Lifestyles programme - Lot 1 NHS Health Checks Programme
Description:
LOT 1: NHS Health Checks and Community Outreach - the requirement 
Working as part of the overall Camden and Islington Adult Healthy Lifestyles programme for lot 1 we are seeking a provider who can deliver NHS Health Checks and Community Outreach both as part of the overall lifestyle programme.
NHS Health Checks is a nationally mandated public health programme that aims to keep people well for longer. It is a risk assessment and management programme that aims to prevent or delay the onset of major non-communicable disease including heart disease, stroke, diabetes, and kidney disease through earlier awareness, assessment, and management of risk factors and conditions.  These assessments are targeted at those aged 40 to 74 years with no diagnosed long term conditions. This service will deliver NHS Health Checks in the community alongside those delivered in General Practice. 
In Camden and Islington we recognise that the burden of ill health is such that our populations would benefit from lifestyle interventions that stretch beyond the national eligibility criteria and remit of the NHS Health Checks. 
The immediate aim of both NHS Health Checks and Lifestyle Checks is to identify risk factors; deliver healthy living messages; and motivate behaviour change through relevant behaviour change techniques and onward referral to GPs and the Lifestyle Hub. The approach to Lifestyle Checks has been determined locally but is based on the best practice of the lifestyle elements of the NHS Health Check.

Title: NHS Leeds South and East CCG Social Prescribing Service
Description:
NHS Leeds South and East CCG wish to contract with providers for a Social Prescribing Service for patients registered with a Leeds GP Practice.

Brief Description of Service Requirements: 

The aim of the service is to facilitate, manage, assess and signpost service users to community based services for patients requiring Social Prescribing.

Social Prescribing is often referred to as: ‘A means of enabling primary care services to refer patients with social, emotional or practical needs related to their health and well-being to a range of local, non-clinical services, often provided by the voluntary and community sector, and to broader universal services’ Age Concern (2011).

The objectives of the service are:
— Increase the number referrals made by GP's, health, social care and other relevant professionals to local community activity provision, targeting communities most in need and leading to more local people accessing local community activity in areas of greatest need.
— Increase the number of local people accessing local community activity provision.
— Improve the social support available for individuals by supporting, signposting and connecting people to community groups, activity and provision in the local area.
— Reduce social isolation and improve community connectiveness to contribute to overall improvements in the health and wellbeing of individuals and communities.
— Apply to all residents of LSE, of all ages and operates a flexible, inclusive service to meet diverse needs.

All provisions of this service will be expected to meet and comply with NHS standards for IT Governance, Data Protection, security of general and personal information, data and records held and processed and transmitted (via and over all mediums).

The successful provider will be required to sign the NHS Standard Contract for the service and accept all terms and conditions.

Potential Providers are asked to please note the Following:
— Service specifications, Standard NHS Contract and the electronic application form can be found online at www.nhssourcing.co.uk
— Applications will be received until 3.7.2015
— Applicants are advised to review the service conditions and general conditions for the NHS standard contract before making their applications, these can be found at the following link:
NHS England 2015/16 NHS standard contract.
— If applicants are asked clarification questions during the evaluation stage they will have 48 hours to respond.

The contract will last for 3 years.

As the procurement falls under Part B of Schedule 3 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2006, it is only mandatory for the procurement to comply with Regulation 5 (2).

Title: NHS Wakefield CCG Community Cataract Services AQP Window 2
Description:
In securing services from AQP Providers, NHS Wakefield CCG requires assurance of competence, quality and safety standards, just as it would for services secured under a formal tender process. 

Any provider will be eligible to apply for this AQP subject to demonstrating compliance and competency against the specified criteria outlined in the specification.

The successful provider(s) will deliver a cataract care service to patients registered with a NHS Wakefield CCG GP Practice.

The Provider (s) must also ensure the services delivered are located within the boundaries of Wakefield District and accessible to patients registered with Wakefield GPs.

If more than one provider is successful it will be a contract obligation as service providers to meet quarterly as part of a clinical network to discuss operational issues and work towards continuous improvements to patient pathways and patient experience. 

The successful provider(s) will be expected to sign the standard NHS contract, accepting all terms and conditions.

It should be noted that under the Any Qualified Provider model, there will be no guarantees of volume or payment in the contracts awarded. 

Organisations will be asked to complete an on line qualification questionnaire. 

NHS Wakefield CCG is seeking providers who can provide a cataract care delivered in community settings within the boundaries of Wakefield District for access to Wakefield patients. 

The overarching aims/objectives of the service are: 

• To provide equitable, timely and appropriate access to cataract care; 

• To Provide cataract care in accordance with the commissioning policy of NHS Wakefield CCG; 

• To provide cataract care as part of a care pathway developed by NHS Wakefield CCG; 

• To ensure patients are seen and treated in a safe environment; 

• To provide cataract care as part of the local ophthalmology ‘model of care’ developed by NHS Wakefield CCG; 

• To ensure the effective and sustainable use of resources. 

The overarching outcomes of the service are for the successful provider(s) to evidence: 

• Improved visual outcomes for patients, post-surgery; 

• The incidence of post-operative complications being in accordance with preoperative risk factors

• Patients’ satisfaction with the outcome of surgery.

As the service will be commissioned under AQP arrangements, payment will be made at national tariff for consultant-led care; there is no guarantee of income.

The provider has full responsibility for the costs of any drugs used/prescribed within the service.

No Market Forces Factor (MFF) will be paid for this service.

A CQUIN scheme to the value of 2.5% of the provider’s actual annual activity will be made available
Additional Text:
How to apply 
For further information about this service, to access the service specifications for this service and to apply to provide this Any Qualified Provider service please visit www.nhsssourcing.co.uk

Suppliers Instructions How to Express Interest in this Tender~: 

1. Register your company on the eSourcing portal (this is only required once) - Browse to the eSourcing Portal: https://www.nhssourcing.co.uk and click the link to register - Accept the terms and conditions and click 'continue' - Enter your correct business and user details - Note the username you chose and click 'Save' when complete - You will shortly receive an email with your unique password (please keep this secure)

2. Express an Interest in the tender - Login to the portal with the username/password - Click the 'PQQs / ITTs Open To All Suppliers' link. (These are Pre-Qualification Questionnaires or Invitations to Tender open to any registered supplier) - Click on the relevant PQQ/ ITT to access the content. - Click the 'Express Interest' button at the top of the page. - This will move the PQQ /ITT into your 'My PQQs/ My ITTs' page. (This is a secure area reserved for your projects only) -You can now access any attachments by clicking 'Buyer Attachments' in the 'PQQ/ ITT Details' box 

3. Responding to the tender - Click 'My Response' under 'PQQ/ ITT Details', you can choose to 'Create Response' or to 'Decline to Respond' (please give a reason if declining) - You can now use the ‘Messages’ function to communicate with the buyer and seek any clarification - Note the deadline for completion, then follow the onscreen instructions to complete the PQQ/ ITT - There may be a mixture of online & offline actions for you to perform (there is detailed online help available) You must then submit your reply using the 'Submit Response' button at the top of the page. If you require any further assistance please consult the online help, or contact the eTendering help desk.

Title: APMS GP Contract Opportunities in London
Description:
NHS England London Region invites Expressions of Interest and completed PQQ applications from all suitably qualified and experienced healthcare providers able to deliver Primary Medical Services under an Alternative Provider of Medical Services (APMS) contract. 

16 APMS contracts are offered in different parts of London, forming the 4th tranche (T4) of London’s APMS procurement programme.  Potential providers are invited to express an interest in one or more of these opportunities.

The outline details of the current procurements are as follows: 
•	NHS England (London Regional Teams) Commissioning Approach.
•	A standard APMS Contract has been developed by NHS England’s London Regional Teams
•	The proposed contract term shall be 5 years with an option to extend for up to 5 further years
•	A standard pricing regime will be used for all new proposed APMS contracts. 
•	A common service specification that builds on the most up to date GMS requirements will be used 
•	The contract will incorporate a suite of KPIs and standard performance monitoring arrangements. 

NHS England London Regional is operating an e-Procurement process via the link provided below. Interested Applicants wishing to participate in this procurement activity must express an interest by registering their details and completing the PQQ available from the portal website at: https://procontract.due-north.com/register. 

If you are not already registered on the portal you will need to register.  Guidance on how to register is attached.  Once you have completed this you will need to look for "Current Opportunities". Within this area there will be a project called " APMS GP contract opportunities in London".   Click the link for the opportunity and in the right hand box on the screen titled:  Expression of Interest Window, please log-in and register your interest in this opportunity.  Please follow the instructions to express an interest.  You should then receive two emails; 1: advising that you have successfully registered your interest, 2: advising you that the documents are now available to download.  You will then need to log back into to the portal to access and download the documentation.   

Please note that by expressing an interest you are NOT committing yourself to submit a bid. The closing date for submission of PQQ is: 12.00pm (NOON) on 8th December 2015. Submissions received after the above date and time may not be accepted.  NHS England London Region reserves the right to amend any of the details stated herein.

Notice Identifier: Northumberland Tyne & Wear NHS Foundation Trust C/O Inenco - Gas Portfolio Services Framework
Title: Gas Portfolio Services Framework
Description:
Please note: this contract award notice is linked to the Gas Portfolio Services Framework contract notice.

The Invitation to tender (ITT) was issued to establish a gas portfolio services framework for a central purchasing body covering the UK. 

The lead contracting authority for this tender was Northumberland Tyne & Wear NHS Foundation Trust. The tender process and resulting framework agreement was managed by Inenco, acting as the agent for the central purchasing body. 

The framework is available for use by all National Health Service (NHS) organisations across England, Scotland and Wales. 

The client sought bids from suppliers to participate in a single lot gas portfolio services framework. The primary requirement for this framework is a gas procurement solution, where clients are aggregated into a trade shape to enable consolidated trading of the commodity via the wholesale market.

The framework agreement is to be four years in duration from the commencement date.

The framework is to cover call-off contracts made within England, Scotland and Wales, but excludes Northern Ireland.

The framework is available for use by all NHS organisations including, but not limited to, the following defined groups: 

https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/nhs-foundation-trust-directory/nhs-foundation-trust-directory 
http://www.nhs.uk/ServiceDirectories/Pages/NHSTrustListing.aspx 
http://our.property.nhs.uk/ 
http://www.nhs.uk/ServiceDirectories/Pages/NHSTrustListing.aspx 
http://our.property.nhs.uk/ 
http://www.scot.nhs.uk/organisations/ 
http://www.nhsdirect.wales.nhs.uk/localservices/localhealthboards/ 
http://www.nhs.uk/pages/home.aspx 

Where an entity listed in the above defined groups is succeeded by another entity, the successor entity shall be deemed to be included in the defined groups list. 

The framework is also available to all current and future members of the central purchasing body.
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and The Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West,Scotland,Wales,Isle of Man,Channel Islands
Contact Address 1: St Nicholas Hospital, Jubilee Road, Gosforth

Title: Category Management Service Provider contracts for NHS Supply Chain
Description:
As part of the future Target Operating Model of NHS Supply Chain, the Authority sought to award contracts for the provision of category management services for each of the four defined Product Groups. The procurement was conducted under a single procurement containing four Lots.

Lot 1: Medical Consumables - Surgical Consumables and Infection Control
Lot 2: Medical Consumables - Rehabilitation and Community
Lot 3: Non-Medical - Food; and
Lot 4: Non: Medical - Facilities (including Office Solutions)

During the procurement, Lots 1 and 2 were abandoned, and Lots 3 and 4 continued through to award of contract.

In accordance with Regulation 55(1)(b) of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015, the Authority advises that it did not conclude the procurement procedure for Lots 1 and 2. The procurement commenced on 11/04/2022 under Contract Notice reference 2022/S 000-009671, the decision in respect of Lot 1 and 2 was based on value for money and organisational strategy considerations. The Authority determined that it will transition the services covered by Lots 1 and 2 of the Procurement to an internal delivery model. The Authority considered that insourcing these services will better achieve the objectives of the target operating model.

The Authority will therefore not be awarding any contract for Lot 1 or Lot 2 pursuant to this procurement.

As outlined above, the procurement in respect of Lots 3 and 4 continued, and the Authority has awarded contracts for Lots 3 and 4 as outlined within this award notice.

Each contract will be for an initial period of forty-five months (excluding the anticipated three month implementation period) and may be extended for up to an additional twenty-four months subject to achieving the relevant criteria set out in the contract. The total operative period of the contract, following implementation, shall not exceed sixty-nine months.

Under the contractual arrangements, the Authority appoints Category Management Service Providers (CMSPs) to operate on behalf of NHS Supply Chain. Under the contractual agreements, the CMSPs will procure frameworks for the provision of supplies and/or services which it will make available for purchase by: 1) NHS Supply Chain, 2) any NHS Trust; 3) any other NHS entity or healthcare provider (including private organisations, primary care, community settings and social care); 4) any government department, agency, or other statutory body (including Devolved Authorities, Crown Dependencies and/or Pandemic & Emergency Planning Programmes), and/or 5) any private sector entity active in the UK healthcare sector on behalf of a public-sector organisation listed in 1) to 4) above.
Contact Address 1: Supply Chain Coordination Limited, Equinox House
